div1.head: h

div2.entryFree: alphabetical letter h * [The twenty-sixth letter of the alphabet; called haA='N: it is one of the class termed Haloqiy~apN [or guttural], and is a radical letter, except when written with two dots, p; for which, and for the pronominal values of h, &c., see the Supplement. ― -b2- As a numeral it denotes five.]

R. Q. 1 haA^ohaA^a biAlA_ibili * , (El-Umawee, S, K,) inf. n. hiyhaA='N and haA^ohaA='N, (K,) the latter extr., (TA,) [see ZaA^oZaA^a,] He called the camels to food, or provender, by the cry hiy^o hiy^o: (S, K:) or he chid them, (zajarahaA), by the cry haA^ohaA^o. (K.) [See also arts. jA^ and jyA^.] ― -b2- haA^ohaA^a, inf. n. haA^ohaA='N, He chid a dog. (TA.) ― -b3- He called a dog. (TA.) ― -b4- haA^ohaA^a, inf. n. haA^ohaA='N, He laughed loud and long: [a word imitative of the sound]. (K, TA.)

hiYo'N * , subst. from haA^ohaA^a, [A call to camels to food, or provender]. (S, K.) hiYo'N and jiYo'N are said to be thus written by Az's own hand, with kesr: and are thus written in the Jáme' [of Kz]. (L.) [See arts. jA^ and jyA^.]
haA^ohaA^N * and haA^ohaA='N One who laughs loud and long. (K, TA.) ― -b2- jaAriyapN haA^ohaA^apN A damsel who laughs loud and long. (Lh, TA.)

1 hab~ati Alr~iyHu * , (S, &c.,) aor. tahub~u, (M, &c.,) contr. to analogy; for all reduplicate triliteral verbs that are intrans. have kesr in the aor., except twenty-eight, of which this is one; (Lb;) inf. n. hubuwbN and habiybN (S, K) and hab~N; (K;) but this last is not of high repute; (IDrd;) The wind blew; rose; was in a state of commotion. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- It is also said of a foul, or stinking, odour. (Msb, in art. qwH.) ― -b3- yawomN tahub~uhu Aln~akobaA='u is for tahub~u fiyhi [A day in which the wind called AlnkbA' blows]. (TA, art. HS.) ― -b4- hab~a (assumed tropical:) It (a star) rose: (TA:) [and in like manner, the dawn: see EuTaAsN.] ― -b5- hab~a A_ilaY AlS~alaApi He arose, or went, or betook himself, to prayer. (ISh, from a trad.) ― -b6- hab~a, inf. n. hab~N, (tropical:) He was brisk; lively; sprightly. (TA.) ― -b7- hab~a, inf. n. hab~N and hubuwbN and hibaAbN, He (any person or animal marching or journeying) was brisk, lively, or sprightly, and quick: (K:) or hab~a, aor. yahib~a, with kesr, inf. n. hab~N and hubuwbN, he (any such person or animal) was brisk, lively, or sprightly: and hab~a, [aor. yahub~u,] inf. n. hubuwbN and hibaAbN, he (the same) was quick, and brisk, &c.: ex. hab~ati Aln~aAqapu, aor. tahub~u, with damm, inf. n. hibaAbN, The she-camel was quick in her march, or pace: (TA:) and hab~a AlbaEiyru, inf. n. hibaAbN, The camel was brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his march, or pace. (Lh, S, TA.) See also R. Q. 1. -A2- hab~a, aor. yahub~u, (S,) inf. n. hab~N and hubuwbN (K) and habiybN; (TA;) and ↓ habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He awoke, or became roused, from his sleep. (S, K.) ― -b2- hab~a yafoEalu ka*aA (tropical:) He began to do so; set about doing so; i. q. Tafiqa. (S, K.) ― -b3- [You say] mino A^ayona hababota (assumed tropical:) Whence hast thou come? (K;) as though you said mn Ayn jiy^ota; i. e., mn Ayn A@notabahota lanaA Whence hast thou been roused [to come] to us. (S.) [And] A^ayona habibota Ean~aA, with kesr, (in some copies of the K, Han~aA is put for Ean~aA; but this is a mistake; TA;) Where hast thou absented, or hidden, thyself, from us? or, rather, where hast thou been absent, or hidden, from us? (Yoo, K.) ― -b4- hab~a (tropical:) He was absent a long time. (Yoo, K.) -A3- hab~a, (S, K,) aor. yahib~u, (Msb,) or yahub~u, (Az, TA,) inf. n. hab~apN (S) [and, app., hib~apN,] and hab~N, (TA,) It (a sword, S, K, and a spear, S,) shook, or quivered, (S, K,) and penetrated into the thing struck with it. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- hab~ahu, (aor. yahub~u, TA,) inf. n. hab~N and hab~apN and hib~apN; and ↓ Ahtb~h; (Sh, * K;) It (a sword, Sh,) cut him, or it; or cut it off. (Sh, K.) ― -b3- hab~a He was routed, or put to flight, in battle. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- hab~a, aor. yahib~u (S, K) and yahub~u, (K,) the latter dev. from rule, and not found in other lexicons, but see what is cited above from Lb, that hb~ is one of the twenty-eight verbs which thus deviate from rule, (TA,) inf. n. habiybN and hibaAbN and hib~apN; and ↓ Ahtb~; (S, K;) and ↓ habohaba, (K,) inf. n. habohabapN; (TA;) (tropical:) He (a goat) was excited with lust: (TA;) or uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] and was excited by desire of the female; or uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] when so excited, or at rutting-time: (S, K:) or habohaba signifies he uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] at rutting-time: (TA:) or hab~a, inf. n. hibaAbN and habiybN; and ↓ Ahtb~; He (a stallion-camel, &c.) desired copulation. (M.) ― -b5- hababotu bihi I called him (a goat, TA) ad initum; ut femellam conscenderet. (K.) [F observes, that J's giving hababotuhu in this sense is a mistake: but MF remarks, that what J says is ↓ habohabotuhu, he (MF) having examined many copies of the S and found them all alike in this case, and that this is correct; and this is the reading that I find in both of M. Fresnel's copies of the S: see also tahabohaba, given in the S as quasi-passive of habohabotuhu SM, however, states in the TA, that the reading found by him in a copy of the S in the handwriting of Yákoot, the author of the Moajam, collated with the copy of Aboo-Zekereeya Et-Tebreezee and that of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee, is hbbt bh, as in the K; and this, he says, is the genuine reading.]

2 hb~bh *
He tore it, or rent it, much. (K.)

4 Ahb~ Alr~iyHa * , and ↓ Asthb~hA, [He (God) caused the wind to blow; to rise; to be in a state of commotion]. (A.) -A2- Ahb~h (assumed tropical:) He awoke him, or roused him, from his sleep. (S.) ↓ hab~ahu is said to signify the same; and in proof thereof is adduced a reading in the Kur, deviating from that which is universally received as correct; mano hab~anaA min m~aroqadinaA, instead of mano baEavanaA, Who hath roused us from our sleeping-place? [ch. xxxvi., v. 52;] but IJ rejects this reading, unless it be elliptical, for hab~a binaA. (TA.) -A3- Ahb~ Als~ayofa He shook the sword; or made it to quiver. (Lh, Sh.)
5 thb~b * (tropical:) It (a garment) became worn out, or ragged. (S, K, TA.)
8 A_ihotaba3a see 1.
10 A_isotahoba3a see 4.

R. Q. 1 habohabotuhu * : see hababotu bihi. ― -b2- habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He was quick, or swift. (K.) See also 1. -A2- habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, It (the saraAb, or mirage,) glistened, or shone; syn. taraqoraqa; (K;) i. e., lamaEa. (TA.) -A3- habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He urged, or checked, [app. the former,] with his voice; syn. zajara; (K;) by saying habo. (R, as cited by MF,) or habo habo: [so I understand from the TA, where it is said wAlfEl mnh habo habo; for which it is evident that we should read waA@somu AlfiEoli mnh Alx; meaning “ its ” (imperative) verbal a &c.:] accord. to some, used specially with reference to a horse: see hAb [in art. hyb]. (TA.) You also say habohaba bihi. (TA.) -A4- habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He slaughtered [a beast]. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tahabohaba *
He (a goat, TA, called ad initum, S) shook himself; syn. tazaEozaEa. (S, K.) See hababotu bihi. -A2- jayo$N yatahabohabu An army of which one part presses upon another. (TA, art. jEb.)
hibabN * , pl. of hib~apN: see vawobN habaAy^ibu.

Alhub~apu *
The wind. (TA, voce kub~ap.)

hab~apN * (S) and ↓ hib~apN, (K,) both of which forms are correct, (TA,) (tropical:) The penetration of a sword. (S, K,) or spear, into the thing that is struck with it, and its shaking, or quivering. (S.) ― -b2- *uw hb~pK A sword that shakes, or quivers, and penetrates into the thing struck with it: (S:) and, that falls with vehemence. (TA.) ― -b3- hab~apN (S, K) and ↓ hib~apN, (K,) or the latter only, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) An hour, or a short time, (sAEp,) remaining before dawn. (As, S, K.) ― -b4- hab~apN (S, K) and ↓ hib~apN, (K,) or the latter only, (TA,) (tropical:) An indefinite period of time; syn. HiqobapN: (S, K:) a long time; syn. dahorN. (Az.) Ex. Ei$onaA bi*`lika hb~pF mina Ald~ahori We lived therein, or in that [state], some time, [or a long time]: like the saying sab~apF. (AZ, S.) ― -b5- [You say] raA^ayotuhu hab~apF I saw him once (K) in life. (TA.) ― -b6- qado jaA'aniY hab~apF He has come [in] to me once. Occurring in a trad.; said by a woman in allusion to her husband's having once come in to her: (TA:) i. q. waqoEapF. (Msb.) See art. Esl in the Mgh.

hib~apN * : see hab~apN throughout. ― -b2- A state, or condition: [or perhaps the meaning intended is the state of being brisk, lively, or sprightly, and quick]. (K.) Ex. A_in~ahu laHasanu Alhib~api Verily he is in a good state, or condition, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- hib~apN The state of a stallion when excited by desire of the female. (S.) See 1. -A2- hib~apN A piece of a garment, or the like: (K:) pl. hibobN, (S, K:) a piece of rag. (TA.) ― -b2- See vawobN habaAy^ibu.
hab~Y * mentioned on the Nawádir of Th, and said to be from hubuwbu Alr~iyHi, but not of established authority: [unexplained]. (TA.)

habohabN * A wolf that is light, or active, and quick, or swift, of pace. (K.) See habohabiY~N. ― -b2- A certain valley of hell, the place of abode of tyrants, oppressors, and the like. (TA, from a trad.)

habohabiY~N *
Quick, or swift: as also ↓ habohabN and ↓ habohaAbN. (K.) ― -b2- A light, or active, camel: fem. with p. (K.) ― -b3- habohabiY~N One who serves well; a good servant. (K.) ― -b4- Any one who does well a small thing: accord. to some, specially, a cook, and a roaster of meat. (TA.) ― -b5- A butcher; syn. qaS~aAbN, [from habohaba “ he slaughtered ”]. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- habohabiY~N One who signs well to camels, to urge, or excite, them. (K.) ― -b7- habhabiY~N A pastor: (S:) or a pastor of sheep or goats: or the he-goat of a flock. (K.)
habaAbN * i. q. habaA'N [Dust, &c.: see habuwbu]. (K.)
habuwbN * and ↓ habuwbapN and ↓ habiybN A wind that [blows violently, and] raises the dust. (S, K.)
habuwbpN * : see habuwbN.
habiybN * : see habuwbN.

habohaAbN * : see habohabiY~N. -A2- Clamorous; a bawler. (K.) -A3- habohaAbN The saraAb, or mirage. (M, K.) ― -b2- habohaAbN A certain game of children, (K,) of the children of El-'Irák, (TA,) or of the children of the Arabs of the desert. (T.)
vawobN habaAy^ibu * , (As, S, K,) as also xabaAy^ibu, (As, S,) and ↓ A^ahobaAbN, and ↓ hibabN, (K,) (tropical:) A garment rent in pieces, ragged, or tattered. (As, S, K.)
riyHN haAb~apN * [A wind blowing; rising; in a state of commotion.] (A.)
vawobN A^ahobaAbN * : see vawobN habaAy^ibu. [mahab~N A place of blowing of the wind.]

mihobaAbN * (S, L, K) and ↓ muhotab~N (S) and ↓ muhab~abN, of the same measure as muEaZ~amN, (L,) (tropical:) A he-goat that is much excited with lust: or that rattles much, and is much excited by desire of the female: or that rattles much when so excited: see 1. (S, K.)
muhab~abN * and muhotab~N: see mihobaAbN.

1 habatahu * , aor.
habita , (inf. n. habotN, TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, him (A, 'Obeyd, S, K) with a sword. (Sh.) Ex. habtuwhumaA Hat~aY faraguwA minohumaA They smote them both with swords until they slew them (TA, from trad.) ― -b2- habatahu, aor.
habita , He, or it, lowered him, syn. habaTahu and TaA^oTaA^ahu and HT~ahu. (K,) with respect to station, rank, or dignity (TA:) and abased him; debased him; rendered him abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (L.) Ex. habatahu Almawotu EinodiY mnozlapF Death lowered him in my estimation with respect to rank, or dignity, because he died upon his bed. and did not die a martyr. From a trad. (Fr.) ― -b3- hubita He was lowered with respect to rank, station, or dignity. (Fr.) ― -b4- hubita (like EuniYa, [i. e. pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (K,) He (a man) was cowardly, and his intellect quitted him: (S, K:) he was without intellect. (TA.) ― -b5- habata, aor. habita see habiytN.

habotN *
Softness; laxity. (L.) ― -b2- Stupidity, foolishness, stupefaction. (TA.)

habotapN *
Weakness (S, K) in intellect. (S.) Ex. fiY Eaqolihi hbtpN There is a weakness in his intellect. (S.) fyh hbtpN There is a stroke of stupidity in him: or there is in him what resembles heedless ness, and unsoundness of intellect: (TA:) or habotapN signifies loss of reason. (TA in art. xlE.)

entryFree.key: maA tasoA^alu Eano $ayoxK nawomuhu subaAtN walayoluhu hubaAtN

div2.entryFree:
maA tasoA^alu Eano $ayoxK nawomuhu subaAtN walayoluhu hubaAtN *
Dust thou not inquire respecting an old man, whose sleep is that of a sick person, or of one far advanced in years, or whose sleep is light, TA, art. sbt,) [and whose night is one of languor.] From a trad. hbAt. here, is from habotN, as signifying “ softness, and laxity. ” (TA.)

habiytN * One in whom is sudden fright, or terror. and a shrinking (talab~u*) [by reason of fear]. (L.) ― -b2- habiytN and ↓ mahobuwtN A cowardly man, whose intellect is quitting him: (S, K:) a man without intellect. (TA.) ― -b3- In the saying of a poet, na$owatuhaA habiytu, quoted, limit not expl., by Th, hbyt is thought by ISd to be of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN. and to signify, $aYo'N yahobitu, i. e. A thing that stupefies, or renders foolish, and confounds, perplexes, or amazes, and thus stills, or quiets and causes to sleep. The poet says,
turiyka qa*FY bihaA A_ino kaAna fiyhaA
buEayoda Aln~awomi na$owtuhaA habiytu
[he is app. describing clear and strong wine, and says, It will show thee a mote in it, if it be therein: a little after sleep, (even,) the intoxication (which is the result) thereof is a thing that stupefies, &c.]. (TA.)

mahobuwtN *
Confounded; perplexed; amazed; i. q. mahofuwtN. (TA, art. hft.) mahobuwtu Alfuw^aAdi A man of a cowardly heart, without intellect. (S.) See habiytN ― -b2- mahobuwtN Lowered with respect to rank, station, or dignity. (Fr.) ― -b3- mahobuwtu Alt~araAqiY Having depressed, deficient, collar-bones, or clavicles. (Fr.) -A2- mahobuwtN A bird that is sent forth at random; without being rightly directed; [without being let fly at some other particular bird]. Thought by IDrd to be a post-classical word in this sense. (TA.)

1 hbv maAlahu * , aor.
habuva , inf. n. habovN, He scattered, or squandered, his property. (L.)
Q. Q. 1 hanobava * : see hanobavapN.

hanobavapN *
A severe, difficult, or afflictive, affair: (S, K:) pl. hanaAbivu: the n is an augmentative letter. (TA.) The pl. also signifies calamities: and confused affairs and news. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, Confusion in speech, or, in what is said: (S, K:) [probably an inf. n, of which the verb is hanobava].

1 habijN * , aor.
habaja , inf. n. habajN; (L;) and ↓ thb~j He, or it [a camel's udder], became swollen; or had a tumour [or habaj]. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- habija It (a man's face) became swollen, and contracted: (L:) [and so ↓ thb~j, in the K, art. rhl: see its part. n.] ― -b3- habajahu, (S, K,) aor.
habaja , (K,) or
habija , [which is more probably right,] (L,) inf. n. habojN, (S, L,) He beat him, or struck him, (S, K,) with a staff, or stick: like HabaHahu (S) [and xabajahu]: or, with uninterrupted blows, but not violently: or, with a piece of wood, like as one beats a dog in killing him: or he beat him in any part of him that he saw. (TA.)

2 hb~jhu * , inf. n. tahobiyjN, It caused him, or it, [a camel's udder], to become swollen; or to have a tumour [or habaj]. (S, K.) ― -b2- hb~j wajohahu [It rendered his face swollen: see habija:] said of much sleep. (TA, in art. rhl.) ― -b3- hb~j He killed a dog, [app. by beating]. (L.)
5 tahab~aja see 1.

habajN *
A thing like a tumour, in a she-camel's udder: (S, K:) it is a tumour, or swelling, of the slightest kind. (TA.)
habijN * : see what follows.

muhab~ajN * A man swollen; or affected with a tumour. (TA.) A swollen face of a man; (A;) as also ↓ habijN, (L,) and ↓ mutahab~ij. (A.) ― -b2- A man heavy, or dull, in spirit; syn. vqiylu Aln~afosi. (S, K.)
mutahab~ijN * : see muhab~ajN.

1 habada Alhabiyda * , aor.
habida , (L, K,) inf. n. habodN, (L,) He broke habiyd, (Lth, L, K,) i. e. colocynths: (Lth, L:) or (in the K, and) he cooked habiyd [i. e., colocynths or their seeds]: (L, K:) or (in the K, and) he gathered habiyd [i. e. colocynths]; (L, K;) as also ↓ thb~dhu and ↓ Ahtbdhu; (K;) or ↓ thb~d and ↓ Ahtbd; which are said of an ostrich and of a man: and these two verbs signify he (an ostrich or a man) extracted habiyd [or colocynth-seeds] to eat: (L:) you say of an ostrich ↓ huwa yatahab~adu he extracts the seeds of the colocynth to eat them: and ↓ thb~d signifies he took a colocynth, or colocynths, and broke it, or them: (S, L:) or he (an ostrich) broke a colocynth, or colocynths, and ate its, or their seeds: (A:) and he gathered colocynths and macerated them in water: (L:) and ↓ Ahtbd he [an ostrich) pierced colocynths with his beak, and ate their seeds: (T, L:) and he took the seeds of dry colocynths, and put them in a place, and poured upon them water, and rubbed and pressed them with the hand, then poured off from them the water, and did this for some days, until their bitterness was gone; after which they are bruised, or brayed, and cooked: (S, L:) or he prepared for food (EaAlaxa) the pulp of colocynths. (AHeyth, L. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce rAjlp.]) ― -b2- Also habadahu, (aor. as above, L,) He fed him (namely a man, K) with habiyd. (L, K.)
5 tahab~ada and 8: see 1.
habodN * : see habiydN.

habiydN * The colocynth; as also ↓ habodN: (L, K:) or the seeds of the colocynth; (S, A, L, K;) as also habodN: (L, K:) n. un. of the former, [which is a coll. gen. n.,] with p: (L:) or the pulp of the colocynth. (AHeyth, L.) ― -b2- [See barowaqN] ― -b3- Also, A certain food, which is eaten in cases of necessity, made by breaking colocynths, and taking forth their seeds, and macerating these in water, that their bitterness may go, and then cooking them: (Nh, L:) or colocynths macerated for some days in water, then washed, and, after their upper rind has been thrown away, cooked; to which is added some flour; and sometimes EaSiydap is made of it: (AA, L:) or a food made by macerating in water the seeds of dried colocynths, and heating this water until its bitterness has gone, then pouring upon it some grease, and sprinkling upon it a little flour, after which it is supped. (L.)

rajulN haAbidN *
A man who gathers colocynths: (TA:) and hawaAbidu [pl. of haAbidapN] women who gather colocynths. (K.)
see h*b
1 habara * , &c.: see Supplement.]
DarobN haborN * : see saEorN.

hiboriyapN * (S, K) and ↓ hubaAriyapN (TA) [Scurf on the head;] what is in the hair of the head, resembling bran; (S;) the dirt of the head, that clings to the lower part of the hair, resembling bran; (K;) as also A_iboriyapN (TA) and tiboriyapN. (AO, S, K, in art. tbr.) ― -b2- Also, [both ↓ words,] What flies about, of, or from, feathers, (K, TA,) and the like: (TA:) and the former, what flies about, of, or from, the down of cotton: (K:) or the fine down that flies about from cotton: (L:) and what becomes scattered about, and compacted, of, or from, canes, or reeds, and the barodiY~ [or papyrus]: (Yaakoob:) pl. of the former, hiboriyaAtN. (TA.)
hubaAriyapN * : see above, in two places.

hab~uwrN *
Barley growing, or growing forth; in the Nabathaean language. (Sa'eed ibn Jubeyr, TA, art. ESf.)

1 haba$a * , aor.
habi$a , (S, TA,) inf. n. habo$N, (S, A, K,) He collected a thing; (TA;) as also habi$a, aor.
haba$a : (ISk, ISd:) he collected; and gained or earned, or sought sustenance; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ thb~$: (S, A:) or he practised some art or trade, to procure sustenance; and he exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs: (TA:) and ↓ Ahtb$ and ↓ thb~$ he gained or earned, or sought sustenance; and collected; and exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs: (ISd, TA:) and ↓ hb~$, inf. n. tahobiy$N, he collected much; syn. jm~E. (K.) You say, huwa yahobi$u liEiyaAlihi He collects; and gains or earns, or seeks sustenance; for his family, or household; (S;) as also ↓ yatahab~a$u: (S, A:) or practises some art or trade, to procure sustenance for them; exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs, for them. (TA.) [See also Haba$a.] ― -b2- haba$otuhu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) I obtained it, (K, TA,) by collecting and gaining or earning. (TA.) And minohu EaTaA='F ↓ Ahtb$ He obtained from him a gift. (K.) ― -b3- haba$a Alganama, inf. n. as above, [app. meaning He roused and scared the sheep or goats, and drove and collected them to some
person or place,] is like naja$a AlS~ayoda. (Ibn- 'Abbád.)
2 hab~a$a see 1.

5 thb~$ * : see 1, in three places. -A2- Also, and ↓ Ahtb$, It became collected; or it collected itself: or the former, it became collected, or it collected itself, from several places: syns. tajam~aEa and A_ijotamaEa. (K.) And thb~$ Alqawomu The company of men became collected as an army, or a military force; or collected itself into an army, or a military force. (TA.)
8 A_ihotaba$a see 1, in two places: -A2- and see 5.

hubaA$apN *
i. q. HubaA$apN; (S, K;) i. e. What is collected, of men, and of property: (S, TA:) a company, or body, of men, not of one tribe: (TA, in art. Hb$:) and what one gains or earns, and collects, of property: pl. hubaA$aAtN. (TA.)

hab~aA$N *
One who collects; and who gains, or earns, or seeks sustenance: (S:) or who does so much: (Lth, K, TA;) and who exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs, for his family, or household. (Lth, TA.)

mahobuw$N *
Collected; and gained or earned. (S, * TA.)

1 habaTa * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
habiTa and
habuTa , (Msb, K,) but the latter is of rare occurrence, (Msb,) inf. n. hubuwTN, (S, K,) of that whereof the aor. is
habiTa , and of that whereof the aor. is
habuTa ; (TA;) or of the latter only, that of the former being haboTN; (Msb;) He, or it, (said of water &c., Msb,) descended: (S, Msb, K:) and ↓ thb~T he descended, or went down, or went down a declivity; and it sloped down; syn. A_inoHadara; (TA;) and ↓ AnhbT signifies the same as this last; or (assumed tropical:) he became lowered, or degraded; syn. A_inoHaT~a; (K;) being quasi-pass. of ↓ A^ahobaTahu, (S, TA,) and it may be also of habaTahu, as is said in the M. (TA.) You say, habaTonaA fiY HaduwrK SaEobapK [We descended a difficult declivity]. (A, in art. Hdr.) And habaTa AlwaAdiYa, (Bd, ii. 58, and Msb,) [as though it were trans., for fiY AlwaAdiY,] inf. n. hubuwTN, (Msb,) We descended into the valley. (Bd, Msb.) And habaTa minohu He came forth from it. (Bd, ubi supra.) It is said in the Kur, ii. 58, A_ihobiTuwA miSorFA Descend ye into Misr: (Bd:) accord. to one reading, A^uhobuTuwA. (Bd, TA.) You say also habaTa balada ka*aA He entered such a town or country. (K.) And habaTotu mino mawoDiEK A_ilaY mawoDiEK I removed him from a place to a place. (Msb.) ― -b2- haboTN also signifies (tropical:) The falling into evil: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) the being, or becoming, low, abject, mean, or vile: (TA:) and (tropical:) the suffering loss, or diminution. (K, TA.) You say, habaTa mino manozilatihi (tropical:) He fell from his honourable station. (TA.) [See also 7, mentioned above.] And habaTa fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one became low, abject, mean, or vile. (TA.) And habaTa mina Alxa$oyapi (tropical:) He became mean, or abject, and lowly, or submissive, from fear (TA.) [See Kur, ii. 69.] And habaTa Alqawomu, aor.
habiTa , (tropical:) The people, or company of men, became in a state of abasement and diminution. (TA.) Whence the trad., (TA,) A^all~`hum~a gaboTFA laA haboTFA, (S, TA,) i. e. nasoA^aluka AlgiboTapa wanaEuw*u bika mino A^ano nahobiTa Eano HaAlinaA ((tropical:) O God, we ask of Thee a good state, or condition, and we put our trust in Thee for preservation that we may not become brought down from our state]: (S.) mentioned [and explained] before, in art. gbT, q. v. (TA.) [But in this instance, haboTFA may be regarded as the inf. n. of the trans. v. to be mentioned below.] You say also, habaTato A_ibiliY waganamiY, aor. habiTa , inf. n. hunuwTN, (assumed tropical:) My camels, and my sheep, or goats, suffered loss, or diminution: and in the same sense habaTa is said of flesh, and of fat, and of fatness. (TA.) And habaTa vamanu Als~iloEapi (tropical:) The price of the commodity, or article of merchandise, became diminished, or lessened, (S, Msb, K, TA.) below its former full rate; (Msb;) became lowered, or abated. (TA.) And habaTa AlEidolu (assumed tropical:) The counterpoising portion of the load became adjusted or arranged, made even, or made easy, upon the camel. (TA.) -A2- habaTahu, (S, Msb. K.) aor.
habuTa , (K,) inf. n. haboTN, (S,) He made him, or it, (namely water. &c., Msb,) to descend: (S, Msb, K;) [he sent, or east, him, or it, down;] as also ↓ AhbThu. (K.) You say, Als~anapu A_ilaY ↓ A^ahobaTatohumu AlA^amoSaAri [The year of dearth, or drought, caused them to go down to the cities, or great towns]. (A, in art. Hsr.) And habaTahu balada ka*aA He, or it, caused him to enter such a town or country. (K.) [And habaTa bihi EalaY makaAnK He, or it, made him to alight upon a place: see an ex. voce zaH~a.] ― -b2- (tropical:) He lowered him, or degraded him, from his state, or condition; (Fr;) as also ↓ AhbThu; (Fr, S;) i. e., God did so; (Fr;) or a man: (S:) it (time, or fortune,) caused his wealth, and his goodness or beneficence, to go away, after he had abounded therein. (TA.) ― -b3- habaTa AlmaraDu laHomahu (tropical:) The disease rendered him lean; emaciated him: (S, K:) or diminished his flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- habaTa vamana Als~iloEapi, (S, K.) inf. n. haboTN, (K,) (tropical:) He (God, K, or a man, S) diminished, or lessened, the price of the commodity, or article of merchandise; (S, K;) he lowered, or abated, it; (TA;) as also ↓ AhbThu, said of a man: (A 'Obeyd, S, M:) or habaTa mina Alv~amani (assumed tropical:) he diminished somewhat from the price; and sometimes ↓ AhbThu is used in this sense. (Msb.) ― -b5- habaTa AlEidola (assumed tropical:) He adjusted or arranged, made even, or made easy, the counterpoising portion of the load upon the camel (TA.) ― -b6- habaTa fulaAnFA He beat, or struck, such a one. (K.)
4 A^ahobaTa see habaTahu, in five places.
5 tahab~aTa see habaTa, first sentence.
7 A_inohabaTa see habaTa, first sentence.

haboTapN *
A low, or depressed, piece of land or ground; (Mgh, K;) contr. of SaEodapN. (Mgh.)

habuwTN *
A declivity, or declinal place, a place of descent, or by which one descends, (S, Msb, K;) a place which brings one down from a higher to a lower place. (Az, TA.)

habyTN * (tropical:) Lean, or emaciated, by reason of disease; as also ↓ mahobuwTN: (K:) both are applied to a camel, signifying whose fatness has become diminished; as also ↓ haAbiTN: (TA:) and the first, to a she-camel, signifying lean, and lank in the belly; (AO, S;) or to a wild bull, to which a she-camel is likened in respect of her swiftness, and her briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness (IB:) and ↓ the second signifies rendered lean. or emaciated, by disease, so that his flesh quivers. (TA.)

haAbiTN * [act. part. n. of 1, both intrans. and trans.] The rájiz says,
maA raAEainY A_il~aA janaAHN haAbiTaA
EalaY Albuyuwt qawoTahu AlEulaAbiTaA
[Nothing surprised me but the wolf sending down upon the tents his flock of sheep, or goats, fifty or more in number]: he means muhobiTFA qawoTahu: so says ISd: or he may mean haAbiTFA EalaY qawoTihi [descending upon his flock, &c.]; making hAbTA trans by ellipsis: (TA:) jnAH, in this verse, is the name of a wolf. (TA, in art. jnH.) ― -b2- See also habiyTN.
mahobiTu AlwaHoYi * [The place of descent of revelation;] a name of Mekkah. (Msb, TA)
mahobuwTN * (tropical:) A man whose state, or condition has become unsound. (TA.) ― -b2- See also habyTN, in two places.

div2.head: hbE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 hat~a * , aor.
hati3a , inf. n. hatiytN, He (a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a sound resembling a squeezing of the voice ($bh AlESr llSwt): you say, of a bkr, observes Az, yahit~u, inf. n. as above; then, yaki$~u, inf. n. ka$iy$N then yahodiru, inf. n. hadiyrN. (L.) ― -b2- hat~a Alhamozapa, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, He uttered the letter hemzeh. (L.) [See mahotuwtN.] ― -b3-
ht, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, He uttered, recited, or repeated, a speech or the like, with uninterrupted fluency; syn. sarada (S, L, K) and taAbaEa. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence] hat~ato gazolahaA, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, She spun her thread one part immediately after another: (TA:) she spun her thread continuously: (Az:) hat~N signifies a woman's spinning thread continuously. (K.) -A2- hat~a, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N; and ↓ hatohata, inf. n. hatohatapN; He broke a thing, (K,) so that it became reduced to small fragments, or particles: (TA:) he stamped upon a thing vehemently, so that he broke it. (TA.) ― -b2- hat~a, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, He rent clothes. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) He rent the reputation of another. (IAar, K.) -A3- hat~a, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, He removed the leaves of a tree [by rubbing or scraping the branches]; syn. Hat~a; (K [in the CK, hat~, is put for Ht~;]) i. e. he took them. (TA.) -A4- hat~a, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, He poured out, or forth, [water, &c.] (K.) ― -b2- hat~a AlmazaAdapa He poured out, or forth, [the contents of] the mzAdp. (TA.) ― -b3- hat~a $ayoy^FA He poured out, or forth, one part or portion of a thing immediately after another. (TA.) ― -b4- Als~aHaAbapu taHut~u AlmaTara The cloud pours forth the rain continuously. (TA.) -A5- hat~a, aor.
hatu3a , inf. n. hat~N, he lowered (HaT~a) a person with respect to rank, or dignity, in [the manner of] paying honour [to him]. (IAar, K.) [Comp. hbt.]

R. Q. 1 hatohata *
He urged a camel (zajarahu) on the occasion of drinking, by the cry hato hato. (AHeyth, K.) See hato, below. ― -b2- hatohata, inf. n. hatohatapN; as also tahotaha; He twisted, or distorted, his tongue in speaking. (Az.) ― -b3- Also htht; (and ↓ hat~a, TA, [aor.
hati3a ?];) He was quick, or rapid, in his speech. (K.) ― -b4- See hat~a.

hato * , (TA,) or hato hato, (K,) A cry by which a camel is urged (yuzojaru) on the occasion of drinking. (K.) ― -b2- A_i*aA waq~afota AlbaEiyra EalaY Alr~adohapi falaA taqulo lahu hato; or, as some say, falaA tuhatohito bihi; [When thou hast made the camel to stand over the hollow in the rock in which the rain-water has collected, say not to him hato]. A proverb; meaning, accord. to AHeyth, when thou hast shewn a man his right course of conduct, do not urge him. (TA.) ― -b3- hat~u qawaAy^imi AlbaEiyri The sound of the falling of the camel's feet [upon the ground]. (L.) -A2- tarakahumo hat~FA bat~FA [He left them routed, or broken asunder, and cut off;] he broke them asunder: or he cut them in pieces. (L.)

hatiytN *
A sound. Occurring in a trad. as signifying a sound made by wine poured out upon the ground. (L.) -A2- hatiytN and ↓ mahotuwtN A thing broken so as to be reduced to small fragments, or particles: stamped upon vehemently, so as to be broken. (TA.)
hat~aAtN * : see mihat~N.
rajulN mihat~N * , and ↓ hat~aAtN, A man quick and voluble in speech; (S, K;) incorrectly, and vainly, or frivolously, loquacious; a great babbler. (TA.)

mahotuwtN * : see hatiytN. ― -b2- Alhamozapu SawotN mahotuwtN fiY A^aqoSaY AlHaloqi [Hemzeh is a sound uttered (after a suppression of the breath) in the most remote part of the throat]. (Kh, L.) Sb applied the term Almahotuwtu to the letter h, because of its weakness and lowness. (L.) ― -b3- A^asoraEu mina Almuhatohitapi Quicker than the quick-speaking woman. (IAar.)

1 hataA^a * , aor.
hataAa , (K,) inf. n. hato'N, (TA,) He beat a person (K) with a staff or stick. (TA.) ― -b2- hatiy^a, aor.
hataAa , He was bent, or crooked. (K.)

5 tht~A^ *
It (a garment) became ragged, and worn out. (S, K.)

maDaY mina All~ayoli hato'N * , and ↓ hito'N, (ISk, K,) and ↓ hatiYo'N, (Lh, K,) and ↓ hatiY~N, (Lh,) and ↓ hitaA'N, and ↓ hiytiy^N (same measure as ziborijN, as in the TA), or ↓ hitoyaA='N, (as in the CK and a MS. copy) and ↓ hiytaA='N, (K,) and ↓ hatoA^apN, (AHeyth, K,) A portion of the night elapsed (K, &c.) ― -b2- maA baqiYa mino ganamihimo A_il~aA hito'N There remained not, of their sheep, or goats, save a part, less than the part that had gone away. (TA.)
hito'N * : see hato'N.
hataA^N * and ↓ hutuwo'N A rent. (K.) ― -b2- A swelling: syn. nutuw~N, (TA.)
hatoA^apN * : see hato'N.
hitaA='N * : see hato'N.
hatiYo'N * : see hato'N.
hatiY~N * : see hato'N.
hutuwo'N * : see hataA^N.
hitoyaA='N * : see hato'N.
hiytaA='N * : see hato'N.
hiytiy^N * : see hato'N.

A^ahotaA^u *
Humpbacked. (K.)

1 hatarahu * , aor.
hatira , (K, TA,) like yaDoribu, (TA [in the CK, -, but this is evidently a mistake,]) It (old age, K, TA, and disease and grief, TA), made him to be such as is called muhotarN; [i. e., made him to lose his reason, or intellect: or to be addicted to, or fond of, speaking of a thing: which latter signification seems to be particularly indicated in the lexicon from which this is taken; but the former seems the more appropriate.] (K.)

3 hAtrhu * , [inf. n. muhaAtarapN and hitaArN,] He encountered him with mutual reviling, saying what was false: (K, * TA:) so says IAmb, on the authority of AZ; but, says Th, accord. to others, AlmuhaAtarapu signifies the saying [that] whereof one part contradicts, or annuls, another: and hence one says, daEi AlhitaAra [leave the saying that whereof one part contradicts another]. (TA.)

4 A^uhotira *
He became disordered in his intellect: (A, TA:) or he became so by reason of old age: (S:) or he lost his reason from old age, (AZ, A'Obeyd, K,) as also ↓ A_isotahotara, (AZ, TA,) or from disease, or grief; as also A^ahotara. (K.) See also 10, in two places.

5 tht~r *
He was, or became, stupid, and ignorant. (K: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.)

6 thAtrA *
They accused each other falsely. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And hence, thAtrt Albay~inaAtu, (Msb,) and Al$~ahaAdaAtu, (A, Mgh,) The testimonies, or evidences, became null: (Mgh, Msb:) or belied one another. (A.)

10 A_isotahotara * : see 4. ― -b2- He was, or became, much given to false, or vain, sayings, or actions. (TA [but this seems rather to be A^usotuhotira: see its part. n., below.]) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He followed his own natural desire, not caring what he did. (Msb [but this also seems to be in the pass. form.]) ― -b4- A^usotuhotira bika*aA (tropical:) He became addicted to, or fond of, such a thing, (K, TA,) not talking of any other thing, (TA,) nor caring what was done to him, (K, TA,) nor how he was reviled: (K:) he became addicted to, or fond of, such a thing, not talking of, nor doing, any other thing: and he became fascinated by such a thing, and lost his reason on account of it, and his strong determination became turned towards it, so that he talked much and vainly respecting it. (TA.) ― -b5- A_isotahotara bifulaAnapa, [or A^usotuhotira,] and bihaA ↓ A^ahotara, [or A^uhotira,] (tropical:) He [became attached, or devoted, to such a woman so that he] cared not what was said of him on her account, nor how he was reviled: (A, TA:) and ↓ A^uhotira also signifies (assumed tropical:) he became addicted or given to, or fond of, speaking of a thing. (K.)
hutorN * The loss of reason from old age or disease or grief. (K.)

hitorN *
An error in speech. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, jaA='a bihitorK mina Alqawoli He uttered
an error of speech. (A.) And ↓ hitorN haAtirN A great error of speech. (S, K. *) ― -b2- A falsehood; a lie. (K.) You say, qawolN hitorN A false saying (TA.)
haAtirN * : see hitorN.

tahaAtiru *
Testimonies, or evidences, that belie one another: as though pl. of tahotarN: (K:) or any evidences, or testimonies, that are not legal proofs (Mgh [but in my copy of that work written tahAtur.])

muhotarN *
Disordered in his intellect, (S,) or having lost his reason, (AZ, A'Obeyd, K,) from old age. (AZ, A'Obeyd, S, K,) or from disease, or grief: (K:) if from A^ahotara, it is anomalous. (K, TA,) like muHoSanN, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Addicted or given to, or fond of, speaking of a thing (K.) See also musotahotarN.

muhotirN *
Erring in his speech. (TA.)

musotahotarN *
Much given to false, or vain, sayings, or actions: (K:) or one who says what is false or erroneous: or one who cares not what is said of him, nor how he is reviled: or (assumed tropical:) attached, or devoted, (musotahotarN,) to the world (IAth, TA) ― -b2- musotahotarN bi$aYo'K (tropical:) Addicted to, or fond of, a thing, (K, TA,) or fascinated by it, (A,) not talking of any other thing, (TA,) nor caring what is done to him, (A, K, TA,) nor how he is reviled, (K,) having lost his reason; (A.) as also ↓ muhotarN. (A.) You say, fulaAnN musotahotarN biAl$~araAbi (tropical:) Such a one is addicted to, or fond of, drink, not caring what is said of him. (S.)

div2.head: ht$ &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 hav~a * , aor.
havu3a , inf. n. hav~N, He mixed a thing, one part with another. (M.) ― -b2- hav~a, [aor.
havi3a ,] inf. n. hav~N, He lied. (IAar, K.)

R. Q. 1 havohava * , inf. n. havohavapN, He mixed, or confounded; like mavomava. (TA.) hvhv A^amorahu He confounded his affair. (TA.) ― -b2- havohava, inf. n. havohavapN, It was mixed, or confounded. (S, K.) ― -b3- havohava, (inf. n. havohavapN, K,) He (a magistrate, S) acted unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, K.) ― -b4- hvhv Aln~aAsa He (a magistrate) acted unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards the people. (TA.) -A2- havohava, inf. n. havohavapN, It sent forth quickly: (K:) [ex.] havohavati Als~aHaAbapu biquTorihaA wavalojihaA The cloud sent forth quickly its rain and its snow. (S.) -A3- havohava, inf. n. havohavapN (and hvhAv, TA) He trod, or trampled, vehemently. (K.) ― -b2- It (a pasturing herd or flock) trod the fresh green pasture until it was destroyed, HtY ywtY [So in the L, app. Hat~aY yuw^utiYa].)

hav~N * and ↓ havohavapN and ↓ hvhAv A confusion of sounds, noises, or voices, in war or a raising of a loud cry, or clamour, or confused noise (M,) [App. inf. n., of which the verbs are hav~a and havohava]
havohavapN * and ↓ havohaAvN A word imitative of somewhat of the speech of him who has the vitious kind of pronunciation termed luvogap (TA.) See hav~N

havohaAvN *
Quick (K) rain (TA.) ― -b2- havohaAvN Confused, confounded: (K,) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b3- See hav~N ― -b4- And see hav~aAvN and havohavapN ― -b5- havohaAvN A town, or district, abounding with dust. (K)
hivohaAvN * : see hav~N.
hav~aAvN * and ↓ havohaAvN A liar, (K.) ― -b2- Also, the latter, A man who tells unmixed lies. (TA.)

div2.head: hvm &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haj~ati Aln~aAru * aor.
haji3a , inf. n. hajiyjN and haj~N; (L;) The fire burned fiercely, or intensely; or flamed, or blazed. or burned without smoke, fiercely, or intensely or, made a noise, or sound: hajiyjui Aln~aAr being the same as A^ajiyjuhaA, (S, L, K) like as haraAqa is the same as A^araAqa (S, L,) or, burned, and caused a sound, or noise, to be heard by its burning. (L.) -A2- See art. Eaj~a, last para.

2 hj~j Aln~aAra *
He made the fire to burn fiercely, or intensely; or to flame, or blaze, or burn without smoke, fiercely, or intensely: or, to make a noise, or sound, or to burn so as to cause a sound, or noise. to be heard by its burning. (L.) ― -b2- hj~j He (a camel) had his eyes sunk in his bead by reason of hanger or thirst or fatigue; not by their natural formation. (Lth, As.) ― -b3- haj~ajato EayonuhN [so in three copies of the S, and in the L; not haj~ato, as Golius seems to have found it written in a copy of the S;] His eye became sunk in its socket, (As, S) In the saying of the daughter of El-Khuss, when she was asked how she knew a she-camel to be pregnant, A^araY AlEayona haAj~o waAls~anaAma raAj~o watamo$iY fatufaAj~o [I see the eye to have become sunk, and the hump to have shaken, or moved to and fro, and she walks, and straddles in doing so], hAj~ may be [an act. part. n.] formed from haj~ato, although this form of the verb be not used; and she makes AlEyn masc., meaning thereby AlEuDow or AlT~arof; for properly she should have said haAj~ap: or hAj~ is used [instead of haj~aj~ato] in im-cation of rAj~ [and tfAj~]. (L.)

3 hAj~ fiY hadiyrihi *
He (a camel) made his braying to reciprocate. (L.)
4 A^ahoja3a see Eaj~a last paragraph

8 Ahtj~ fiyhi *
He persevered (tamaAdY) in it, K. i. e., in his judgment, not listening to the counsel of any one. (TA.)

10 Asthj~ *
He followed his own judgment. (K,) whether erring or taking a right course, without consulting any one. (TA.)

R. Q. 1
hajohaja bAls~aboEi (S, K,) and Als~aboE, (L,) He cried one to the lion or other beast of prey, (S, K,) and chid him, in order that he ought refrain, forbear, or abstain (S) [See haji ― -b2- hajohaja biAlojamali He chid the camel, saying to him hiyj; (K;) [in the CK. hiyja, see art hyj:]) or hyjo; (accord. to the TA;) [but it occurs in a verse written hyj ] and in like manner bAln~aAqapi, the she-camel (L.) ― -b3- hajohaja fiY hadiyrihi, said of a stallion-camel, (S) He make a vehement noise in his braying. (L.)

hajK * and hajo, (S, K,) like as one says naxK and baxo, (S,) or hijiY. as related by Lh, (L,) and hajA (K,) or hajK hajK and hajo hjo and jajaA hajaA. (Az,) Cries by which one chides a dog. (S, K,) and a lion, and a wolf, &c., to quiet him: (Az:) and sometimes one says hajaA hajaA (ISd,) and, if he please, hajA, once, (Az) to chide camels (ISd, Az) and hajo, or haj at the end of a verse is a cry by which a she-camel is chidden. (L.) For hajo hajo, one also says jaho jaho, by transposition. (L.)
hajohajo * , (K,) and hajohaja, (S,) but the latter is only used by poetic licence, (K,) A cry by which sheep or goats (and a dog, Az,) are chidden, or checked, or urged, (S, K.)

hajohajapN *
A word imitative of the cry of a man when he cries out to a lion. (Lth) [See haj]

hajaAjN *
One in whom is no good. (L, art. Eaj~aAj.)

hajaAjayoka * , (As, S, K,) as also hadaA*ayoka, (As, S,) in the dual number. like dawaAlayoka and HawaAlayok, (TA,) supposing [it to be addressed to] two [persons], (As, S, K,) or hjAjyk humunaA wahuhunaA i. e., Refrain thou! or forbear thou! or abstain thou! (TA;) said to people when one desires their refraining, or forbearing, or abstaining, from a thing: (As, S, K:) and to a lion, and a wolf, &c., to quiet him. (Lh.)

hijorapN * , a subst. from hajarahu, (S, K,) as also ↓ hijoraAnN, (Msb,) signifying The cutting another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse: (S:) cutting one; or ceasing to speak to him: (K:) forsaking, abandoning, deserting, or shunning or avoiding, one. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA hijorapa baEoda valaAvK [There shall be no cutting off from friendly communion after three nights with their days,]: the meaning is, hajorN as contr. of waSolN; i. e., such anger as exists between Muslims, or a failing, or falling short, with respect to the duties of society, exclusively of what relates to religion: but the hijorap of those who follow their own natural desires [in matters of religion], and of innovators [in religion], should continue even as long as they do not repent, and return to the truth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, A mode, or manner, of cutting another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse: &c. See 1, where an ex. occurs.] ― -b3- Also, A removal from the desert to the towns or villages: this was its [primary] acceptation with the Arabs: and the forsaking of his country, or district, or the like, by an inhabitant of the desert, or by an inhabitant of a town, or village, or cultivated district, and taking up his abode in another country or district, or the like, an emigration; (TA;) the forsaking of one's home and removing to another place; (Mgh;) the forsaking of a country, or district, or the like, and removing to another; (Msb;) the going forth from one land to another; as also ↓ hujorapN. (K:) [and an emigration from the territory of the unbelievers to the territory of the believers, or to any place of safety or refuge on account of religious persecution &c.: see 3, last signification:] a subst. from haAjara. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- [AlhijorapN, peculiarly, The emigration, or flight, (for it was really a flight,) of Mohammad, from Mekkeh to Yethrib, which latter was afterwards called El-Medeeneh. Hence, taA^oriyxu Alhijorapi The era of the Hijreh, or Flight. The epoch of this era is not the date of the Flight itself, as some have imagined, (for this took place on an uncertain day, most probably the first or second, of the third lunar month of the Arabian year,) but is the first day of the Arabian year in which the Flight happened: and as I believe that all European writers who have attempted to fix it, prior to M. Caussin de Perceval, have erred respecting it, the true date, as shown by him, (see his “ Essai sur l'Histoire des Arabes, ” &c., in the places referred to in the index to that
work,) I think it important here to mention. The first year of the Flight was the two hundred and eleventh year of a period during which the Arabs made use of a defective luni-solar reckoning, making every third year to consist of thirteen lunar months; the others consisting of twelve such months. This mode of reckoning was abolished by Mohammad in the twelfth month of the tenth year of the Flight, at the time of the pilgrimage; whence it appears that the first year of the Flight commenced, most probably, on Monday, the nineteenth of April, A. D. 622; or perhaps on the eighteenth; for the actual appearance of the new moon properly marked its commencement, and, as the new moon happened about sunset on the sixteenth, it may perhaps have been seen on the eve of the eighteenth. According to M. Caussin de Perceval, the first ten years of the Flight commenced at the following periods.
1st. [Mon.] Apr. 19, 622
2nd. [Sat.] May 7, 623
3rd. [Th.] Apr. 26, 624
4th. [Mon.] Apr. 15, 625
5th. [Sat.] May. 3, 626
6th. [Th.] Apr. 23, 627
7th. [Tu.] Apr. 12, 628
8th. [Mon.] May. 1, 629
9th. [Fri.] Apr. 20, 630
10th. [Tu.] Apr. 9, 631
Thus it appears that the first and fourth and seventh years were of thirteen lunar months each; and the seventh was the last year that was thus augmented: therefore, with the eighth year commenced the reckoning by common lunar years; and from this point we may use the tables which have often been published for finding the periods of commencement of years of the Flight. We must not, however, rely upon the exact accuracy of these tables: for the commencement of the month was generally determined by actual observation of the new moon; not by calculation; and we often find that a year was commenced, according as the place of observation was low or high, or to the east or west of the place to which the calculation is adapted, or according as the sky was obscure or clear, a day later or earlier than that which is indicated in the tables; and in some cases, even two days later. The twelfth day of the third month of the first year of the Flight, the day of Mohammad's arrival at Kubà, was Monday: therefore the first day of the year was most probably the nineteenth of April, as two months of thirty days each, or twenty-nine days each, seldom occur together. But the tenth day of the first month of the sixty-first year, the day on which El-Hoseyn was slain at Kerbelà, was Friday: therefore the first day of that year, at that place, must have been Wednesday, the third of October, A. D. 680; not the first of October, as in most of the published tables above mentioned. (For the principal divisions of the Arabian year when the luni-solar reckoning was instituted, see zamanN)]. AlhijorataAni means [The two emigrations, or flights; namely,] the hijorap to Abyssinia and the hijorap to El-Medeeneh. (S, K.) And *uw Alhijoratayoni He (of the SaHaAbap [or Companions of Mohammad] TA) who emigrated, or who has emigrated, to Abyssinia and to El-Medeeneh. (K.)

A place to which one emigrates. (Msb.)

muhaAjirN * Any one, whether an inhabitant of the desert [as in the primary acceptation of the epithet] or an inhabitant of a town or village or cultivated district, who emigrates; or who forsakes his country or district or the like, and takes up his abode in another country or district or the like. Hence AlmuhaAjiruwna applied to The emigrants to El-Medeeneh: because they forsook their places of abode in which they were reared, for the sake of God, and attached themselves to an abode in which they had neither family nor property, when they emigrated to El-Medeeneh. (TA.)

1 hajasa Al$~aYo'u fiY qalobihi * , (A,) or fiY Sadorihi, (K,) or biAlqalobi, (Msb,) aor.
hajisa , (S, K, MS, TA,) or
hajusa , (Msb,) inf. n. hajosN, (Msb, TA,) The thing fell into, or occurred to, or bestirred itself in, his mind, or the mind; or occurred to his mind, or the mind, after having been for-
gotten; syn. waqaEa and xaTara; (Msb;) or, of the phrase in the A and that in the K, xaTara bibaAlihi, (A, K,) and waqaEa fiY xaladihi: (TA:) or hajosN signifies [the thing's] talking, or suggesting something, to the person's mind, in his bosom; expl. by the words A^ano yuHad~iva nafosahu fiY Sadorihi; like wisowaAsN: (K, * TA:) and hence the phrase in a trad., wamaA yahojisu fiY AlD~amaAy^iri, meaning, and what falls into, or occurs in, and bestirs itself in, the minds, (yaxoTuru bihaA,) and revolves therein, of matters of discourse, and of thoughts: (TA:) or hajasa fiY SadoriY $aYo'N signifies i. q. Hadasa [app. meaning a thing came at random into my mind]: (S, L:) and you say also, hajasa fY nafosiY [it fell into, or occurred to, my mind: &c.] (TA.)

5 tahaj~asa *
I. q. A^aqaAma. (T, art. ErS.)

hajosN *
A low voice, or sound, (naboA^apN,) which one hears but does not understand. (S.) ― -b2- See also haAjisN.

haAjisN *
A thing, or an idea, or object of thought, or an opinion, coming at random into, falling into, occurring to, or bestirring itself in, the mind; (S, A, * Msb;) syn. xaATirN: (S, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst predominates: (TA:) and ↓ hajosN also signifies anything falling into, or occurring to, the mind; (Lth, K:) pl. of the former, hawaAjisu. (A, TA.)

div2.head: hjE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 had~a * , aor.
hadu3a , (S, L, Msb,) inf. n. had~N (S, L, Msb, K) and huduwdN, (L, K,) He demolished a a building; (As, S, A, L, K: *) threw it down; (TA;) pulled it down to the ground: (As, S, A, L:) demolished it with violence: (L, K: *) demolished it at once, with a vehement noise. (Msb.) -A2- [Hence you say,] maA ha*uhu ka*aA (assumed tropical:) Such a thing did not break him, or it. (S, L.) ― -b2- had~aniY AlA^amoru, and had~a rukonY, (assumed tropical:) The thing distressed, and broke, or crashed, me. And [in like manner] maA had~aniY mawotu A^aHadK (assumed tropical:) [The death of any one has not distressed, nor broken, or crushed, me]. (L.) And had~atohu AlmuSiybapu The (tropical:) calamity debilitated, or enervated, him. (S, A, L.) ― -b3- had~a, aor.
hada3a , and
hadi3a , inf. n. had~N, He (a man) was, or became, weak, (L, K,) in body; (L:) became extremely aged, or decrepit. (TK.) ― -b4- See 7. ― -b5- had~a, aor.
hadi3a , inf. n. hadiydN, It (a wall or the like, S, L, or a part of a mountain, L, by its falling, S, L) made a noise; (S;) or, a violent noise. (L.) ― -b6- had~ato It (the sky) sent forth a noise, or sound, occasioned by the falling of rain. (L.) ― -b7- had~a, aor.
hada3a , (L,) inf. n. hadiydN, (S, L,) It (the sound called haAd~, from the sea,) made a murmuring. (S, * L.) ― -b8- had~a, aor.
hadi3a , inf. n. had~N, He (a camel) brayed. (TK.) See also R. Q. 1. -A3- mararotu birajulK had~aka mino rajulK I passed by a man who is sufficient for they as a man; (L, K:) as also had~ika: (K.) an expression of praise (L:) or it means, the description of whose good qualities would be burdensome to thee: there are two dial. forms used in this case: some use hd~ as an inf. n., [in the sense of an epithet, (marginal note in a copy of the S,) saying, in such a phrase as the above, had~ika,] in which case, it has no fem. nor dual. nor pl. form; (S, L:) the sing and dual and pl. are the same: (K:) and some make it a verb, and give it [a fem. and] a dual and a pl, and say, mrrt brjl had~aka mn rjl, as above, (S, L,) and bA@moraA^apK had~anoka mni A@moraA^apK, (S, L, K,) like as you say kaf~Aka and kafayoka, (L.,) and birajulayoni had~aAka, and birijaAlK had~uwka, and biA@moraA^atayoni had~ataAka, and binisowapi hadadotaka. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- IAar also cites the following ex. [by El-Kattál El-Kilábee, (marginal note in a copy of the S)]
waliY SaAHibN fiY AlgaAri had~aka SaAHibFA
as meaning. [And I have a companion in the race;] of how great estimation, and how ingenious, and how knowing, is he [as a companion] describing a wolf: (L:) in which he who reads had~aka makes had~a a verb; and as such it has a dual and pl. and fem. but some read had~uka. making it an inf. n. used as an epithet; and as such it has no dual nor pl. nor fem. (Marginal note in a copy of the S.) ― -b3- had~a Alr~ajulu also signifies Excellent is the man; (ISd, L:) and A_in~hu lahad~a Alr~ajulu Verily, excellent is the man (L, K) in hardiness and strength: (L:) and lahad~a Alr~ajulu How hardy is the man! (L.) ― -b4- In a trad., Aboo Lahab is related to have said, lahad~a maA saxarakumo SaAHibukumo, [meaning How greatly hath your companion enchanted you!): lahad~a is an expression of wonder. (L.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yuhad~u Such a one is praiseworthy for hardiness (S, L, K) and strength. (S, L.)

2 hd~dhu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. tahodiydN (S, L) and tahodaAdN; (L:) and ↓ thd~dhu: (S, L, Msb;) He threatened him; (L;) threatened him with punishment; (Msb;) frightened, or terrified, him. (S, L, K.)
5 tahad~a3a see 2.

7 Anhd~ *
It (a building) [fell down: or] became demolished at once, with a vehement noise: (Msb:) and ↓ had~a, aor.
hadi3a , it (a wall) fell down; mentioned by AHei; and also by Es-Semeen, who concedes it; (MF;) but this form of the verb is commonly known only as transitive. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a mountain) broke down. (S, L.)

10 Asthd~hu *
He regarded him as weak. (L.)

R. Q. 1 hadohada * , (S, L, K,) inf. n. hdohadapN, (S, L,) He (a bird) cooed; syn. qaroqara: (L, K, TA [in the CK, farofara]:) he (a pigeon) cooed syn. hadara, and hadala: (TA:) or made a murmuring or confused noise in cooing: (S, L, accord to the explanation of hadohadapN:) and he (a camel, S, L) brayed: syn. hadara: (K:) or made a murmuring or confused noise in braying (S, L,) See also 1. ― -b2- hadohadato, (inf. n. hadohadpN, L.) She (a woman, S, L) shook, or rocked, a child (S, L, K) in its cradle, (L,) in order that it might sleep. (S, L, K.) -A2- hadohada He sent, or threw, a thing down, from a high place to a low one, (L, K.)

had~N * A weak man; (As, S, L, K;) i. e., weak in body; (L;) as also ↓ hid~N: (K:) or, accord. to IAar, the latter only, meaning cowardly and weak: (S, L:) or had~N (Sh, L) and ↓ A^ahd~u (L, K) and ↓ hadaAdapN (Sh, L, K) signify a cowardly (and weak, TA) man: (Sh, L, K:) and ↓ qawomN hadaAdN a cowardly people: (Sh, L:) pl. of had~N, had~uwna: (L, K:) it has no broken pl. (L:) and of hid~N, hid~`wna. (K.) A man says to another, in threatening him, A_in~iY laEayoru had~K Verily I am not weak. (S, L.) ― -b2- had~N Extreme odd age; decrepitude. (K, TA.) See 1. -A2- had~N A cough, or harsh, sound; as also ↓ hadadN. (L, K.) ― -b2- had~N The braying of a camel. (Lh, L, K.) See 1. -A3- had~N A generous, liberal. beautiful man. (IAar. S, L, K. *) ― -b2- A strong man. (IAar. L.) ― -b3- liY SaAHibN had~uka SaAHibFA, and mararotu birajulK had~ika mino rajulK: see 1.
hid~N * and hadarN: see had~N.

had~apN * The sound of the fall of a wall or the like: (S:) or a violent sound occasional thereby, or by the fall of a part of a mountain. (L.) ― -b2- The sound of rain falling from the sky. (L.) ― -b3- A sinking, and falling in, of the ground. (L.)
hadohadN * The voices, or cries, of jinn, or genii: without a singular. (L, K)

hudohudN *
A certain bird, (S, L, Msb, K,) well known; (L, Msb, K;) [namely, the hoopee, or upupa of Linnæus; so this bird is called in the present day; and this, accord. to a common tradition, is the bird mentioned in the Kur, xxvii. 20;] as also hudahidN (K) and ↓ hudaAhidN: (S, L, K:) or the last, a certain bird resembling the pigeon: (Lth, Az, L:) or (in the K, and) hudohudN signifies a pigeon that cooes much; (IDrd in explanation
of v. 20 of ch. xxvii. of the Kur., and AHn, L K;) as also ↓ hudaAhidN: (IDrd, AHn, L:) and any bird that cooes; that utters the cry called qaroqarap; (L, K, TA [in the CK, yufarofiru is put for yuqaroqiru]) as also ↓ hudaAhidN: (As, L:) pl. (of all, K) hadaAhidu (S, L, K) and hadaAhiydu: (Kr, L, K:) but ISd says of the latter, I know not how this is, unless the sing. be hadohaAdN. (L.) Er-Rá'ee says,
kahudaAhidK kasara Alr~umaApu janaAHahu
[Like a hdAhd whose wing the shooters have broken]: (S, L:) As says, he means the faAxitap, or the dubosiY~, or the wara$aAn, or the hudohud, or a man, or camels: and Lh says, that Ks asserts him to mean, by hdAhd, the dim. of hudohudN: but As disapproves of this; and so does ISd; but the latter adds, that it may perhaps be for hudayohidN; as some of the Arabs say duwaAb~apN and $uwaAb~apN for duwyob~apN and $uwayob~apN; though they are only known to change the Y into A before a double consonant. (L.)
hadohadapN * [an inf. n. used as a simple subst.] The murmuring or confused sound of the cooing of pigeons, and of the braying of a camel [and of thunder (see zamozamapN)]: pl. hadaAhidu. (S, L.)
hadaAdN * and hadaAdapN: see had~N.
hudaAhidN * A stallion-camel that brays much among the she-camels but does not cover them. (L.) ― -b2- See hudohudN.

hadiydN *
A voice, cry, sound, or noise. (L.) See also 1. ― -b2- A threatening from behind one. (As, L.)

haAd~N *
A certain murmuring sound from the sea; (K;) a sound which is heard by people inhabiting the sea-shore, coming to them from the direction of the sea, murmuring over the land, and sometimes followed by an earthquake. (S, L.)

haAd~apN *
Thunder. (L, K.) Ex. maA samiEonaA AlEaAma haAd~apF We have not heard this year thunder. (L.)
A^ahad~u * : see had~N.

1 hadaA^a * , aor.
hadaAa , inf. n. hado'N and huduwo'N, He, or it, was quiet, or still, calm, or unruffled; (S, K;) was motionless; was silent: (TA:) [and so, app., ↓ AhdA^: see muhodiy^N.] ― -b2- tahodaY and haAdK occur for tahodaA^u and haAdiy^K. (TA.) ― -b3- hadaA^a Eanohu It [pain or the like] became appeased, and quitted him. (TA.) ― -b4- See 4. ― -b5- A^ataAnaA waqado hadaA^ati Alr~ijolu (tropical:) He came to us when the foot (of the passenger by night) had become still. (S.) ― -b6- AtAnA baEoda maA hadaA^ati Alr~ijolu wAlEayonu (tropical:) He came to us after the foot (of the passenger by night), and the eye, were at rest. (S, TA.) ― -b7- hadaA^a biAlmakaAni (tropical:) He stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (K.) ― -b8- hadaA^a, (inf. n. huduwo'N, TA,) (tropical:) He died. (K.) -A2- hadiy^a, aor.
hadaAa , (K,) inf. n. hadaA^N, (TA,) i. q. janiy^a, He had a curving back, &c.: (K:) or he had depressed and even shoulders, inclining towards the breast; not erect, or elevated: (Lth, and others:) or he was humpbacked. (S, TA.) ― -b2- hadiy^a It (a camel's hump) was bent by much lading, (K,) and had its soft hair (wabar) sticking upon it, without its being wounded. (TA.)

4 AhdA^ *
He rendered quiet, still, motionless, silent. (K, TA.) ― -b2- laA A^ahodaA^ahu All~`hu May God not give him rest from his labour, or fatigue! (K.) ― -b3- AlS~abiY~a ↓ hadaA^a, and AhdA^hu, [the latter only I find mentioned in one copy of the S: but both are mentioned in another, as well as in the TA:] He patted the child with his hand, and quieted him, that he might sleep: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Az, AhdA^to Sabiy~ahaA signifies She spoke soothingly to her child, and quieted him, that he might sleep: and muhodaA^N is a child thus soothed. (TA.) ― -b4- Accord. to IAar, mhdA^ in the following verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, [quoted in the S,]
$ay^izN janobiY kaA^an~iY muhodaA^N
jaEala Alqayonu EalaYAld~af~i A_ibaro
signifies a child soothed in order that he may go to sleep. Others read it as an inf. n. (TA.) -A2- AhdA^ (tropical:) He wore out a garment. (A.) ― -b2- AhdA^hu All~`hu God made it (a shoulder) to be in the state described in the explanation of the word A^ahodaA^u. (K.) ― -b3- AhdA^hu It (old age, K, or beating, TA) rendered him what is termed A^ahodaA^u. (K.)

hado'N * : see 1. ― -b2- A^ataAnaA baEoda hado'K mina All~ayoli, (S, K,) and ↓ hudo'K, (K,) and ↓ hadoA^apK, (S, K,) and ↓ mahodaA_K, and ↓ hadiYo'K, and ↓ huduwo'K, (K; the last is also an inf. n. and pl.; TA,) (tropical:) He came to us after a period, or portion, of the night; (S, TA;) or after about a third or fourth part of the night had elapsed, (S, TA,) when men were asleep, (S,) or at rest, and the night, and the foot of the passenger, were still: (Sb, K:) or hado'N is the first third part of the night; from the commencement to the third, (K,) when it begins to be still. (TA.) -A2- hado'N and hadoYN (in which the Y is said to be substituted for ', TA.) Way, or manner, of life. (AHeyth, K.) -A3- mararotu birajulK hadoy^ika min r~ajulK i. q. had~ika: (see art. hd:) the latter is that which is commonly known and approved. (Ez-Zejjájee.)
hudo'N * : see hado'N.

hadaA^N *
Smallness of a camel's hump, occasioned by his being much laden. (K.) It is less than what is termed Hnb [a word app. incorrectly written, but which I am unable to correct]. (TA.)

hadoA^apN *
Quiet; stillness; rest from motion; silence. (Lh.) -A2- See hado'N, and A^ahodaA^u.

maA lahu hidoA^apu layolapK * , (K,) mentioned by Lh, but not explained by him: thought by ISd to mean He has not a night's food: (and so accord. to the K:) i. e., what may quiet his hunger or sleeplessness or anxiety. (TA.)

hadaA^apN *
A kind of run. (K.)
A^ataAnaA huduwo'FA * (tropical:) He came to us after a sleep: (S:) after men were at rest, and sleeping. (TA.) -A2- See hado'N.
hadiYo'N * : see hado'N.
hud~aA='apN * A slender horse: (K:) generally said to be a term peculiarly applied to the male only: but said by some to be common to the male and the female. (MF.)

huwa A^ahodaA^u mim~aA kaAna * (tropical:) He is more quiet, or more at rest, than he was: i. e., he is dead. From a trad. Said by Umm-Suleym to Aboo-Talhah, respecting her son, to comfort the heart of his father. (TA.) -A2- A^ahodaA^u i. q. A^ajonaA^u, Having a curving back, &c.: (K:) humpbacked: (S:) or a person having the shoulders depressed, and even, and inclining towards the breast; not erect or elevated: fem. hadoA='u: you also say manokibN A^ahodaA^u a shoulder such as is described immediately above: and A^ahodaA^u a crooked man: (Lth, and others:) also a shoulder of which the upper part is swollen, or filled with fat and flesh, and its strength relaxed. (K: in some copies of which we read AstrxY Hylh: in others, Hmlh: [the former is the reading that I adopt].) ― -b2- hadoA='u (so in the CK and a MS. copy: in the TA, ↓ hadoA^apN, [which seems to be an error];) A she-camel having her hump bent by much lading, (K,) and the soft hair (wabar) sticking upon it, without its being wounded. (TA.)
mahodaA'N * : see hado'N.
muhodaA^N * : see 4.

muhodiy^N *
Still; motionless. (TA, in art. xmd.)

mahodaA^apN *
State, or condition. (S.)

tarakotuhu EalaY muhayodiy^atihi *
I left him in the state, or condition, wherein he was: (As, S, K:) dim. of mahodaA^apN. (S.)

1 hadabahu * , aor.
hadiba , He cut it; or cut it off. (K, TA.) See also hadaba. ― -b2- hadaba, (aor.
hadiba , inf. n. hadobN, S,) He milked a camel: (ISk, S, K:) or he milked any animal with the ends of his fingers.
(IKtt.) ― -b3- hadaba (S, K,) aor.
haduba ; or ↓ hd~b, inf. n. tahodiybN; and ↓ Ahtdb; (TA;) He plucked, or gathered, fruit, (S, K,) or [the kind of leaves called] hadabN. (TA.) -A2- hadiba, (inf. n. hadabN, TA;) and ↓ Ahdb; It (a tree) had long and pendulous branches, or twigs. (K.) The latter verb is explained by IKtt as signifying It (a tree) had numerous branches. (TA.) This is not derived from the hadab of the A^aroTaY and the like (AHn.) ― -b2- hadibati AlEayonu, aor.
hadaba , (inf. n. hadabN TA,) The eye had long lashes. (K.)
2 had~aba see 1. -A2- hd~b Als~awoTa [?] i. q. Ea*~aba, q. v (A, in TA, voce E*~b. q. v.)
4 A^ahodaba see 1. ― -b2- Ahdb It (a tree) produced, or put forth, its hadab. (TA.)
5 thd~b * [It (a part of a cloud) hung down like the unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment]. (S.) See hayodabN.
8 A_ihotadaba see 1.

hudobN * and ↓ hudubN, (K,) the latter a dial. form of the former, (TA,) coll. gen. ns., and ↓ hayodabN, (K,) also a coll. gen. n., (TA,) and ↓ hud~aAbN [likewise a coll. gen. n.,] and ↓ hudobapN, [which is rather the n. un. of hudobN,] (TA,) of a garment, or piece of cloth, i. q. xamolN: (K: in like manner, ↓ hudobapN and ↓ hudubapN are explained in the S by xamolapN:) or rather, The [fringe, or] unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment, or of a piece of cloth; its end, or extremity, that has not been woven: or an end, or extremity, consisting of warp without woof: sometimes it is twisted, and [as it forms a fringe,] it preserves the edge [of the woven part] of the garment, &c.: (whereas xml signifies the “ nap, or villous substance, ” of a garment, &c.: [such is the meaning of the words mA ytxl~l Alt~wb kl~h kAlz~iy^obiri: this is what is generally meant by xml] and this is mostly in what are called qaTaAy^ifu: (MF:) or the extremity of a garment, &c. next [the part called] the Tur~ap: (TA:) or the hdbp of a garment, &c., is the same as the Tur~ap: (Msb:) n. un. of the fist word, (hudobN or hudubN,) with p (K:) so too of hydb, (TA,) [and of hd~Ab]. The pl. of hudobapN is hudabN. (Msb.) ― -b2- hudobN, (K,) or hudobu AlEayoni, (S,) and ↓ hudubN, (K,) which is a dial form of hdb, (TA,) coll. gen. ns., The eyelashes; the hairs that grow upon the edges of the eyelids: (S, K:) n. un. with p: (K:) pl. A^ahodaAbN. (Msb.)

hadabN * [generally signifies slender spring, like strings, garnished with minute, amplexicant, appressed, acute leaves, overlying one another like the scales of a fish: see EabalN:] the branches, or twigs, of the A^aroTaY and similar trees (K) that have no leaves; a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p: and the pl., A^ahodaAbN. (TA.) [The foliage of the cypress and tamarisk, and the like:] leaves of a tree that are permanent, (and that have not a projecting nerve along the middle. TA,) as those of the cypress (K) and tamarisk and samur. (TA.) Those parts of a plant that are not waraq but that have the place of waraq. (AHn, K:) or any waraq that have not middle; (S, K;) as those of the A^avol and sarow and A^aroTaY and TarofaA='; (S:) as also ↓ hud~aAbN, (S, K,) both of which are sell gen. ns., of which the as, an. are with p: pl. A^ahodaAbN, (K,) which is a regular pl. of hadabN (TA;) and ↓ hud~aAbN: (K, accord. to the TA: but in a MS. copy, hud~aAbapN; and in the CK, had~aAbapN,) but in the M, hud~aAbN is said to be a noun signifying the hudob of a garment, &c., and the hadab of the A^aroTaY (TA) Az says, that EabalN is precisely the same as hadabN (TA.) ― -b2- ↓ hud~aAbN is also said to signify Inclining branches, or twigs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, Aln~axoli ↓ hud~aAbu Palm branches; syn. saEafuhu. (S) -A2- A^ahodaAbN is said to be used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, in the phrase sabiTu AlAhdAb, as signifying The shoulder-blades. but ISd, who mentions this, denies its correctness. (TA.)

hadibN * A horse having a long forelock. The hdbAn [pl. of hadibN, but whether hidobaAnN or hudobaAnN is not shown,] are among those horses that are held in high estimation among the Arabs, and are distinguished as belonging to different tents, or house. (TA.) ― -b2- Alhudbu (assumed tropical:) The lion. (K.) But accord. to Lth, ↓ A^ahodabu, as an epithet applied to felt and the like, signifies (assumed tropical:) Having long nap, or villous substance (TA,) and as an epithet applied to a lion, accord. to the A, it signifies (tropical:) Having long shag [or shaggy hair]: (TA:) whence it is seen that the correct word [applied to the lion [A^ahodabu, q. v.] and hadibN. (TA.)
hudubN * and hudubapN: see hudobN.

hudobapN * (TA) and ↓ hudabapN (Kr, K) A certain bird: (K:) or a small dust-coloured bird, resembling the haAmap. accept in being smaller than this latter. (L.) El-Jáhidh says, The Arabs have not a name for that [kind of bird] which sees not in the night: it is that which is called $bkwr [a Persian word, written $abokuwro], more frequently than hdbp. (A.) -A2- N, un. of hudobN, q. v.
hdbp * [written without the syll. points: probably hudobapN;] A piece, pace, or portion. (TA.)
hudabapN * : see hudobapN.
hudub~N * : see hayodabN.
hud~aAbN * : see hudobN and hadabN and hayodabN.

hinodabN * (S, K, a word of a rare measure, TA,) and ↓ hinodabaA'N (K: [but it is not there said whether it be imperfectly or perfectly declinable: accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, as mentioned in the TA, it is fem., and therefore imperfectly decl.: but from the ns. an. given below, it appears to be masc., and perfectly decl.: probably, therefore, all the forms of the word ending with long or short alif may be correctly pronounced without, and with, tenween:]) and ↓ hinodab~aY (ISk, S, Msb) and hinodibaA'N and hinodibFY; (Az, S, K, Msb;) but the word which is used by most of the Arabs of the desert is the first: (Az;) IKt only mentions the third form: (Msb:) also ↓ hanodabaApN, (S;) or [hndbY and hndbA' are coll. gen. ns., and] hinadabaApN is a n. un., (AHn, K,) as also hndbA'p: (AHn, TA:) A certain leguminous plant, (S, K,) well known, (K,) of the description termed A^aHoraAr; [i. e., of a slender and soft nature, and eaten crude;) (TA;) [lichorium, intybus and endivia; wild and garden-succory, and endive: also called in the present day $kuwryap] a plant of middling temperament, (muEotadilapN,) useful for the stomach and the liver and the spleen, when eaten: and for the sting of a scorpion, when applied externally, with its roots: he who cooks it errs more than he who washes it [and so uses it]. (K.) F mentions the names of this plant in aro. hndb, as though the n were a radical letter, which noone asserts it to be: J [and others], in art. hdb. (TA.)
hinodaibFY * , hinodaibaA'N, and hinodabaApN, see hin~adabN.

hayodabN * : see hudobN. ― -b2- [Its pl., hayaAdibu, is also applied to Filaments, capillaments, or fringe-like appertenances, of a flower. ― -b3- hayodabN; (tropical:) A cloud or clouds, hanging down, (K,) approaching [the earth], like the hudob [or unwoven end or extremity,] of a (qaTiyfap: (TA:) or the hydb of a cloud is its *ayol [or skirt]. (K:) or what hangs down, of it, like the unwoven and, or extremity, of a garment. (maA taha*~aba minohu.) when it is about to rain, resembling strings (S) ― -b4- hayodabN (tropical:) A pendulous (or flabby. TA,) pubes of a woman: (K:) likened to the hydb of a cloud (TA.) ― -b5- hayodabN (tropical:) Tears flowing in a continued succession. (K.) On the authority of Lth, who cites the following verse:
bidamoEK *iY HaraAraAtK
EalaY Alxad~ayoni *iY hayodabo
[With hot tears upon the cheeks, flowing in a continued succession]. But it is said in the L, I have not heard hydb used as an epithet applied to rain falling continuously, aor. as an epithet applied to tears; and the verse which Lth adduces as an authority is forged. (TA.) ― -b6-
hayodabN (S, K) and ↓ hudub~N and ↓ hud~aAbN (K) Impotent in speech or actions; syn. EayiY~N; (in one copy of the K gabiY~N, or unintelligent; TA;) and heavy, or dull: (S, K:) or hydb signifies impotent in speech or actions; dull of speech and understanding; heavy: and hard, or churlish; heavy, or dull; having much hair: (Az:) or, as some say, one who has upon him dangling strings, or the like, hanging from the suspensory of a sword, or other thing, and resembling the hydb of a cloud: or, as some say, this word signifies stupid; foolish; of little sense: and ↓ hdb~, weak. (TA.)

hayodabaY *
A kind of pace of a horse, in which exertion, or energy, is employed; a certain hard pace of a horse. (K.) See also hayo*abaY.
rajulN hayodabiY~u AlkalaAmi * (assumed tropical:) A man of much speech, or talk; of many words. (K.) App. from the hayodab of a cloud. (TA.)

A^ahodabu * A man having long, or large, eyelashes. (K.) Lth explains it by the words Tawiylu A^a$ofaAri AlEayoni kaviyruhaA; [and J in a similar manner;] but Az disapproves of this expression, because A$fAr AlEyn signifies “ the edges of the eyelids, ” whence the eyelashes grow: (TA:) A^ahodabu AlA^a$ofaAri, and AlA$fAr ↓ hadibu, [the same;] having long eyelashes. (TA.) EayonN hadobaA'u An eye having long lashes. (TA.) ― -b2- $ajarapN hadobaA'u A tree having long and pendulous branches. (K.) ― -b3- A^u*unN hadobaA'u (tropical:) A pendulous, flabby, ear. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- liHoyapN hadobaA'u (tropical:) A lank, not crisp, beard: and so ↓ EuvonuwnN hadibN. (TA.) ― -b5- nasorN A^ahodabu (tropical:) A vulture having long feathers which reach to the ground. (TA.) See hadibN.

muhad~abN *
Having an unwoven end, or extremity; syn. *uw hud~aAbK: occurring as an epithet applied to the kind of stuff called dimaqosN. (TA.)

hudabidN * and ↓ hudaAbidN Very thick milk: (S, L, K:) sour and thick milk. (L.) The former word is a contraction of the latter. (S.) ― -b2- Also the former, Smallness of the eyes, and weakness of the sight; or nyctalopia, or the seeing better by night than in the day, and in a cloudy day than in a clear one; syn. xafa$N: (L, K:) or (so in the L, in the K, and) weakness of the eye, (K,) or, of the sight: (L:) or (so in the L; in the K, and) [that weakness of the sight which is termed] Ea$FA, [which is a badness of sight by night and day; or the quality of seeing by day but not by night,] (El-Mufaddal, L, K,) also termed $abokarapN: (El-Mufaddal, L:) or weakness of the sight, with a flowing of the tears at most times; syn. Eama$N: (S, L:) or this is a mistake: (K:) or any injurious affection of the eye. (M, F.) ― -b3- Also, Weak-sighted: (L, K:) an epithet applied to a man. (L.) ― -b4- Also, Black gum (L, K) which flows from trees. (L.)
hudaAbidN * : see hudabidN.

1 hadaja * , aor.
hadija , inf. n. hadajaAnN (S, K) and hudaAjN (K) and hadojN, (TA,) (tropical:) He walked gently, in a weak manner: (TA:) or he walked in the manner of an old man; (S, K;) and the like: (TA:) or he (an old man) walked with short steps: or walked hastily, without desiring to do so: (TA:) or he walked with unintermitting steps: (As:) or he walked in a shaking manner, by reason of old age. (IAar.) ― -b2- hadaja, (S,) aor.
hadija , inf. n. hadajaAnN; and ↓ Asthdj; (TA;) He (an ostrich) walked, or went, (or ran, TA,) in a tremulous manner. (S, TA.) ― -b3- hadajati Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled vehemently. (TA.) ― -b4- hadajato, (S,) inf. n. hadajN, (L,) She (a camel) yearned towards her young one; Han~ato EalaY waladihaA; (S, L;) as also ↓ thd~jt; (L;) [and, app., uttered the cry produced by yearning towards her young one: see below:] or the latter signifies she was affectionate to her young one. (S, K.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) It (the wind) made a sound; syn. Han~ato and Saw~atato; from hdjt Aln~Aqp. (L.)
2 hd~jt * (tropical:) She (a camel) became high and big in the hump, so that it bore a resemblance to a hawodaj. (TA.)

5 thd~j *
It (the voice, or a sound) became much intercepted, or interrupted, (taqaT~aEa) with a tremulous manner. (S, K.) See 1. -A2- thd~jwA Ealayohi They made apparent, or manifest, his gracious actions, or qualities, or his favours, or kindnesses. (TA.)
10 A_isotahodaja see 1.
hadajodajN * : see had~aAjN.
haduwjN * : see mihodaAjN. ― -b2- qidorN haduwjN (tropical:) A cookingpot that boils vehemently: (TA:) or, quickly. (K.)

had~aAjN * and ↓ hadajodajN One who walks in the manner termed hadajaAnN: see 1. (K.) ― -b2- An ostrich that so walks, or runs. (S, TA.) One says ZaliymN had~aAjN, and naEaAmN had~aAjN and hawaAdiju: (TA:) [the last is pl. of ↓ haAdijapN, fem. act. part. n. of hadaja]. ― -b3- Also, the ↓ latter, An ostrich: so called because it so walks, or runs: (TA:) [and so ↓ haAdijapN, pl. hawaAdiju, as in the following example.] naZarotu A_ilaY AlhawaAdiji EalaY AlhawaAdiji [I looked at the women's camel-litters upon the camels like ostriches]. (A.)
haAdijapN * : see had~aAjN.

hawodajN * [A kind of camel-vehicle for women;] the vehicle of the Arab women of the desert: (JK:) a kind of vehicle for women, (S, K,) having a dome-like top (muqab~abN); and one not having such a top: (S:) or [a camel-vehicle for women] made with staves, over which are put pieces of wood, and covered with a dome-like top: (M:) or a camel-vehicle (maHomil) having a dome-like top (qub~ap), covered with pieces of cloth, in which women ride: (Et-Towsheeh:) pl. hawaAdiju. (TA.) [See maHomilN and maHaArapN.]

mihodaAjN * A she-camel that yearns, or that utters the cry produced by yearning towards her young one: (K:) or that yearns towards her young one: (S, L:) as also ↓ haduwjN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) A wind that has a sound; lahaA HaniynN: (S, L:) from Han~ati Aln~aAqapu. (L.)

musotahodajN *
Haste. (K.)

musotahodijN *
Hasty. (K.)

1 hadara * , aor.
hadira (S, A, Msb, K) and
hadura , (Msb, K,) inf. n. hadorN (S, Msb, K) and hadarN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) It (a man's blood, S, A, Msb, K, or another thing, K) went for nothing; [meaning, in the case of blood, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulet; as shown below, voce hadarN;] it was, or became, of no account, null, or void; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Ahdr. (Msb.) -A2- hadarahu, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
hadura , (Msb,) He (a man, Msb, K, or the Sultán, S, A,) made it (a man's blood) to go for nothing; [meaning, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct;] he made it to be of no account; (A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Ahdrhu; (S, A, Msb, K;) which means he made it (a man's blood) allowable to be taken, or shed. (S, TA.) Thus these two verbs are trans. as well as intrans. (Msb.) It is said in a trad, mani A@T~alaEa fiY daArK bigayori A_i*onK faqado hudirato Eayonuhu [Whoso looketh into a house without permission, his eye shall be allowed to be put out; or] the putting out of his eye shall go for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct. (TA.) One says also, hadarotaniY biA_isoqaATi AlHad~i Ean~iY [Thou hast made me (meaning my offence) to pass unnoticed, or host taken no account of
me, by annulling in respect of me the prescribed castigation]. (K, art. bhrj.) And El-'Ajjáj says,
wahadara Aljad~a mina Aln~aAsi Alha*aro
which El-Báhilee explains as meaning, And the worthless people have made good fortune to become of no account. (TA.) -A3- ha*ara, (S, K,) aor.
hadira (K) [and app.
hadura also], inf. n. hadiyrN (S, K) and hadorN (K) and huduwrN, (TA,) said of a camel, (S, K,) that is advanced in age, (S, in art. nqD,) [He brayed; i. e.,] he reiterated his voice in his Hanojarap [or windpipe, or the head of his windpipe]: (S:) or he uttered his voice, not in a $iqo$iqap [q. v.]: (K:) and ↓ hd~r, (S, K,) inf. n. tahodiyrN, (S,) signifies the same: (S, K:) Z mentions also tahodaArN as an inf. n. of hadara said of a stallion, [meaning a stallioncamel.] (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (TA,) huwa yahodiru fiY manoTiqihi, and fiY xuTobatihi, (tropical:) [He is sonorous and fluent in his speech, and in his oration:] and hadarato $iqo$iqatuhu (tropical:) [His utterance was sonorous and fluent.] (A, TA.) ― -b3- hadara is also said of a calf, [signifying, (assumed tropical:) He lowed] (TA, art. kt, from the Nh.) ― -b4- Also, of a lion, [signifying, (assumed tropical:) He roared.] (S, TA, voce qaboqaba.) ― -b5- Also hadara, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
hadira (Msb, K) and
