hadura , (Msb,) inf. n. hadiyrN (S, IKtt, Msb, TA) and hadorN and tahodaArN, (K,) said of a pigeon (tropical:) It uttered a cry: (S, K:) or cooed, syn. qaroqara, (A,) or sajaEa, (Msb,) and reiterated its voice, or cry, in its Hanojarap [or windpipe, or the head of its windpipe]: (A:) its cry being apparently likened to the hadiyr of the camel: and hadala signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b6- Also hadara said of a boy, (As.) when he desires to speak, being young, or little, (Abu-s-Semeyda',) (assumed tropical:) He uttered a sound, or cry; as also hadala. (As, TA.) ― -b7- It is also said of thunder; inf. n. hadiyrN; signifying (tropical:) It made a [loud, or rumbling,] sound, or noise, (A.) ― -b8- You say also, of $araAb [or wine], ha*ara, (S, K,) aor.
hadira , inf. n. hadorN and tahodaArN, (S, TA,) meaning, (assumed tropical:) It fermented; syn. galaY. (S, K.) And hadarato jar~apN Aln~abiy*i, (TA,) aor.
hadira , (A, TA,) inf. n. hadiyrN and tahodaArN, (TA,) (tropical:) [The jar of nby* fermented.] El-Akhtal says, describing wine,
kum~ato valaAvapa A^aHowaAlK biTiynatihaA
Hat~aY A_i*aA Sar~aHato mino biEodi tahodaAri
[It was stopped three years with its lump of clay, until, when it became free from froth, after fermenting]. (S, TA.)
2 hd~r * , said of a camel: see 1.
4 Ahdr * : see hadara. -A2- Ahdrhu: see hadarahu.

6 thAdrwA *
They made one another's blood to go for nothing; [meaning, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct;] they made it to be of no account. (K, TA.)
hadorN * : see hadarN: -A2- and see also haAdirN.
hidorN * : see haAdirN.

hadorN * , a subst. from hadara in the first of the senses explained above. (Msb.) You say, *ahaba damuhu hadarFA, (S, A, Msb,) and hadorFA, (S, Msb,) His blood went for nothing, or as a thing of no account, (S, A, Msb,) unretaliated, (S, Msb,) and uncompensated by a mulct. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to blood, &c., A thing that goes for nothing; [meaning, in the case of blood, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct;] what is of no account, ineffectual, null, or void; (A, K;) [as also jubaArN.] You say, dimaAw^uhumo hadarN bayonahumo Their blood (lit, bloods) is made to go for nothing, or to be of no account, among them; (K, * TA:) is allowed to be taken, or shed. (TA.) ― -b3- See also haAdirN.
hudarapN * : see haAdirN; the former, in two places.
hidarapN * : see haAdirN; the former, in two places.
jar~apN haduwrN * (tropical:) [A jar of wine or nabiy* fermenting much]. (TA.)
faHolN had~aArN * [A stallion- camel that brays much]. (TA.) See also haAdirN. ― -b2- raEodN had~aArN (tropical:) [Loud, or rumbling, thunder]. (A.)

haAdirN * , applied to a man, (tropical:) Low; ignoble; mean; of no account; worthless; (K;) as also ↓ hadorN, (Kr, K,) and ↓ hudarapN; (S, K;) which last is also applied to a woman: (K, TA: [in the former of which it seems to be implied that hadarapN and ↓ hidarapN are also applied, each, to a man and to a woman; but it appears from what is said in the TA that this is not the case:]) pl. hadarapN and hudarapN and hidarapN; the first of which is the most agreeable with analogy, like kafarapN, pl. of kaAfirN; the second being of a measure exclusively belonging to words which are unsound [in the last radical letter], as in the instances of guzaApN and quDaApN, [originally guzawapN and quDayapN, pls. of gaAzK and qaADK,] unless, indeed, it be a quasi-pl. n.; and some disapprove it, finding fault with IAar who relates it: the third, moreover, is not a pl. of a form, [regularly] belonging to a sing. of the measure faAEilN, whether sound or unsound: (ISd, TA:) [or, accord. to Sb, it is a quasi-pl. n.:] or it is pl. of ↓ hidorN. (TA,) which signifies a heavy man, (K, TA,) in whom is no good; analogous with qiradapN, pl. of qirodN. (TA:) and ↓ hadarN [a quasi-pl. n. of haAdirN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] signifies low, ignoble, or mean, people, in whom is no good. (TA.) You say, humo hadarapN, (S, A, K,) and hidarapN, (IAar, TS, K,) and hudarapN, (IAar, ISd, K,) (tropical:) They are low, ignoble, or mean, people; of no account, or worthless. (IAar, S, A, * K, &c.) -A2- [A braying camel: fem. with p pl. of the latter, hawaAdiru. You say,] A_ibilN hawaAdirN [Braying camels;] camels reiterating their voices in their HanaAjir. (S.) See also muhad~irN, and mubaHovirN. and had~aArN. ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN fuHolN haAdirN (tropical:) [app. Such a one is a vigorous orator of sonorous and fluent speech]. (A.)

kaA@lomuhad~iri fiY AlEun~api * [Like the brayer in the enclosure of wood, or canes, or trees]: a proverb: applied to a man who raises a cry and clamour which is followed by nothing, (S, A, *) or who raises a cry and clamour and does not make his saying or action to have effect: (A, K) like the camel that is confined in the enclosure of wood or canes or trees, prevented from covering, and brays. (S, K.)

div2.head: hdf &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 ha*~ * , aor.
ha*u3a , (S, L,) inf. n. ha*~N (S, L, K) and ha*a*N (L, K) and hu*aA*N, (K, TA,) or ha*aA*N, (CK, [which latter is the correct reading, (see ha*aA*ayoka,) and, accord. to the JK, is a quasi-inf. n.],) He cut quickly, or cut off quickly; as also ↓ Aht*~: (S, L, K:) or he cut anything. (K) ― -b2- ha*~ahu biAls~ayofi, inf. n. ha*~N, He cut him, or it, in pieces with the sword. (L,) ― -b3- ha*~a. aor.
ha*u3a , (S, L.) inf. n. had~N (S, L, K) and ha*a*N (L, K) and hu*aA*N, (K, TA,) or ha*aA*N; (CK [see above];) and ↓ Aht*~, (K:) (tropical:) He read, or recited, quickly. (S, L, K.) You say, had~a qiraA='atahu, aor. ha*~u3a inf. n. ha*~N, (tropical:) He performed his reading, or recitation, quickly. (Msb.) And huwa yahu*~u AlquroA=na (tropical:) He reads, or recites, the Kur-án rapidly and uninterruptedly: (S, A, L:) and in like manner, AlHadiyva the narrative; (S, L;) and Al$~iEora the poetry. (L.)
8 A_ihota*a3a see 1.
ha*~N * , or hi*~N: see ha*uw*N.

ha*uw*N * (S, L, K) and ha*~aA*N (K) and ↓ ha*~N, (L, CK,) or ↓ hi*~N, (as in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) and ↓ ha*ohaA*N and hu*aAhi*N, (L, K [the last in the CK ha*aAhi*N],) Sharp; quickly cutting: (S, L, K:) the first, which is masc. and fem., and the second, applied to a knife; (S * L;) and the last two, to a sword (L)

ha*aA*ayoka * , (as As says, S) is said to people when you desire them to refrain, or forbear, or abstain, from a thing; as also hajaAjayoka; supposing [it to be addressed to] two [persons]; (S, L;) [but it is addressed to one;] meaning Refrain thou! or forbear thou! or abstain thou! (TA, art. hj.) 'Abd-Beni-l-Has-hás says,
A_i*aA $uq~a burodN $uq~a biA@lobrdi mivoluhu
ha*aA*ayoka Hat~aY layos liloburodi laAbisu
[When a burd (a kind of garment) is rent, the like thereof is rent with the burd ― -b2- refrain thou ― -b3- so that there is no wearer of the burd, it having been rent so as to fall off: but it seems more proper to render it here, with rending after rending, which is nearly the original signification, as will be presently shown; and, thus rendered, it does not interrupt the sentence]: the women assert that, when, in the act of concubitus, [app., for the first time,] somewhat of the garment of the man is rent, love continues between the pair; but otherwise, that they desert each other. (S, L. [This verse is related with several variations: see another reading of it voce dawaAlayoka, in art. dwl.]) ― -b4- DarobFA ha*aA*ayoka With a beating, or striking, with cutting after cutting; (L, K;) baEoda ha*~K ↓ ha*~FA, (L,) i. e., qaToEFA baEoda qaToEK: (L, K:) or with a beating, or striking, successively; uninterruptedly; walaA='F tibaAEFA. (JK.) ― -b5- In the saying of the poet,
fabaAkara maxotuwmFA Ealayohi sayaAEuhu
ha*aA*ayoka Hat~aY A^anofa*a Ald~an~a A^ajomaEaA
[in which, for Anf*, in the L and TA, I substitute Anf*,] AHn says, that it signifies ha*~F baEoda ha*~K, i. e., $urobFA baEoda $urobK; the poet meaning And he applied himself early to a jar full of wine, [with its mud-plaster sealed upon it, with drinking after drinking, until he exhausted all that was in the jar,] and emptied it. (L.)
qarabN ha*ohaA*N * (assumed tropical:) A long and difficult night journey to water: (L, K:) or quick. (JK, K.) ― -b2- See h*w*.
ha*~aA*N * : see ha*uw*N. ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) A camel that outstrips others. (K.)

1 ha*aA^a * , aor.
ha*aAa , inf. n. ha*o'N, He cut a thing (As. S, K) [quickly], with a sword, &c. (TA.) It signifies a quicker act than does ha*~a. (K.) ― -b2- ha*aA^a He destroyed the enemy. (K, TA.) ― -b3- ha*aA^hu bilisaAnihi, (K, * TA,) inf. n. ha*o'N, (TA,) He hurt, or offended, [or cut,] him with his tongue; (TA;) made him to hear what he disliked. (K.) ― -b4- ha*aA^ati AlA_ibilu The camels fell down, [and, app., died,] one after another: syn. tasaAqaTato. (K.) ― -b5- ha*iy^a mina Albarodi, [aor. - ,] He perished of cold. (K.) ― -b6- ha*aA^a AlkalaAma He was loquacious, with error. (TA.)

5 th*~A^ *
It (a wound, or an ulcer.) became putrid, or rotten, and dissundered, or ragged. (S, K.)

ha*oA^apN *
i. q. misoHaApN [q. v., in arts. sHY and sHw.] (K.)
ha*~aA^N * and ↓ ha*~aA='N A sharp sword, (TA [but the orthography is not quite clear].) [See also art. h*Y.]
ha*~aA='N * : see ha*~aA^N.
h`*aA * : see art. *A.

1 ha*abahu * , aor.
ha*iba , inf. n. ha*obN, He cut it; or cut it off: (A, K:) like hadabahu. (TA.) ― -b2- ha*abahu, aor.
ha*iba , inf. n. ha*obN; (K;) and ↓ h*~bh, inf. n. taho*iybN; (S;) He cleansed it; purified it; cleared it. (S, K.) ― -b3- ha*iba, aor.
ha*aba , inf. n. ha*abN, It was pure, clear. (K: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b4- maA fiY mawad~atihi ha*bN There is no purity in his love. (TA.) ― -b5- ha*abahu, aor.
ha*iba , inf. n. ha*obN; and ↓ h*~bh, (inf. n. taho*ybN, TA); He put it into a right, or proper, state; put it to rights; trimmed, adjusted, repaired, mended, amended, reformed, or improved, it. (K.) ― -b6- ha*aba Aln~axolapa He trimmed the palm-tree by clearing it of the fibrous substance called liyf. (K.) ― -b7- MF says, on the authority of the etymologists, that the original signification of ↓ taho*iybN and ha*obN is The clearing, or trimming, of trees, by cutting off the extremities of the branches, in order that they may increase in growth and beauty; that they were then used to signify the cleansing, or purifying, of anything; and putting it into a right, or proper, state; trimming it; or adjusting it; and clearing it of any dirty or filthy things, or the like, mixed with it; so that these became their proper meanings by general acceptation: and that they were then used to signify the trimming and embellishing of verse, and clearing it of whatever might vitiate it in the opinion of the chaste in language, and the philologists: but the truth is what is said in the L; that the original signification of th*yb is the clearing the colocynth of its pulp, and preparing its seeds so that they may lose their bitterness, and become sweet. (TA.) -A2- ha*aba, (aor.
ha*iba , inf. n. ha*obN, TA,) It (a thing) flowed. (K.) ― -b2- ha*aba, (aor.
ha*iba , TA,) inf. n. ha*obN and ha*aAbapN; (K;) and ↓ Ah*b, (K,) inf. n. A_iho*aAbN; (S;) and ↓ h*~b, (K,) inf. n. taho*iyb; (S;) and ↓ haA*aba; (K;) He (a man, &c., K, as a horse in his running, and a bird in his flying, TA,) was quick, or swift, (K,) in his pace or course: (TA:) he was quick in flying, in running, and in speech. (S.) ― -b3- ha*aba He ran vehemently. (As.) ― -b4- yh*b Alr~ukuwEa [app. yuha*~ibu yuho*ibu] He makes the inclinations of his head and body [in prayer] in quick succession. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- See also art. hb*. ― -b6- ha*aba Alqawomu The people were very noisy, or clamourous, (K,) and loquacious. (TA.)

2 ha*~aba see 1. ― -b2- h*~b, inf. n. taho*iybN, He trimmed an arrow; or shaped it with nicety, by the second operation: the first operation is called ta$o*iybN. (AHn.) ― -b3- ha*~aba EanohaA i. q. far~aqa, accord. to EsSukkaree, who cites the following verse of one of the Hudhalees: (namely Aboo-Khirásh, L, art. Trd:)
faha*~aba EanohaA maA yaliY AlbaTona waA@notaHaY
Tariydapa matonK bayona EajobK wakaAhili
[app., He removed from her what was next the belly, and directed himself to a line of the back, between the rump-bone and withers]. (TA.)
3 haAo*aba see 1.

4 Ah*bt Als~aHaAbapu *
The cloud poured forth its water quickly. (K.) See 1.

5 th*b * [It became nicely, neatly, or properly, trimmed]: said of a thing from which one has cut off whatever required to be cut off, so that it has become free from everything unseemly. (A, TA, art. H*f.) ― -b2- tahad~abotu EalaY yadika [I was, or have been, amended, or improved, by thy agency, or means]. (A, TA, art. vqf.)
HamiymN ha*ibN * , after the manner of a rel. n., A rain following vehement heat, that pours down quickly: see 4: syn. *uw A_iho*aAbK. (TA.)

hayo*abaY *
A kind of pace of a horse; (S;) like hayodabaY: (K:) a subst. from ha*aba “ he was quick, or swift, in his pace. ” (TA.) The former is also mentioned by Az, in the T; IDrd only mentions the latter word. (TA.) ― -b2- A running with a leaning on one side. Ex. ma$aY Alhayo*abaY [He went leaning on one side]. (IAmb.) But for this some read m$Y Alhawoba*aY, which is equivalent to hy*bY. (TA.)
rajulN muha*~abN * (tropical:) A man of purified natural dispositions, or manners, or morals; (S, K;) a man of integrity; free from vices, or faults. (L.)

muha*~ibN *
Quick, or swift, [in pace, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Almuha*~ibu is also a name of The Devil; who is also called Almu*ohibu, meaning “ he who embellishes,
or gives a goodly appearance to, acts of disobedience [to God]. ” (Fr.)

A_ibilN mahaA*iybu *
Quick, or swift, camels. (K.)

1 ha*ira kalaAmuhu * , aor.
ha*ara , (A, K,) inf. n. ha*arN, (TA,) His speech, or talk, was much, or abundant, and erroneous and false or vain or frivolous. (A, K.) ― -b2- ha*ara, aor.
ha*ura and
ha*ira , He talked much; babbled. was loquacious, or garrulous: (JK:) [or he talked irrationally:] or ha*ara fiY manoTiqihi. aor.
ha*ura and
ha*ira . inf. n. ha*orN (S, Msb, K) and taho*aArN, (K,) which latter has an intensive signification, (TA,) he confounded in his speech, and talked what was not fit or meet or proper: (Msb:) or he talked much and badly: or erroneously: (K:) or he talked nonsense; he talked irrationally, foolishly, or deliriously: (S;) as also ↓ Ah*r: (K:) and fiY kalaAmihi ↓ Ah*r he talked much; babbled; was loquacious, or garrulous. (S, TA.)
4 A^aho*ara see 1, in two places.

laA nazorN walaA ha*orN *
Not little nor much: (TA:) or not scanty, so as to indicate impotence, nor much and corrupt: said of the speech of Mohammad. (K, art. nzr.) [See ha*arN, from which it is altered to assimilate it in form to nazorN.]

ha*arN * , a subst. from ha*ara fiY manoTiqihi, (S, Msb,) Much talk; babble: (JK:) or nonsense; or irrational, foolish, or delirious, talk: (S:) or confused and improper speech: (Msb:) or speech, or talk, that is much and bad: or erroneous: (A, K:) or that is not regarded as of any weight or worth. (TA.) See also ha*orN.
ha*urN * : see ha*irN.

ha*irN * , an epithet from ha*ara, applied to a man, [signifying, Loquacious; garrulous; babbling; a great talker; a bubbler. or nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk: or one who speaks confusedly and improperly: or who speaks, or talks, much and badly: or erroneously:] (JK, S, K:) as also, [but in an intensive sense.] ↓ ha*urN (K) and ↓ hu*arapN (S, K) and ↓ hu*ur~pN (K) and ↓ ha*~aArN (S, K) and ↓ hayo*aArN (K) and ↓ hi*oriyaAnN (JK, A, K) and ↓ maho*arN (K) and ↓ miho*aArN, (JK, S, A, Msb, K,) [signifying, very loquacious, &c.:] and, [but in a doubly intensive sense.] ↓ hayo*aArapN (JK, K) and ↓ miho*aArapN, (JK, A, K.) [signifying very very loquacious, &c.:] fem. ha*irapN (K) and ↓ hayo*arapN (TA) and ↓ miho*aArN [without p]: (K:) or ↓ hi*oriyaAnN signifies one who talks badly, or corruptly, and much: (TA:) or light in speech and in service: (S, TA:) the pl. of ↓ miho*aArN is mahaA*yru, not miho*aAruwna. (ISd, TA.)
hu*arapN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
hu*ur~apN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
hi*oriyaAnN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
ha*~aArN * see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
hayo*arapN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
hayo*ArN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
hayo*aArapN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
maho*irN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
maho*aArN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
maho*aArapN * : see ha*irN; the third, in two places.
Q. 1 ha*oraba * , inf. n. ha*orabapN, He talked much and quickly: (K:) a dial form of ha*orama, or mispronounced for the latter word. (TA.) See also hazorb.
hu*ayribFY * (accord to the TA, ha*ayorabFY, and so in Golius's Lex.,) Custom; habit Ex. h`*ihi h*yrbAhu This is his custom, or habit. (K.)

hu*orubaAnN *
Light, or active, (and quick. TA,) in his speech and in his service. (K.) See also hi*oriyAnN, in art. h*r.

div2.head: h*f &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
Q. 1 ha*olama * , inf. n. ha*olamapN, He was light, or active, and quick. (K.) But IDrd and others assert it to be a word mispronounced for ha*oram. (MF.)

1 har~a * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yahir~u, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. hariyrN, (S, A, &c.,) said of a dog, [He snarled, or howled, or whined;] he uttered a cry less vehement than barking (S, A, Msb, K.) by reason of his little patience of cold; (S, K) A_ilayohi at him. (K.) or barked and grinned, displaying his fangs. (L, TA.) It is said in a trad, A_in~a Alkaloba yahir~u mino waraA='i A^aholihi Verily the dog [snarls, or] harks and grins, displaying his fangs, behind his master: meaning, that courage is a quality implanted by nature in a man, so that he engages in wars naturally, and from care to defend what should be inviolable, not reckoning upon a reward, like as the dog naturally barks and grins, displaying his tangs, to defend his masters. (L, TA.) ― -b2- hariyrN is also applied to other sounds than the cry of the dog; as in the instance of hariyru Alr~HaY (assumed tropical:) The sound of the turning of the mill-stone. (TA.) You say also har~ati Alqawosu (assumed tropical:) The bow made a sound. (AHn, K.) And the looking of courageous men, one at another, is likened to hariyr. (ISd, Msb.) ― -b3- har~a fiY wajohi Als~aAy^ili (tropical:) He grinned in the face of the beggar, showing his teeth, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] har~ahu. (S, K,) aor. yahur~u and yahir~a, (K,) [the latter irreg., like yarim~u as aor. of the trans. v. ram~a,] inf. n. har~N (S, K) and hariyrN. (K,) (tropical:) He disliked, disapproved of or hated, him or it. (S, K.) You say, har~ahu Aln~aAsu (tropical:) The people disliked, &c., his vicinity. (A.) And har~a AlkaAsa. and AlHaroba, (S, A,) inf. n. hariyrN. (S.) (tropical:) He disliked. &c., the cup of wine, and war. (S, A.) -A2- har~ahu Albaroda, (K,) aor. yahur~uhu, inf. n. har~N, (TA,) The cold made him (a dog) [to snarl, or hand, or whine; or] to cry [in the manner described above]; as also ↓ A^ahar~ahu, (K,) inf. n. A_ihoraArN. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, (TA,) *aA naAbK ↓ $ar~N A^ahr~a [It is, or was, an evil thing that made the fanged animal to snarl, &c.]: alluding to the appearance of the signs and symptoms of evil: the sayer thereof, hearing the cry (hariyr) of a dog, feared the assault of evil, and therefore said this to denote the magnitude of the case in his mind: meaning, nought but an evil thing made the fanged animal to cry: and for this reason, the use of an indeterminate word as an inchoative is well. (K.)

3 haAr~ah *
i. q. har~a fY wajohh, (S, K,) i. e., (tropical:) He grinned in his face, showing his teeth, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (A) like a dog. (TA.)
4 A^ahora3a see 1, last signification, in two places.

hir~N *
A male cat; syn. sin~aworN; (S, A, K:) which latter is uncommon in the language of the Arabs (IAmb, in Msb, art. snr;) fem. hir~apN: (S, A. Msb, K:) or hir~N is applied to the male and the female; and the latter is sometimes called hrapN (IAmb, Msb:) the pl. of hr~N is hirrpN: and that of hir~apN is hirarN: and the dim. of hir~apN is hurayorapN. (Msb)) -A2- Also, a subst. from har~ahu meaning "he disapproved of, or hated, him or it. " (S) It is said in a proverb, (S,) yaEorifu hir~FA mino br~K (S, A, K,) meaning He knows not him who dislikes or hates him from him who behaves towards him with goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances. (S, TA.) this is the best explanation of it: (TA:) or the action of him who grins in his face, showing his teeth, and looking steraly, austerely, or morosely, from the action of him who holds loving communion with him. (A:) or the calling of sheep or goats, (S,) or the calling of them to water. (K.) from the driving of them: (S:) or the calling of sheep or goats to provender from the calling of them to water: (IAar) or
the driving of sheep or goats (Yoo, K) from the calling of them. (Yoo, TA.) It has been explained [more fully] in art. br. (K.)
har~aArN * : see haAr~N.

haAr~N * A dog [that snarls, or howls, or whines, by reason of his little patience of cold: or] that barks and grins, displaying his fangs: and ↓ har~aArN signifies the same [but in an intensive manner; that snarls, &c., much:] or the latter signifies a dog that grins [much], displaying his fangs: or that barks much: or that barks [much] and grins, displaying his fangs. It is said in a trad., laA A^aEoqilu Alkaloba ↓ Alhar~aAra [properly signifying, I will not pay a fine for killing the dog that barks much, is expl. as] meaning, I will not impose anything [as a fine] for the killing of a dog that barks much; because such a dog annoys by his barking. (TA, [see art. Eql.]) ― -b2- EaAda lahaA AlmaTiY~u haAr~FA The ridingcamels returned to her, or it, one grinning (yahir~u) in the face of another, showing its teeth, in consequence of fatigue. (TA.)

1 haraA^ahu Albarodu *
The cold destroyed him, or, perhaps, debilitated him; i. e., a beast; lit., broke him: syn. ksrh. (TA.) [See also hazaA^a.] ― -b2- hariy^a, like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (incorrectly written in the S hariy^a, K,) It (a camel or sheep &c., or a man.) perished of cold, or heat. (Ks, K.) ― -b3- haraA^ahu Albarodu, inf. n. haro'N (As, S, K,) and haraA='apN; (K;) and ↓ AhrA^hu; (Fr, S, K;) The cold affected him so severely as nearly to kill him: (As, S, K:) or so severely as to kill him. (K.) ― -b4- haraA^ati Alr~iyHu The wind was, or became, intensely cold. (K.) -A2- haraA^a, (K,) inf. n. haro'N; (TA:) and ↓ hr~A^; (K;) and ↓ AhrA^, (Fr, K,) inf. n. A_ihoraA='N; (TA;) He cooked flesh-meat thoroughly: (K:) or so that it fell off from the bone. (S, K.) ― -b2- hariy^a, aor.
haraAa , inf. n. haro'N and huro'N and huruwo'N; (K;) and ↓ thr~A^; (S, K;) It (flesh-meat) was thoroughly cooked: (K:) or was cooked so as to fall off from the bone. (S, * TA.) -A3- haraA^a fiY manoTiqihi, (S, K,) aor.
haraAa , (K,) inf. n. haro'N, (TA,) He was loquacious: or he was loquacious, with incorrectness; (TA;) as also haraA^a AlkalaAma: (ISk, S:) or he was very foul in his speech: or was very incorrect, or faulty, therein: (K:) or, simply, he was foul, (S,) or incorrect, or faulty, (TA,) in his speech: (S, TA:) also AlkalaAma ↓ AhrA^ he multiplied his words but spake not to the point, or correctly. (K.) ― -b2- A_in~a manoTiqaha yahoraA^u, inf. n. haro'N, [Verily his speech is prolix: or is vitious, and disorderly]. (TA.)
2 har~aAa see 1.

4 A^ahoraAa see 1. ― -b2- AhrA^ fiY Alr~awaAHi He entered upon the cool time of the evening: (S, K: *) or properly said only of the evening of the hot season. (K.) [See also AhzA^.] ― -b3- A^ahoriy^u Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (TA, in this art.; and IAar, in TA, art. fyH.) -A2- AhrA^ He slew a person. (K.) -A3- See 1, last sentence but one.

5 thr~AF *
He (a beast) was destroyed, or, perhaps, debilitated, by the cold; lit., was broken: syn. tks~r. (TA.) -A2- See 1.
hariy^N * (so in the TA: in one copy of the S, hariYN: in another, hariY~N:) and ↓ muhar~aA^N (TA) Meat thoroughly cooked: (TA:) or cooked so as to fall off from the bone. (S, * TA.)
huraA^N * : see huraA='N.

huraA='N * , or manoTiqN huraA='N, (S, K,) Loquacity: or vitious, disorderly, speech: (K:) or loquacity with incorrectness. (S.) ― -b2- huraA='N, (K,) fem. with p, pl. with wn; (TA;) and ↓ huraA^N; (K;) A great talker of nonsense. (K.)

hiraA='N *
A young shoot of a palm-tree, (AHn, K,) when first plucked from the mother-tree. (As.) -A2- AlhiraA='u A certain devil whose office it is to suggest foul dreams. (K.)

qir~apN lahaA hariyoy^apN *
Cold that occasions injury and death to men and to cattle &c. (El-Fezáree, ISk, S.) ― -b2- Also, hariyoy^apN The time in which cold thus affects them. (TA.)

mahoruwo'N * , from huriy^a, pl. with wn, [in the CK, for mahoruww^uwna is put mahoraw^una,] Perishing of cold, or heat. (Ks, K.) ― -b2- Explained by AHn [in his book on plants] by the words A^al~a*iY qado A^anoDajahu Albarodu [meaning, What is nipped, shrunk, shrivelled, or blasted, by the cold: see art. nDj]. (TA.)
muhar~aA^N * : see hariy^N.

1 haraba * , (S, K,) aor.
haruba ; not
haraba , as some have imagined on account of the measure of the first of the following inf. ns., imagining thence also that the pret. is hariba; nor
haraba with the pret. haraba, as some have supposed because of the guttural letter; for a guttural letter, when it is the first, is not reckoned as having any influence on the form of the aor.; nor
hariba , as some have thought; (TA;) inf. n. harabN (S, K) and mahorabN and harabaAnN; (K;) He (a man, or any animal, TA) fled; ran away. (S, K.) ― -b2- A_ilayoka minoka Almahorabu [To Thee I flee for refuge from Thee; i. e., from thy punishment: addressed to God]. (TA.) ― -b3- haraba mina Alwatadi niSofuhu Half of the wooden pin, peg, or stake, disappeared [in the ground]. (K.) -A2- hariba, aor.
haraba , He became extremely aged, old and weak, or decrepit; i. q. harima; (K;) of which it is a dial. form. (TA.)
2 hr~bh * , inf. n. tahoriybu, He made, or caused, him to flee, or run away. (S, K.) See also 4.

4 Ahrbh *
He forced, or compelled, him to flee, or run away. (K.) See also 2. ― -b2- Ahrbti Alr~iyHu The wind raised and carried away the dust, (K,) causing dust and dry herbage &c. to accumulate on the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- Ahrb He (a horse, or other animal that runs, Lh) strove, or exerted himself, in going away, or in flight, being frightened, (ISk, S, K,) or not being frightened. (TA.) See jaA'a muhoribFA. ― -b4- Ahrb He went, or travelled, far into, or through, the land. (TA.) [fY ↓ haraba AlA^aroDi, mentioned also in the TA, seems to signify the same.] ― -b5- Ahrb fiY AlA^amori He immersed himself in the affair; took extraordinary pains in it. (K.) See jaA'a muhoribFA.
6 thArbwA * (S, O, K, art. fr,) They fled, one from another. (TK.)
hurobN * The thin integument of fat that covers the stomach and intestines: or the fat [or caul] that is spread over the intestines: i. q. varobu AlbaToni: (K:) a word of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

maA lahu haAribN walaA qaAribN *
He has not [of camels &c.] any that returns from water, nor any that comes to it; i. e., he has not anything; (Kh, S, K;) or, he has not anything, nor has he any people; an expression similar to maA lahu saEonapN walaA maEonapN: (Lh:) accord. to IAar, haAribN signifies one who returns from water; and qaAribN, one who seeks, or journeys to, water: (TA:) or the meaning is no one flees from him, nor does any one approach him; i. e., he is a person of no account. (As, K.) [In the TA a trad. is quoted which confirms the former signification.] See also art. qrb.

mahorabN *
A place to which one flees; a place of refuge. (Msb.) ― -b2- fulaAnN lanaA mahorabN (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a refuge to us. (TA.)

jaA'a muhoribFA *
He came striving, or exerting himself, in the affair: (Lh:) or, as some say, he came fleeing and in fright. (TA.)

mihorabN *
A piece of wood, or wooden implement, which the sower, or ploughman, draws forward and backward [over the ground]. (K.) [A piece of the trunk of a tree, or of a thick branch, is thus drawn over the soil after sowing.]

hirobi*N * sing. of haraAbi*apN, which signifies The servants, or ministers of the fire (S, K) of the Magians; (K;) the servants, or ministers, (qawamap,
L, K, by which is meant xadam, TA,) of the fire temple of the Indians: (L, K:) or the judges of the Magians: (L:) or the great men of the Indians: or their learned men: (L, K:) a Persian word, [originally hirobido,] arabicized. (S, L.)

haroba*apN *
A pace less quick than that termed xababN. (S, L, K.)

hirobi*aY *
A proud and self-conceited manner of walking, or going: (L, K;) which a (L.) a manner of waking or going like that of the haraAbi*ap [pl. of hirobi*N] (A'Obeyd, 1: A'Obeyd mentions it in speaking of the paces of camels. and says that it is without a parallel in form. (L.) ― -b2- EadaA Aljamalu Alhirobi*aY The camel ran in clining towards one side. (S, L, K.)

1 harata $ayoy^FA * , [aor.
harita and
haruta ,] inf. n. harotN, He rent, or slit, a thing, to widen it. (TA.) ― -b2- harata $idoqahu, [aor.
harita and
haruta ,] inf. n. hazotN He drew the side of his mouth towards the ear, (TA) ― -b3- harita, aor.
harata , (inf. n. haratN, S,) He was wide, or ample, in the sides of the mouth: he had a wide mouth (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- harata Alv~awoba, (S,) aor. and
haruta , inf. n. harotN, (ISd, K,) He was the garment. (Az, S, ISd, K.) ― -b5- hrt EiroDahu (S) aor. and
haruta , inf. n. harotN, (K,) He wounded his reputation; syn. TaEana fiyhi; (S:) as also harad and haraTa, (TA.) [Accord. to the K, harata seems to signify the same as TaEana absolutely: but in the TA the signification is restricted as above; ― -b6- harata All~aHoma, (S, K,) aor.: and
haruta , inf. n. harotN, (K,) [and ↓ har~atahu: see muhar~atN;] He cooked the flesh-meat thoroughly: (K:) cooked it so that it fel off from the bones, (S,)
2 har~ata see 1, last sentence.
Alharitu * and Alharuwtu see Alhariytu.

hariytN *
Wide or ample. (K.) ― -b2- Wide, or ample, in the sides of the mouth: (S:) as also ↓ A^ahortu Al$~idoqi, and hariytu Al$dq, and ↓ mahoruwtuhu: and ↓ munohrituhu. (TA A wide-mouthed horse; as also ↓ A^ahoratu. and camel (TA) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce rasanN.] ― -b3- Hay~pN hariytu Al$~idoq. and ↓ mhoruwtatuhu. A serpent having a wide mouth. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ A^asodN A^ahoratu A lion wide in the sides of the mouth. (S.) ― -b5- ↓ AjulN A^ahoratu A man having a wide mouth. (TA.) ― -b6- Alfami ↓ muhoruwtu Having a mouth wide in the sides. (S.) ― -b7- ↓ kilaAbN muharotuhu AlA^a$odaAqi Dogs wide in the sides of the mouth. (S.) [See an ex., voce Ea*abN] ― -b8- Alhariytu and ↓ Alharitu and ↓ Alharuwtu and ↓ Alhar~aAtu (K.) and ↓ Almuhar~atu (L) The lion. (K.) ― -b9- Also hariytN A woman in whom the division between the vagina and the rectum has been broken through. (S, K.) Sometimes employed in this sense. (S,) ― -b10- hariytN A rent garment (ISd.) ― -b11- hariytN A wounded reputation. (ISd) -A2- rajulN hrytN A man who does not keep a secret, and who talks fault. (K.)
Alhar~aAtu * : see Alhryitu.

hAruwtu * [A certain fallen angel. the companion of maAruwtu] the name of an anger, or of a king. but the former accord. to the more common opinion: generally and most correctly held to be a foreign name (TA.)
A^uhoratu * see hariytN throughout. ― -b2- A^ahoratu Al$~iqo$iqapi † an epithetic appellation given to a xaTiyb; pl. hurotN: (TA;) [like *uw $iqo$iqap q. v.]
mahoruwtN * : see hrytN.
muhar~atN * : see hariytN. -A2- Flesh-meat thoroughly cooked, so that it has fallen in pieces; as also muhar~adN; or this latter [only] is the correct word. (TA, from a trad.)

mutahaAritN *
Twisting about the sides of the mouth, and drawing them often. or much towards the ears (TA, from a trad.)
mutohawitN * : see hariytN.
hirovN * An old, worn-out garment. (K.) [See also hawiyvN.]

1 harija * aor. inf. n. harojN He did, acted, or occupied himself, much in a thing (S, L:) expatiated, or to a wide range, in it. (L.) This is the original signification. (S,) ― -b2- harj fiY AlHidiyvi, (aor, inf. n. harojN. Msb.) He launched into, and expatiated in. or was diffuse in discourse, talk or narration: (K:) this is the signification in most frequent use: (TA:) or he made a confusion, or confounded, therein. (K, Msb.) ― -b3- haraj. aor
harija , and
haruja , inf. n. harojN, Multum inivit (S. L.) or [simply] inivit an cillam suam (K.) ― -b4- haraja, aor.
harija , (inf. n. harojN, TA,) He (a horse) ran much (S. L:) or ran quickly or swiftly: (Msb:) or [simply] ran (K,) ― -b5- haraja Aln~aAsu aor.
harija , (inf. n. harojN, (S.) The people fell into a state of trial, or civil war or conflict and faction or discord, or discussion, (fitonap,) and confusion, or disorder, (S, K,) and slaughter. (K.) ― -b6- harija, aor.
haraja , (inf. n. harajN, S,) He (a camel) became perplexed in his sight, by reason of the vehemence of heat, and his being much smeared with pitch, (S, K,) and being heavily laden. (TA.)

2 hr~j AlbaEiyra * , inf. n. tahoriyjN, and ↓ Ahrjhu, inf. n. A_ihoraAjN; He incited, or urged, the camel to journey on (during the hottest time of the day, S) until he [the camel] became perplexed so his sight by reason of the vehemence of the beat. (S, K.) ― -b2- hr~j biAls~aboEi, inf. n. tahoriyjN, He cried and to the lion or other beast of prey, and child him. (S, K.) -A2- hr~j. inf. n. tahoriyjN. It (beverage of the kind called nabiy*) affected, or took effect upon, a person. (S, K.)
4 A^ahoraja see 2. ― -b2- A^ahoraja The heal reached has (a camel's) inside (L.)

6 thArjwA *
Iniverunt, ulii alias. (TA.)

7 AnhrJ *
He was, or became, affected by beverage of the kind called nabiy*. (S, CK)

harojN *
Trial, or civil war, or conflict and faction, or discord, or dissension. (fitanopN,) and confusion. or disorder: (S:) vehement and much slaughter (TA:) in a trad. respecting the signs of the last day, conflict, and confusion, or disorder: (TA:) or slaughter; as explained by Mohammad himself: (S:) and so, accord to Aboo-Moosa. It signifies in the language of Abyssinia (TA.) Ibn-Keys Fr-Rukeiyát said in the days of the faction of Ibn-Ez-Zubayi.
layot $iEoriY A^aA^aw~alu Alharoji h`*aA
A^amN zamaAnN mino fitonapi gayori haroji
Would that I knew whether this be the first of the slaughter predicted as a sign of the last day, or whether it be a time of trial, or civil war &c., other than the slaughter so predicted (S)
har~aAjN * : see mhorajN.

har~aAjapN *
An assembly, or a company, of men who launch into, and expatiate in, or are diffuse in, discourse, talk, or narration.
muhorijN * A man whose camels are affected with the scab, and have therefore been smeared with pitch, and to whose insides the heat has penetrated. (TA.)
mihorajN * and ↓ har~aAjN A horse that runs much: (S. K:) and ↓ mihoraAjN a horse that runs vehemently (TA.)
mihorAjN * : see mihorjN.
Q. 1 harojaba * . inf. n. harojabapN, He was quick. or swift. (IKtt)

hirojaAbN * and hirjab~N Tall, or long, as an epithet of a man &c. (K.) ― -b2- hirojaAbN A tall, or longbodied, (Tawiylap) and bulky, she-camel: (S:) as also hirjaAlN: pl. haraAjiybu. ― -b3- hirojaAbN Anything great, large, or bulky: so in the Moajam: or extending long, horizontally. (TA.) ― -b4- naxolapN hirojaAbN A tall palm-tree. (TA.)

1 harada * , (S, L, K,) aor.
harida , (K,) inf. n. harodN, (L,) He rent, or tore, (S, L, K,) a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, L;) as also harata: (Az, L:) he rent, or tore, to injure, or spoil, (L, K,) not to amend: (L:) he (a puller) rent, or tore, and beat, a garment, or piece of cloth: (L:) and ↓ hr~d he rent, or tore, much. (L.) ― -b2- harada EiroDahu, aor.
harida , (L,) inf. n. harodN, (S, L, K,) He wounded his reputation. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- harada, aor.
harida , (S, L, K,) inf. n. harodN, (L,) He cooked flesh-meat so that it fell off from the bones: (S, L, K:) or cooked it much: (As, L:) or cooked it thoroughly and well: (ISd, L, K:) and ↓ hr~d, (K,) inf. n. tahoriydN, (S, L,) signifies the same, (S, L, K,) but with an intensiveness: (S, L:) or he put flesh-meat into the fire, and cooked it thoroughly. (AZ, L.) ― -b4- harida, (L, K, TA,) or harada, (AZ, L, CK,) and ↓ thr~d, (TA,) It (flesh-meat) became cooked so that it fell off from the bones: or, cooked much: or, cooked thoroughly and well: (L, K: *) or it, being put into the fire, became thoroughly cooked. (AZ, L.) Irreg. verb. haradotu Al$~aYo'a, aor. A^uhariyduhu, [in the CK, A^uhoriyduhu,] (Lh, M, art. rwd; and K,) inf. n. hiraAdapN, (Lh, M in art. rwd,) i. q. A^aradotuhu [q. v., in art. rwd, I willed, wished, or desired, the thing]. (Lh, M, art. rwd; and K.)
2 har~ada see 1. -A2- hr~d, inf. n. tahoriydN, He wore a mahoruwd, (K,) i. e., a yellow garment, dyed with hurod. (TA.)
5 tahar~ada see 1.

hurodN *
Certain roots with which one dyes, (L, K,) of a yellow colour: (TA:) or (so accord. to the L; but in the K, and) i. q. kurokumN: (L, K:) or the yellow kurokum: correctly, the roots of the kurokum, or waros: (TA:) and a certain red earth (K) with which one dyes. (TA.)

hirodaY * , (As, S, L, K, [but in the last it is not shown whether it be with or without tenween]) of the measure faEolaY, (S, L,) of the fem. gen., (IAmb,) but AHn says, I know not whether it be masc. [and therefore with tenween] or fem. [and therefore without tenween], (L.) [in one instance in the L, and in a copy of the K, written hrdA, which is evidently wrong,] and hirodaA=', [i. e. hirodaA='u or hirodaA='N,] (L, K,) and ↓ hirodaAnN, (L,) A certain plant; (As, S, L, K;) a certain herb, of which AHn says, that he had not met with a description of it: (L:) and ↓ hayorudaAnN is also the name of a certain plant, (K,) like hirodaY, (L,) or i. q. hirodaAnN. (TA.)
hurodiY~N * : see mahoruwdN.
hirodaAnN * : see hirodaY.
hayorudaAnN * : see hirodaY.
hariydN * and ↓ mahoruwdN A garment, or piece of cloth, rent, or torn; (L;) as also hariytN. (AZ.)

mahoruwdN * : see hariydN. ― -b2- Also, (S, L, K,) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed yellow (S, L) with hurod; (L;) and so ↓ muhar~adN (L) and ↓ hurodiY~N: (K, * TA,) or, as Sh says, accord. to information given to Aboo-'Adnán by an intelligent Arab of the desert, of the people called Báhileh, dyed with waros, and then with saffron, so as to become of a colour like that of the flower of the Hawo*aAnap: (Az, L:) or of a light yellow colour. (IAmb, L.)
muhar~adN * : see mahoruwdN.
Q. 1 harodaba * , inf. n. harodabapN, (and hrdb, TA, [a strange form: perhaps a mistake for harodaAbN or hirodaAbN:]) He ran heavily. (IKtt &c., and K.)

hirodab~apN * (and hirodab~N, TA) An old woman. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (as some say, TA,) Having a swollen belly, and cowardly: (S, K:) or cowardly, bulky, of little sense, swollen in the belly, and having no heart. (TA.) ― -b3- Accord. to Az, in the T, A large, long-bodied man is called hirodab~apN. (TA.)

1 harasahu * , aor.
harusa , (IF, A, Msb,) inf. n. harosN, (IF, S, A, Msb, K,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; crushed it so as to break it; broke it, or broke it in pieces, by beating; (S, IF, Msb, TA;) namely, grain, (Msb,) or some other thing: (IF, Msb:) or he did so vehemently, or violently: (A, K:) or with something broad: or with some preservative between it and the ground. (TA.)

hariysN *
Grain, (Msb,) or wheat, (A,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (A, Msb,) vehemently, or violently, (A,) with the mahoraAs, before it is cooked; for when it is cooked, it is termed hariysapN: (Msb:) [of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN:] from the verb above-mentioned. (K.) You say, EinodiY hariysN lilohariysapi I have wheat bruised, &c., for the hariysap. (A.)

hariysapN *
Grain, (Msb,) or wheat, (TA,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, [vehemently, or violently, (see hariysN,)] and then cooked: (Msb, TA:) [or a kind of thick pottage, prepared of cooked wheat and cooked flesh-meats much pounded together: (Golius; app. on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof:) but this is probably one of the kinds of hrysp peculiar to post-classical times; which kinds are many: see De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-Allatif, pp. 307 and 312:] of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) from the verb above-mentioned: (S, K:) pl. haraAy^isu. (A.)

har~aAsN *
A maker, or preparer, of hariysap: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and a seller thereof. (Mgh.)

mihoraAsN * [in the M, voce juronN, q. v., accord. to the TA, mhrs, i. e., app. mihorasN,] A stone hollowed out, (S, Mgh, Msb,) oblong, (Mgh, Msb,) and heavy, resembling a [vessel of the kind called] tawor, q. v., (Mgh,) in which one bruises, brays, or pounds, and from which one performs the ablution termed wuDuwo'; (S, Mgh, Msb;) and it is also made of brass; and grain and other things are bruised in it: (Msb:) and sometimes, by a tropical application, (tropical:) one of wood, (Mgh, Msb,) used for the same purpose: (Msb:) or a mortar; syn. haAwuwnN; (K;) or thing in which grain is bruised: (A, TA,) and also, (A, K,) tropically, (A,) (tropical:) a hollowed stone, (A, K,) of oblong shape, (A,) from which one performs the ablution above mentioned; (A, K;) consisting of a bulky stone, which several men cannot lift nor move because of its weight, capable of holding much water. (TA.)

1 hari$a * , aor.
hara$a , (Sgh, K,) inf. n. hara$N, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, evil, or bad, in disposition. (Sgh, K.) -A2- hra$a Ald~ahoru, (Ibn- 'Abbád, A, K,) and Alz~amaAnu, (A,) aor.
haru$a and
hari$a , (A, K,) inf. n. haro$N, (TK,) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, was, or became, distressful, or calamitous. (I'Abbád, A, K.) [In the A, app. by inadvertence, hr$ Aldhr is mentioned as proper; and hr$ AlzmAn, as tropical.]

2 har~a$a bayona AlkilaAbi * , (A, * K, * TK,) inf. n. tahoriy$N, (S, A, K,) He excited strife, or quarrel-ling, between, or among, the dogs; syn. Har~a$a: (S, * A, K, TK:) and bayona AlkilaAbi ↓ hAr$, (A, Mgh, TA,) or biAlkilaAbi, (S,) or baEoDa AlkilaAbi EalaY baEoDK, (K, * TK,) inf. n. muhaAra$apN (S, A, Mgh, K) and hiraA$N, (S, Mgh,) he incited the dogs to attack one another. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] hr~$ bayona Alqawomi, (A,) or bayona Aln~aAsi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (tropical:) He excited discord, dissension,
disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people. (S, * A, K.)

3 haAra$aA * [They fought and assailed each other]: said of two dogs. (A.) See also 6. ― -b2- [Hence,] kalobu hiraA$K [An irritable, or a quarrelsome, dog]; like kalobu xiraA$K. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2. ― -b4- hiraA$N is also used to signify The fighting against each other of men. (Mgh.)
6 thAr$t AlkilaAbu * , and ↓ Ahtr$t, (A, K, TA,) and baEoDuhaA baEoDFA ↓ haAra$a, (A,) The dogs fought and assailed one another. (TA.)
8 A_ihotara$a see 6.

hiro$ab~apN *
An old woman far advanced in years: (K:) a worn-out old woman; as also hiro$af~apN. (T.)

haraAmiytu *
Wells: (K;) a pl. that has no sing.; or its sing. is hiromiytN or huromuwtN; or perhaps the t is an augmentative letter: (MF:) or, accord. to the L, it is a name of a certain group of wells in the tract of Ed-Dahma, said to have been dug by Lukmán the son of 'Ád: or, accord. to As, certain wells on the left of Dareeyeh: if so, F has erred in prefixing to it the art. Al. (TA.)

1 haz~ahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and haz~a bihi, [respecting which see what is said on an ex. below,] (A, K,) aor.
hazu3a , (A, Msb,) inf. n. haz~N, (S, A, Msb,) [He shook it;] he put it in motion, or into a state of commotion; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ hz~zhu, (S, K,) and hz~z bihi, (TA,) inf. n. tahoziyzN; (K;) and ↓ hazohazahu, (S, K,) inf. n. hazohazapN; (TA;) meaning, he made it move by pulling and pushing; or he made it move to the right and left: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, he did so with violence, or vehemence. (TA.) It is said that haz~a is trans. by itself, and by means of bi, like A^axa*a and taEal~aqa: it is trans. in the latter manner in the Kur., [xix. 25,] where it is said, wahuz~iY A_ilayoki biji*oEi Aln~axolapi [And shake thou towards thee the trunk of the palm-tree], i. e. Har~ikiY: but ISd says, that the verb is here made trans. by means of b because it is used in the sense of jur~iY: and MF says, that, properly, it is not trans. by means of b. (TA.) You say, haz~a Als~ayofa wagayorahu [He shook the sword, &c.] (A.) And haz~ati Alr~iyHu AlA^agoSaAna, (A,) and Al$~ajara, and ↓ haz~azatohaA, (S,) [The wind shook the branches, and the trees,] and haz~ati Aln~abaAta it shook (Har~akat) the plants: but this has also a tropical signification, which see below. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, A^uhuz~u katifiY, and manokibiY, (tropical:) [lit., I shake my shoulderblade, and my shoulder-joint;] meaning, I walk with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait; I behave with pride and self-conceitedness. (Mgh.) And haz~a EiTofayohi lika*aA (tropical:) [lit., He shook his sides at such a thing app. meaning, he was active, or prompt, and brisk, or was moved with alacrity, to do such a thing, or he was rejoiced at such a thing: like ↓ Aihotaz~a lahu, q. v.]: and in like manner, haz~a manokibayohi. (A.) [In like manner also you say,] haz~a maA raA^ayotu mino EiTofaY [app. meaning, accord. to a gloss cited by De Sacy in his Anthol. Gr. Ar., p. 309, (tropical:) What I saw rejoiced me: or, as rendered by him, p. 286, ce dont j'étois temoin, réveilla en moi le courage.] (Z, in his preface to the Keshsháf.) And haz~a AlA_ibila, (S, A, K,) aor.
hazu3a , inf. n. haz~N (TA) and haziyzN, (S, K, TA,) (tropical:) He (a man urging his beasts by singing) made the camels to be brisk, or sprightly, by his singing to urge them. (S, * A, K.) And haz~ahaA Als~ayoru (tropical:) [The journeying made them to be brisk, or sprightly]. (TA.) And haz~a bihi Als~ayoru (assumed tropical:) The pace brought him on quickly. (TA.) And hazazotu fulaAnFA lixayorK (assumed tropical:) I made such a one to rejoice [or to be prompt and brisk (see the quasi-pass., 8,) to do good]: said of a generous man: (En-Nadr, TA:) and ↓ hazohazotuhu and hazohazotu minohu [app. signify the same]. (A.) And jaA='a fulaAnN yahuz~u Alma$oYa, and yahuD~uhu, (assumed tropical:) Such a one came walking impulsively: (JK in art. hD:) or with a graceful gait, impulsively. (Ibn-El-Faraj, TA, in art. hD.) ― -b3- You also say, of a plant, or herbage, Alr~iyaAHu waAlA^amoTaAru ↓ haz~atohu (tropical:) The winds and the rains made it to become tall. (A, TA. *) ― -b4- haz~a Alkawokabu: see 8. ― -b5- [mahaz~apN seems to be an inf. n. of haz~ahu.] You say rumoHN ladonu Almahaz~api (S, TA, art. ErS,) [app. for Einoda Almahaz~api] A spear that vibrates, or quivers, when shaken. (TA, ibid.)
2 haz~a3a see 1, in two places.
5 tahaz~a3a see 8.

8 Ahtz~ * , (inf. n. AihotizaAzN,) quasi-pass. of haz~ahu, (TA,) [It shook; or quivered;] it became in motion, or in a state of commotion; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ thz~z, (S, K,) quasi-pass. of hz~zhu; (TA;) and ↓ tahazohaza, (S, A, K,) [quasi-pass. of hazohazahu; meaning, accord. to explanations of haz~ahu in the TA, it became moved by being pulled and pushed; or it became moved to the right and left: or it became so moved with violence, or vehemence.] ― -b2- Ahtz~ AlmiaA='u fY jazoyihi (tropical:) [app. the water quivered in its running]: and Alkawokabu fiY A@noqiDaADihi (tropical:) [the star in its shooting, or darting, down]: (S, A, TA:) and Ahtz~ Alkawokabu (tropical:) the star shot, or darted, down [app. with a quivering motion]; (O, L, TA;) as also haz~a. (A, K.) ― -b3- Ahtz~ Almawokibu (tropical:) The procession, or cavalcade, went quickly: (En-Nadr, TA:) or made a noise and clamour. (S.) ― -b4- Ahtz~t AlA_ibilu (tropical:) The camels, being urged on by the singing of their driver, became brisk, or sprightly. (S, * A, TA.) You say also, Ahtz~ liA^amorK (tropical:) He was, or became, active, or prompt, and brisk, or cheerfully excited, at a thing, or to do a thing. (TA.) [Ex.] Ahtz~ lixayorK (tropical:) He rejoiced [or was active or prompt, &c., to do good]: said of a generous man. (En-Nadr, TA.) And huwa yahotaz~u lilomaEoruwfi (tropical:) [He rejoices, or is active, or prompt, &c., to do what is beneficent, or kind]. (A.) [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN laA yahotaz~u wal`kin~ahu yakutaz~u (tropical:) [Such a one does not rejoice, &c., to give, but he shrinks from giving]. (A, TA, art. kz.) [Hence also,] A_ihutaz~a Earo$u Alr~aHomaAni limawoti saEodK (tropical:) The empyrean of the Compassionate rejoiced at the death of Saad; (En-Nadr, IAth, K, TA;) meaning Saad Ibn-Mo'ádh; (TA;) i. e., when he [meaning his soul] was taken up; (IAth, TA;) because of the honour in which he was held by his Lord; (K;) or the inhabitants of the empyrean rejoiced at his death: these words occur in a trad., of which there is another relation, Ahtz~ AlEaro$u: and some say, that by AlEr$ is meant the bier upon which Saad was removed to his grave. (TA.) You also say, A_ilayohi qalobiY ↓ tahazohaza (tropical:) My heart became moved by a cheerful, or joyful, affection towards him. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Ahtz~ Aln~abaAtu (tropical:) The plant, or herbage, became tall. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Ahtz~t AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The land produced plants, or herbage: (A:) or became put in motion, and produced plants, or herbage. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 hazohazahu * , and hazohazotuhu, and hazohazotu minohu: see 1. ― -b2- Also, the first, (inf. n. hazohazapN, TA,) (tropical:) He subdued him, or rendered him submissive; syn *al~alahu. (K, * TA.)
R. Q. 2 tahazohaza * : see 8, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) He became subdued, or submissive; quasi-pass. of hazohazahu. (TA.)
haz~apN * (tropical:) Brisk and rejoicing to do evil or mischief; applied to a woman: pl. haz~aAtN. (A, TA.)

hiz~apN * (tropical:) Briskness, or sprightliness: (S, K:) and (tropical:) briskness, sprightliness, alacrity, or cheerfulness, disposing one to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, and beneficence; or liberality of disposition; syn. A^aroyaHiy~apN; (K;) and [in like manner] ↓ haziyzN (tropical:) briskness, or sprightliness, of camels when urged on by the singing of their driver. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A kind of pace, or manner of going, of camels; (As, K;) when the train goes quickly: (As, * En-Nadr, TA:) or a state of commotion of a train or procession or cavalcade: (ISd, TA.) or the confused sound thereof. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- (tropical:) The sound of the boiling of a cooking-pot: (S, K:) (assumed tropical:) the reiterating sound of thunder; as also ↓ haziyzN
(K:) which latter has likewise the following similar significations: (assumed tropical:) a sound, or noise; (K:) as, for instance, a sound, or noise, of turning of a mill; as also A^aziyz~a [inf. n. of A^az~a]: (TA:) and (tropical:) the murmuring of the wind (S, K) when it shakes the trees: (S:) or the sound of the blowing of the wind: (TA:) or the lightness of the wind, and the quickness of its blowing. (A, TA.)
haziyzN * : see hiz~apN.
hazaAy^izu * (assumed tropical:) Difficulties, afflictions, or calamities: [a pl.] having no singular. (Th, TA.)
kawokabN haAz~N * (tropical:) [A star shooting, or darting, down; or quivering in doing so: see 8]. (S, TA.)
hazohazapN * : see R. Q. 1, of which it is the inf. n.: and see hazaAhizu.

hazaAhizu * [app. pl. of hazohazapN] Seditions, or discords, or dissensions, (fitanN,) in which people are in a state of commotion: (S, Msb:) or wars and difficulties or afflictions or calamities that put into a state of commotion: (A:) or the excitement of commotion in men, by trials, or trying events, and by wars; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ hazohazapN. (K.)

1 hazaA^a minohu * , (K,) and bihi; (S, K;) and haziy^a (S, K) followed by mnh and bh; (Akh, S;) but accord. to Yoo, we should say hzy^ bh only; not mnh; (TA;) aor.
hazaAa , inf. n. huzo'N and huzuw^N (S, K) and huzuwo'N (TA) and mahozaA^apN; (S, K;) and bh ↓ thz~A^, (AZ, S, K,) and bh ↓ AsthzA^; (S, K;) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (S, K.) ― -b2- The most approved reading of ↓ musotahoziy^uwna in the Kur, ii. 13, is with the ' fully pronounced: some alleviate it: and some read musotahoziyurna: and some musotahozuwna; (but this pronunciation is of weak authority;) and say A_isotahozayotu for A_isotahozaA^otu. (Zj.) ― -b3- Als~araAbu yahozaA^u biAlr~akobi (tropical:) [The mirage mocks the company of riders]. (A.) -A2- hazaA^a, (K,) inf. n. hazo'N, (TA,) He, or it, broke a thing. (K.) ― -b2- A poet says, describing a coat of mail,
lahaA Eukano tarud~u Aln~abola xanosFA
watahozaA^u biAlomaEaAbili waAlqiTaAEi
[It has creases that repel the arrows, making them to recede, and break the broad and long arrow-heads, and those which are small and broad]. The b in bAlmEAbl is redundant. This is the opinion of the lexicologists, except ISd, who thinks that this is an error, and that thzA^ here means “ mocks. ” (TA.) -A3- hazaA^a A_ibilahu (K; but it is thought that this may be a mistake for haraA^a, TA,) inf. n. hazo'N; (TA;) and ↓ AhzA^ hA; (K;) He killed his camels with cold. IAar says, that AhzA^hu Albarodu and AhrA^hu both signify The cold killed him. (TA.) -A4- hazaA^a He put in motion, [or excited,) the beast on which he rode. (As, K.) -A5- hazaA^a and haziy^a He died (K) in his place, or on the spot; i. e. unexpectedly, or suddenly: (Z:) improperly objected against by Ibn-Es-Sáïgh. ('Ináyeh, MF.)

4 AhzA^ *
He entered upon the time of severe cold. (K.) See also AhrA^, which is the word commonly known. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1. -A2- AhzA^to bihi naAqatuhu His she-camel hastened with him. (K.)
5 tahaz~aAa see 1.
10 A_isotahozaAa see 1.
huzoA^apN * One who is mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided; a ridiculous person. (S, K.)
huzaA^apN * One who mocks at, scoffs at, laughs at, derides, or ridicules, others. (S, K.)
gadaApN haAziy^apN * (tropical:) A morning intensely cold: as though mocking men when they shrug and shiver. (A.)
mafaAzapN haAziy^apN biAlr~akobi * , and with huzaA^apN for hAzy^p, (tropical:) [A desert that mocks the company of riders]. (A.)

hawozabN * A camel strong in running; syn. qawiY~u AljaroYi: (K, and so in a copy of the S:) or a strong and bold camel; syn. qawiY~N jariY'N: (so in the S, in several copies): a strong camel: (ElJarmee:) a camel advanced in age, and bold. (As.) ― -b2- hawozabN A vulture, (K,) advanced in age. (TA.)

hayozabN *
Sharp; fierce; syn. HadiydN. ― -b2- lyovN hayozabu A sharp, or fierce, lion: (K, accord. to the TA:) or a strong lion. (CK.)
haAzibaY * and haAzibaA'u A kind of fish. (K.)

hizaborN * and hizobarN and huzaAbirN, (K,) or the first [only], (TA,) Thick and bulky: and strong and hard or hardy: pl. hazaAbiru. (K.) You say, naAqapN hizaborapN A hard, or hardy, she-camel. (IAar.) ― -b2- Also, the first, (S, K,) and the second and third, (Sgh, K,) The lion: (S, Sgh, K,) accord. to some, because of his thickness and bulkiness. (TA.) Some say that the h is a radical letter: others, that it is augmentative, and that the word is from zaborN, signifying the “ act of repelling with strength. ” (MF, TA.)

1 hazija * , aor.
hazaja , (S, K,) inf. n. hazajN; (L;) He sang in a certain manner, with trilling, or quavering; as also ↓ thz~j; (S, K;) and ↓ hz~j: (K:) or ↓ thz~j signifies he reiterated, or made to reciprocate, the graceful modulations of his voice: or prolonged his voice, without elevating it: (Aboo-Is-hák, L:) or hazajN does not at all signify trilling, or quavering; and therefore IAar has applied hazijN as an epithet to a dog that barks much. (L.) ― -b2- He read, or recited, with a prolonging and trilling of the voice, making the sounds to follow closely, one upon another; as also ↓ thz~j. (TA.)

2 hz~j AlS~awota * , inf. n. thoziyjN, He (a singer [or a reader or reciter]), made the sounds of the voice to be closely consecutive, and uttered in a light and quick manner. (L.) ― -b2- hz~j Sawotahu, and ↓ thz~jhu, [the latter app. a mistake for thz~j fiyhi,] He made the sounds of his voice to be closely consecutive, or near together. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1.

4 Ahzj *
He (a poet) composed, or uttered, verses of the metre termed Alhazaj. (K.)
5 thz~jt Alqawosu * (tropical:) The bow twanged, on the archer's loosing the string after drawing it. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- See 1, and 2.

[
hazajN * (tropical:) The twanging of a bow, on the archer's loosing the string after drawing it; and of a lutestring: in the TA, i. q. ran~pN: pl. A^ahozaAjN and pl. pl. A^ahaAziyju: or perhaps this latter is a pl. of which the sing. is ↓ A^uhozuwjapN, like as A^araAjiyzu is pl. of A^urojuwzapN: and the twanging of a bow-string or lute-string may be likened to an ode or a song of the metre termed Alhazaj, which is perhaps, judging from analogy, the proper signification of Ahzwjp.] liloEuwdi waAlqawosi A^ahaAziyju (tropical:) [To the lute and the bow there are twangings]. (A.) El-Kumeyt says, [speaking of a bow,]
lamo yaEibo rab~uhaA walaA Aln~aAsu minohaA
gayora A_ino*aArihaA Ealayohi AlHamiyraA
biA^ahaAziyja mino A^agaAniy~ihaA Alju$i
waA_itobaAEihaA Aln~aHiyba Alz~afiyraA
[Neither its owner nor the people imputed a fault to any of its properties, except its warning the (wild) asses of his presence by the twangings of its harsh singings, and its causing a groaning sound to follow the loud, or prolonged, wailing]. (S.) ― -b2- hazajN One of the modes of singing (AlA^agaAniY~), in which is a trilling, or quavering: (S, K:) pl. A^ahozaAjN. (L.) [But see 1.] ― -b3- A voice that excites lively emotions of joy or grief. (K.) ― -b4- A fine, or delicate, and elevated, voice. (TA.) ― -b5- A voice in which is hoarseness, or harshness. (K.) ― -b6- Any speech of which the component parts are closely consecutive, or near together, (K,) uttered in a light, or quick, manner: pl. as above. (L.) ― -b7-
AlhazajN The name of a certain kind of metre of verse; (S, K;) consisting of four feet, each of the measure mafaAEiyluno: originally of six feet, like the rajaz and the ramal, in each of which, [as in the hazaj,] each foot consists of one element of the kind termed watidN majomuwEN, and of two elements of the kind termed sababN xafiyfN: so called because of the mutual nearness of its component parts. (TA.) ― -b8- hazajN Lightness, or agility. (TA.) ― -b9- Quickness in the falling, and putting down, of the legs [upon the ground]. (TA.) ― -b10- (tropical:) The sound of thunder. (S.) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) The buzzing of flies. (L.)

hazijN * A singer [or reader or reciter] who prolongs his voice, with trilling, or quavering, making the sounds to follow close, one upon another. (A.) ― -b2- haziju AlEasiY~i, occurring in a verse of 'Antarah, cited voce daf~N, The cat that cries for food at supper-time: (EM, p. 233:) or the dog that barks much in the evening; meaning, in the night: or buzzing flies in the evening. (L.) ― -b3- hazijN A child, and a horse, whose legs fall, or are put down, quickly [upon the ground]. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Sounding thunder, as also ↓ mutahaz~aijN. (L.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A twanging lute [and bow]. (A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A cloud sounding with thunder. (A.) ― -b7- haziju AlS~awoti, and ↓ huzaAmijuhu, One who makes the sounds of his voice to follow close, one upon another. (L.)

hazomajapN *
Uninterrupted speech or language. (K.) ― -b2- Confusion of voice or sound beyond measure; (K;) as also hazolajapN. (K, TA, art. hzlj.) ― -b3- [The m is an augmentative letter: see huzaAmijN.]

huzaAmijN * A voice, or the like, of which the sounds are closely consecutive. The m is an augmentative letter. (S, K.) ― -b2- SawotN huzaAmijN A confused voice or sound. The sound so called is less than what is termed rugaA='N. (L.) ― -b3- [See also hazjN.]
A^uhozuwjapN * : see hazajN.
mutahaz~ijN * : see hazijN.

div1.div2:
hzr [See Supplement.]
hazaArN * [The nightingale;] a certain bird, (K. TA,) the same that is called EanodaliybN, (S, K, art. Endlb,) of sweet voice; improperly said in the K to be what is called in Persian hazaAro dasotaAno; for hzAr itself is Persian, and signifies “ a thousand, ” and daAsotaAno means [as also dasotaAno in that language] “ a tale; ” as though this bird, in the sweetness of its warbling and the pleasantness of its melody, told a thousand tales; being thus called by way of hyperbole and excessive praise: then they contented themselves by employing the word hzAr alone; and the Arabs used it, and prefixed to it the article Al: (TA:) the pl. is hazaAraAtN. (Msb.)

div2.entryFree: Q. 1 hazoraba * , inf. n. hazorabapN, He was light, or active, and quick, or swift. (IKtt, K.) A dial. form. of ha*oraba. (TA.)

Q. 1 hazolaja * , inf. n. hazolajapN, He (an ostrich, or anything,) was quick, or swift. (TA.)
hazolajapN * : see 1; and art. hzj.
hazal~ajN * A quick, or swift, he-ostrich. (K.)

hizolaAjN *
Quick, or swift: (TA:) a light, or an agile, (and swift, or quick, TA,) wolf: (S, K:) pl. hazaAliju and hazaAliyju. (TA.) Accord. to Kr, it is derived from Alhazaju. (TA.) [See hzomajapN in art. hzj.]
See Supplement
hazomajapN * and huzaAmiju: see art. hzj.

hasobN *
Sufficiency; like HasobN. (K.)

div2.head: hsd, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 ha$~a * , aor. yahi$~u; (JK, TA;) or ha$~a, secpers. ha$i$ota, aor. yaha$~u; (Msb;) inf. n. ha$aA$apN (JK, A, Msb, TA) [and hu$uw$apN and hu$uw$N and ha$~N, as appears from what follows]; It, (a thing) was, or became, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; (JK, A, Msb, TA;) syn. kaAna fiyhi raxaAwapN, (JK,) or kaAna rixowFA lay~inFA, (A, * TA,) or laAna waA@sotaroxaY. (Msb.) You say, ha$~a Alxubozu, aor.
ha$i3a , (S, K,) inf. n. hu$uw$apN (K) and ha$~N, (TA,) meaning, SAr ha$~FA; (S, K;) i. e., The bread became [soft, &c., or] easy to break. (TA.) And ha$~a AlEuwdu, (IAar, Msb,) aor. [
ha$i3a , or]
ha$a3a , (Msb,) inf. n. hu$uw$N, (IAar, Msb,) The wood, or stick, broke in pieces: (IAar:) or became easily or quickly broken. (Msb.) And ha$~ati Al$~ajarapu, inf. n. ha$~N, The tree dropped its leaves, one after another. (Msb [in which it seems to be indicated that the aor. of the verb in this sense is
ha$u3a ; but this is contr. to rule in an intrans. verb of this class; and I think it improbable.]) ― -b2- ha$~a, inf. n. hu$uw$apN, (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became weak; unable to endure difficulty or distress. (TA.) And ha$~a, aor.
ha$i3a , (assumed tropical:) He affected languor, or languidness; syn. takas~ara: and he became old, or aged. (TA.) -A2- ha$~a, (Msb, K,) first pers. ha$i$otu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaha$~u; (Msb, K,) and ha$~a, first pers. ha$a$otu, aor. yahi$~u; (Msb, K;) inf. n. ha$aA$apN (S, Msb, K) and ha$aA$N; (A, K;) (tropical:) He was, or became, cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (S, K:) or he smiled, and was, or became cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Msb.) You say, ha$i$otu bifulaAnK, (S, TA,) and ha$a$otu bihi, (TA,) (tropical:) I was, or became, cheerful, &c. in behaviour towards such a one: (S:) or I was, or became cheerful in countenance, or joyful, or pleased, at meeting with such a one. (TA.) And huwa yaha$~u A_ilaY A_ixowaAnihi, (tropical:) He is cheerful, &c., towards his brethren]. (A.) And biY ↓ daxalotu Ealayohi faA@hota$~a (tropical:) [I went in to him, and he was cheerful, &c., in his behaviour towards me]; like A_ihotaz~a lY. (A, * TA.) And ha$i$otu lilomaEoruwfi, (JK, TA, *) and ha$a$otu, (TA,) inf. n. ha$aA$apN (S) and ha$aA$N, (A,) (tropical:) I was, or became, cheerful, brisk, &c., to do what was kind, or beneficent: (S, * TA:) or I desired to do it: (JK:) and ↓ A_ihota$a$otu llmErwf I was, or became, cheerful, &c., and desirous, to do what was kind, or beneficent. (TA.) And huwa *uw ha$aA$K A_ilaY Alxayori (tropical:) [He possesses cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, of disposition to do good]. (A.) Accord. to Sh, ha$i$otu signifies (assumed tropical:) He rejoiced, and desired; or was, or became, joyful, and desirous. (TA.) And the phrase ha$i$otu A_ilaY A@moraA^atiY, if correct, means either (assumed tropical:) I inclined towards my wife, or I was, or became, brisk, or sprightly, in disposition towards her. (Mgh.) And accord to ISd, ha$aA$u Alqawomi [so in the TA, but accord. to the JK ha$aAhi$u,] (assumed tropical:) The people's being in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.) -A3- ha$~a Alwaraqa, aor.
ha$u3a , (S, A, K,) and
ha$i3a , (Sgh, K,) inf. n. ha$~N, (S,) He beat the leaves with a staff, or stick, in order that they might fall; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ ha$oha$ahu. (Z, TA.) It is said in the Kur, [xx. 19,] (S,) waA^ahu$~u bihaA EalaY ganamiY [And I beat the leaves with it in order that they may fall upon my sheep, or goats]: (S, A:) or, accord. to Fr, and I beat the dry trees with it in order that their leaves may fall so that my sheep, or goats, may feed upon them; and so says As: (TA:) Lth says, that Alha$~u signifies thy drawing towards thee a branch of a tree: and also, thy scattering its leaves towards thee with a staff, or stick: (JK, * TA:) but Az says, that the correct ex-
planation is that given by Fr and As; not the former of the two explanations given by Lth. (TA.) [The verb also seems to have a similar application in a more extended sense; for it is said that] ha$~a, aor.
ha$u3a , inf. n. ha$~N, signifies He (a man) assaulted (SaAla) with his staff, or stick. (Msb.) You say also, ha$~a Alha$iyma He broke in pieces the dry herbage or the like. (TA.)

2 h$~$hu * , (JK, K,) inf. n. taho$iy$N, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He deemed him, or reckoned him, weak, or feeble, (JK, K, *) and soft, or gentle. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) He, or it, rendered him brisk, lively, or sprightly; and joyful, glad, or happy: (K:) and ↓ Asth$~hu (tropical:) it (a thing, JK, TA) incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness or sprightliness; syn. A_isotaxaf~ahu. (JK, K, TA.) You say, ↓ fulaAnN maA yasotahi$~uhu Aln~aEiymu (tropical:) [Such a one, weal, or welfare, does not excite him to briskness, &c.] (A, TA.)

8 Aht$~ *
He was, or became, cheerful, &c.: see 1, in two places.
10 A_isotaho$a3a see 2, in two places.
R. Q. 1 ha$oha$ahu * : see 1, latter part. ― -b2- He moved, or put in motion, or into a state of commotion, him, or it. (IDrd, K.)

ha$~N * A thing, (S, Msb,) or anything, (JK,) soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; (JK, * S, * A, * Msb, K, * TA;) syn. rixowN lay~inN; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ ha$iy$N. (JK, S, K.) You say, xubozN ha$~N, (S, K,) and ↓ ha$aA$N, (K,) Bread that is [soft, &c., or] easy to break. (TA.) And xubozapN ha$~apN A lump of dough, baked in a fire in the ground, that is dry, or hard: asserted by IKtt to have two contr. significations. (TA.) [But to this assertion it may be replied, that dry bread is easy to break.] And in like manner, A^utoruj~apN ha$~apN A citron easy to break: or dry, or hard. (TA.) And EuwdN ha$~N Wood, or a stick, that is easily, or quickly broken. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa ha$~N Almakosiri, (JK, S, A, K,) or Almakosari, (TA, [but this is contr. to all the other authorities that I know,]) and Almukas~ari, (TA,) (tropical:) He is easy, or compliant, when asked: (A:) or he is of easy nature, or disposition, (JK, S, K,) with respect to what is sought, or demanded, of him, of things needed: (S:) said in praise of a man (S, TA) when it means [lit.] that he is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; but said in dispraise of a man when it means [lit.] that he is one whose wood is weak. (TA.) [And in like manner] ↓ ha$iy$N (K) and ↓ haA$~N (TA) signify (tropical:) One who rejoices, or is glad, when asked. (K, TA.) You say, ↓ huwa haA$N Einoda Als~uw^aAli, and ↓ ha$iy$N, (tropical:) He is one who rejoices, or is glad, at being asked. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] rajulN ha$~N, (TA,) or rajulN ha$~N A_ilaY A_ixowaAnihi, and ↓ haA$~N, (JK,) (tropical:) A man who is cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his behaviour towards his brethren. (JK, TA.) And rajulN ha$~N ba$~N (tropical:) A man who is cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (S:) or cheerful in countenance; pleasant [therein]. (S, TA in art. b$.) And A^anaA bihi ha$~N ba$~N (tropical:) I am cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in behaviour towards him; (K;) joyful; happy. (TA.) And rajulN ha$~N fuw^aAduhu (tropical:) A man quick, or prompt, to do good. (As.) And fara$N ha$~u AlEinaAni (assumed tropical:) [A horse that is brisk, lively, or sprightly; lit.,] light of rein. (TA.) And farasN ha$~N (tropical:) A horse that sweats much; (JK, IF, K;) contr. of SaluwdN; (S;) or not Slwd. (A.)
ha$uA$N * : see ha$~N, second sentence.
ha$uw$N * (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, abounding with milk. (S, K.)

ha$iy$N *
Dry herbage, syn. ha$iymN, (K, TA,) for the horses of the people of AlA^asoyaAf [app. meaning the shores of 'Omán] in particular. (TA.) -A2- See also ha$~N, in three places. ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) A man who is niggardly towards his family, or others, with respect to food; syn. muHotirN. (TA.) [Thus it bears two contr. significations.]
ha$iy$apN * is thought by ISd to signify Leaves [app. beaten from a tree]. (TA.)

qirobapN ha$~aA$apN *
A water-skin from which the water flows by reason of its thinness. (K.)
ha$oha$apN * (assumed tropical:) Motion; or commotion. (JK.) [ha$aAhi$u is app. its pl.: see 1, next before ha$~a Alwaraqa.]
ha$ohaA$N * (tropical:) Good in disposition; liberal, or bountiful. (IAar, K.)
haA$~N * : see ha$~N, in three places.
muha$ohi$apN * , in the copies of the K erroneously written mutaha$ohi$ap, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A woman who manifests love to her husband, and rejoices in him. (K, * TA.)

div2.head: h$r, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haSaba * , aor.
haSuba , inf. n. haSobN, He fled; ran away. (K.)

1 haSarahu * , (S, A, K,) and haSara bihi, (S, K,) aor.
haSira , (K,) inf. n. haSorN, (A, K,) He pulled it: and he inclined it: or he pulled and inclined it: (A, K, TA [but in the last of these, only haSarahu is given in this sense, agreeably with the A:]) he brought it near; (K;) which is near in meaning to “ he inclined it: ” (TA:) he took hold of its (a branch's) head and inclined it towards him: (S:) or he inclined it (a branch) towards him: (A:) or he bent it (a branch) and drew it towards him: (Mgh:) he bent it; namely, a pliant thing, such as a branch and the like: (A, K:) and he broke it without separating: (K:) or he bent it, namely, anything: (A, * K:) as also ↓ AhtSrhu. (K.) Imra-el-Keys says, (S, TA,) using the verb tropically, (TA,)
falam~aA tanaAzaEonaA AlHadiyva waA^asomaHato
haSarotu biguSonK *iY $amaAriyxa may~aAli
And when we discoursed together, and she became compliant, I pulled, (TA,) or, laying hold of its head, inclined towards me, (S,) a branch with fruit-stalks, waving from side to side: the poet meaning, by the branch, her body, because bending, and soft or supple, like a branch, and likening her hair to the fruit-stalks of the raceme of a palm-tree, in respect of its abundance and luxuriance. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the building of the mosque of Kubà, rafaEa HajarFA vaqiylFA fahaSarahu A_ilaY baTonihi He raised a heavy stone, and inclined it towards his belly. (TA.) And in another trad., kaAna A_i*aA rakaEa haSara Zahorahu He used, when he bowed himself [in prayer], to bend down his back towards the ground: (TA:) or haSara Zahorahu signifies he bent his back much, making it even with his neck. (Mgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He pushed him or it; so accord. to all the copies of the K; but accord. to other authorities, (tropical:) he pressed or squeezed, him or it: and he pressed, or squeezed, him or it vehemently. (TA.) You say, haSara qironahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He pressed, or squeezed, his adversary. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or haSarahu [alone], (S,) (assumed tropical:) He broke it; (S, K;) as also ↓ AhtSrhu. (S.) You say of a lion, haSara Alfariysapa, (A, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He broke [the neck of] the prey, and inclined it towards him. (TA.) And haSara raA^osa Alfariysapi, and biraA^osihaA, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He [broke the head of, or] slew the prey. (TA.) -A2- haSira jad~uhu, aor.
haSara , [inf. n. haSarN,] (tropical:) His good fortune declined. (TA.)
5 tahaS~ara see 7.

7 AnhSr * and ↓ AhtSr It became pulled: and it became inclined: or it became pulled and inclined: it was brought near: it (a pliant thing, such as a branch and the like,) bent: it broke, without separating: or it (anything) bent: (K:) or it (a branch) inclined and bent: (TA:) or fell upon the ground: (AHn, TA:) and ↓ thS~r it (a branch)
hung down, or was pendent. (TA.) [It seems to be implied in the K that AnhSr and ↓ AhtSr are quasi-passives of haSarahu in all its senses.]
8 AhtSr * : see 7. -A2- AhtSrhu: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AhtSr Aln~axolapa He placed the racemes of the palm-tree upon the branches, and put them straight or even. (T, K.)

haSirN * (tropical:) A man who presses, or squeezes, vehemently; as also ↓ huSarN. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The lion; as also ↓ huSarN and ↓ huSarapN (K) and ↓ haSuwrN (S, K) and ↓ haSowarN and ↓ haSaworapN (K) and ↓ haS~aArN (S, K) and ↓ haASirN (K) and ↓ hayoSarN (S, K [in the CK ↓ hayoSuwrN]) and ↓ hayoSaArN and ↓ mihoSarN and ↓ mihoSaArN and ↓ mihoSiyrN and ↓ muhotaSirq: (K:) or haSuwrN is an epithet applied to a lion, (A, TA,) as also ↓ haS~aArN and ↓ hayoSarN [&c.], (A,) signifying, that slays and breaks: (TA:) pl. [of haASirN] hawaASiru and [poeticè] hawaASiyru. (TA.) -A2- jad~N haSirN (tropical:) Declining good fortune. (TA.)
huSarN * : see haSirN.
huSarapN * : see haSirN.
haSuwrN * : see haSirN.
haSowarN * : see haSirN.
haSuwrapN * : see haSirN.
haS~aArN * : see haSirN.
haASirN * : see haSirN.
hayoSarN * : see haSirN.
hayoSaArN * : see haSirN.
hayoSuwrN * : see haSirN.
mihoSarN * : see haSirN.
mihoSaArN * : see haSirN.
mihoSiyrN * : see haSirN.
muhotaSirN * : see haSirN.

div2.head: hSm, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haD~ahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
haDu3a , (S,) inf. n. haD~N, (TA,) He broke it; as also ↓ AhtD~hu; (S, K;) and ↓ haDohaDahu; (K;) inf. n. haDohaDapN. (TA:) and the first, (S, A,) or ↓ all, (K,) he bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it; (S, K;) i. q. raD~ahu; i. e. a stone, &c.: (A:) or he broke it in a manner falling short of what is termed had~N, [in the CK, incorrectly Had~,] but exceeding what is termed raD~N: (Lth, K:) or, accord. to some, the first, he broke it leisurely, or gently: and the ↓ last, he broke it hastily. (TA.) You say, AlfaHolu yahuD~u A^aEonaAqa AlfuHuwli (S, A) The stallion breaks, or crushes, the necks of the [other] stallions; as also ↓ yuhaDohiDuhaA. (TA.) And AlA_ibilu yahuD~u AlA^aroDa The camels bruise the ground. (L.) ― -b2- Also, haD~ati AlA_ibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels hastened, or went quickly. (K.) And jaA='ati AlA_ibilu tahuD~u Als~ayora, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The camels came hastening, or quickly. (TA.) And jaA='a fulaAnN yahuD~u Alma$oYa, (Ibn-El-Faraj, JK, K, *) and yahuz~uhu, (Ibn-El-Faraj, JK,) (assumed tropical:) Such a one came walking impulsively: (JK:) or with a graceful gait, (Ibn-El-Faraj, K,) impulsively. (Ibn-El Faraj.) -A2- haD~a is also syn. with HaD~a. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

2 hD~D *
He bruised the ground vehemently with his feet. (TA.)

7 AnhD~ *
It broke, or became broken: (S, K:) it became bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: (S:) quasi-pass. of haD~ahu and AhtD~hu. (TA.)

8 A_ihotaDa3a see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AhotaDaDotu nafosiY lifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I held myself to have fallen short of my duty to such a one; syn. A_isotazadotuhaA. (JK, S, K [in one copy of the S, A_isotaro*alotuhaA.]) ― -b3- A_ihotaDaDotu mino fulaAnK $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) I took from such a one a thing. (JK.)
R. Q. 1 haDohaDahu * : see 1, in three places.

haD~aA='u *
A company (S, K) of men; of the measure faEolaA='u, like SaHoraA='u; mentioned by Th; (S;) and by As; (TA;) or a company of horses, or horsemen: (A, TA:) and a [troop of horse such as is termed] katiybap: because they break things. (TA.)
haDiyDN * A thing (S) broken: bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: as also ↓ mahoDuwDN, (S, K,) and ↓ munohaD~N. (S.)

haDaADapN * , like saHaAbapN, (K,) or huDaADapN, (so in the JK,) (assumed tropical:) What is taken (maA yuhotaD~u [in the CK, erroneously, yahotaD~u,]) from any one. (JK [where it immediately follows the phrase A_ihotaDaDotu mino fulaAnK $ayoy^FA explained as above], Sgh, K.)

faHolN haD~aADN *
A stallion that breaks, or crushes, the necks of the [other] stallions; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ haDohaADN: (JK, K:) or a stallion that throws down a man, and a camel, then leans, bears, or presses, upon him with his breast. (IDrd.)
haDohaADN * : see what next precedes.
mahoDuwDN * : see haDiyDN.
munohaD~N * : see haDiyDN.

muhaDohiDapN * (tropical:) A woman (TA) who annoys, or molests, her fellow-wife or female neighbour, or her fellow-wives or female neighbours: (so accord. to different copies of the K:) transmitted by Sgh. (TA.)

1 haDabati Als~amaA'u * , aor.
haDiba , The sky rained: (K:) or rained for some days incessently. (TA.) See haDobapN. ― -b2- haDabatohumu Als~amaA'u The sky rained upon them: (S:) it wetted them much. (TA.) ― -b3- yahoDibu biAl$~iEori wabiAlxuTabi (tropical:) He pours forth verses, and discourses in rhyming prose, or the like. (A.) ― -b4- haDaba fiY AlHadiyvi and ↓ AhtDb, (S, K,) and ↓ AhDb (K, but omitted in the TA,) (assumed tropical:) He launched into discourse, (S, K,) and talked much, or launched into discourse time after time, (TA,) and raised his voice. (S, TA.) ― -b5- AihoDibuwA yaA qawom Talk, or speak, O people. (S.) ― -b6- haDaba and ↓ AhDb He talked loud. (AA.) -A2- haDaba He (a man) walked in the manner of a stupid, dull, unexcitable person. (K.) -A3- haDaba Alqawomu: see Dahaba, and haADibN.
4 A^ahoDaba see 1.
8 A_ihotaDaba see 1. -A2- AhtDb It (the vibrating of a bow-string) produced a twanging. (TA.)

10 AsthDb *
It became what is termed haDob, (K,) or haDobap; (A;) i. e. a mountain of the kind so termed. (A.)

haDobN *
A kind, mode, or way. A. Heyth quotes the following verse of El-Kumeyt, describing a horse:
muxay~afN baEoDuhu warodN wasaAy^iruhu
jawonN A^afaAniynu A_ijoriy~aAhu laA haDobu
The poet means, that his running, or usual running, was of different, or various, kinds; not of one hDb, or kind. (L.) -A2- See haDobapN.
haDabN * : see haDobapN.

haDobapN *
A rain: (S, K:) or a rain consisting of many drops: (IAth:) or a lasting rain, consisting of great drops: or a single fall thereof: (TA:) or hard rain: (Msb:) pl. hiDabN, (S, K,) like bidarN pl. of badorapN, (S,) extr. [with respect to rule], (TA,) and hiDaAbN, (K,) or this is pl. of haDobN accord. to the S; (TA;) and pl. pl. A^ahaADiybu; (K;) or this is pl. of hiDaAbN, which is pl. of ↓ haDobN, signifying fine showers of rain after other rain; syn. HalabaAtu qaTorK baEoda qaTorK; (AZ, S;) and this is what is correct: (TA:) or ↓ haDobN signifies a fine rain; or a fine shower of rain; syn. Halobapu qaTorK: it is also said, in the L, that ↓ A^uhoDuwbapN is syn. with haDobN, [either in one of the last two senses, or as a coll. gen. n. of which haDobapN is the n. un., which it is said to be below,] and that AhADyb is its pl.: ↓ huDuwbapN also is the same as AhDwbp: so in the phrase A^aSaAbatohumu AlhDwbpu mina AlmaTari [The fine shower, or showers, of rain
(or the shower of rain, or of copious rain, or of lasting rain consisting of large drops, or hard rain,) fell upon them]; mentioned in the K: it is also said in the L, that haDobN forms in the pl. A^ahoDaAbN, and then A^ahaADiybu; like as qawolN forms A^aqowaAlN, and then A^aqaAwiylu.
