(TA.) ↓ haDobN is also said to be a pl. of haDobapN; but it is rather a coll. gen. n., [of which haDobapN is the n. un.]: and haDabN is also added to the list of the pls. of the same word; but this, accord. to the S, on the authority of AA, is pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of haADibN, [act. part. n. of 1,] like as tabaEN is of taAbiEN, and baEadN of baAEidN. (TA.) -A2- haDobapN A hill; (IAth:) or a mountain spreading over the surface of the ground: (S, Msb, K:) or a mountain composed of one mass of rock: (K:) or any firm, hard, large mass of rock: (TA:) or a long inaccessible mountain, separate from others; but only of red mountains: (K:) or a hill, such as is termed A^akamap, with few plants, or little herbage: (Msb:) pl. hiDabN and hiDaAbN; (S, K;) and pl. pl. A^ahaADiybu. (K, TA.) A^ahaADibu is used, by poetical licence, for AhADyb, in a poem of one of the Hudhalees: (TA:) [or it is pl. of A^ahoDubN, which is pl. of pauc. of haDobN]. haDobN is also said, in the S, and L, to be a pl. of haDobapN; but it is rather a coll. gen. n. (TA.) ― -b2- An elevated, or overlooking, tract of sand. (TA, art. Twd.) -A3- (assumed tropical:) A run; a single run. (AHeyth.)

hiDab~N * (tropical:) A horse sweating much; or that sweats much. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hard, or firm, and strong, or robust. (K.) ― -b3- Large, or bulky; as an epithet applied to the kind of lizard called Dab~, and to other things. (TA.)

ganamN haDiybN *
Sheep or goats having little milk: (K:) app. form AlhaDobu, signifying Halobapu AlqaTori. (TA.)
huDuwbapN * : see haDobapN.

haADibN * , used after the manner of a rel. n., signifying *uw haDobK: so in the following expression in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee; fiY yawomK mina All~ahowi haADibKi; which means In a day when the people had played much, and quickly: explained by the words kaAnuwA qado haDabuwA fiY All~ahowi. (TA.)
A^uhoDuwbapN * : see haDobapN.
rawoDapN mahoDuwbapN * [A meadow, or the like, rained upon: or much wetted by rain]. (TA.)

div2.head: hDl &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 hafata * , aor.
hafita , inf. n. hafotN; (TA;) and ↓ thAft; (S, K;) It fell continuously, or successively, (S, K,) part by part, (S,) or part after part, like as snow, or fine rain, falls. (TA.) ↓ thAft is mostly used with reference to something evil; (TA;) [as] yatahaAfatuwna fiY Aln~aAri [They shall fall successively into the fire of hell]; (TA, from a trad.;) [and] tahaAfata AlfaraA$u fiY Aln~aAri The moths fell successively into the fire; (S;) [and] tahaAfaba Alqawomu The people fell down successively dead; (TA;) [and] tahaAfatuwA Ealayohi They fell upon him successively. (TA.) ― -b2- hafata and ↓ tahaAfata It (snow, and fine rain,) fell quickly. (TA.) ― -b3- hafata, [aor.
hafita ,] inf. n. hafotN, He, or it, fell; fell down. (TA.) ― -b4- hafata, aor.
hafita , (S, K,) inf. n. hafotN and hufaAtN; (TA;) and ↓ Anhft; (S;) It was, or became, depressed, or lowered; syn. A_inoxafaDa and A_it~aDaEa. (S, K.) ― -b5- hafata and ↓ Anhft It was, or became, lessened, or diminished. (IKtt.) ― -b6- hafata, (aor.
hafita , inf. n. hafotN, TA,) It became minute, fine, or slender; syn. daq~a. (K.) ― -b7- hafata, (aor.
hafita , K,) inf. n. hafotN and hufaAtN, It flew about, or became dispersed, by reason of its lightness. (S, K.) ― -b8- hafata, aor.
hafita , He talked much, without consideration. (K, TA.)

6 thAft *
It (a garment) fell in pieces, piece after piece falling off, and became worn out. (TA.) ― -b2- thAft It was continuous, or successive; syn. tataAbaEa. (K.) -A2- See also 1. ― -b2- thAft Aln~aAsu EalaY AlmaA'i The people pressed, or crowded, to the water, [one after another, or party after party]. (Msb.)
7 A_inohafata see 1.

hafotN * Rain falling quickly. (K.) ― -b2- A depressed, or low, piece of ground: (K:) like hajolN. (Az.) -A2- kalaAmN hafotN Inconsiderate loquacity. (TA.) ― -b2- hafotN Abundant stupidity: (K:) surpassing stupidity. (IAar.)

hafaAtN *
Stupid; foolish; of little sense. (S, K.) [But see its syn. lafaAtN, voce A^alofatu.] Authorities differ respecting this word and lafaAtN, whether they should be written with t or with p or with both. (TA.)

Hab~N hafuwtN *
Grain that falls to the bottom of the cooking-pot, and swells out quickly. (Lth.)

waradato hafiytapN mina Aln~aAsi *
There came a party of men whom a year of drought had compelled to emigrate. (S.)

mahofuwtN *
Confounded; perplexed; amazed: (K:) like mahobuwtN. (TA.)

div2.head: hfw &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

haqobN *
Width; amplitude; largeness. (K.)

hiqabo *
A word by which a horse is checked, or urged. (K.

hiqab~N *
Having a large, or ample, throat, (K,) swallowing everything. (TA.) ― -b2- Large, big, or bulky, and tall, or long; an epithet applied to an ostrich, (Lth, K,) and to other things: (K:) or long, or tall, as an epithet applied to other things than the ostrich. (TA.)

haqaboqabN *
Hard, or firm, and strong, or robust. (K.)

div2.head: hqE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haliba * , aor.
halaba , inf. n. halabN, He had much hair [of the kind termed hulob]; was very hairy. (K.) ― -b2- halaba *anaba Alfarasi, and halaba Alfarasa, aor.
haluba , inf. n. halobN, He shore the tail of the horse: (Msb:) shore it, or cut it off, utterly. (TA.) halabahu; (S, K;) and ↓ hl~bh, (K,) inf. n. taholiybN; (TA;) He plucked from him (i. e. a horse, S,) his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b3- huliba It (a tail) was entirely cut off. (TA.) -A2- halabahumo bilisaAnihi, aor.
haliba ; and ↓ hl~bhm, (inf. n. taholiybN, TA;) (tropical:) He satirized and reviled them: (K:) he carped at them severely with his tongue. (TA.) -A3- halaba, aor.
haluba ; and ↓ Ahlb, (inf. n. A_iholaAbN, TA) ; He (a horse) prosecuted, or continued, his course, or run, uninterruptedly; syn. taAbaEa AljaroYa: (K:) and, the latter verb, he (a horse,) was ardent, or impetuous, in his course, or running; as also A^alohaba. (As, in TA, art. lhb.) [See also Dahba Alqawomu] -A4- halabati Als~amaA'u Alqawoma The sky wetted the people with dew (nadFY): or, with continual rain. (K.) halabatonaA Als~amaA'u The sky wetted us with dew (ndY) or the like; (TA;) as also ↓ A^aholabatonaA: (T:) the sky rained upon us a copious, or an excellent, rain. (TA.)
2 hal~aba see 1.
4 A^aholaba see 1.
5 thl~b * and ↓ Anhlb [He, a horse, had his tail shorn: see 1:] he had his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail &c.,] plucked out. (K.)
7 A_inohalaba see 5.

8 Ahtlb *
He drew a sword from its scabbard. (TA.)

hulobN * , [a coll. gen. n.,] Hair, absolutely: or coarse hair; (K;) as the hair of the tail of a she-camel: (Az:) or hair of the tail: or pigs' bristles, with which skins and the like are sewed: (K:) J gives this last signification to ↓ hulobapN: and also, coarse hair of the tail &c.: (so in the S:) but hulobapN is the n. un. (TA.) ― -b2- hulobN, The eyelashes. (TA.) ― -b3- hulobN, call. gen. n., Hair
that one plucks from the tail: n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b4- hulabN [pl. of hulobapN] Tails and manes plucked out. (TA.) -A2- hulobN Continuance, or constant succession, of rain. (TA.)
rajulN halib * [A man having much hair; of the kind called hulob; very hairy: see haliba:] a man whose hulob is growing forth. (TA.)

hulobapN * The hair that is above the pubes, extending near to the navel. (TA.) See hulobN. -A2- hulobapN Severity, or pressure, of fortune: like kulobapN and julobapN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ hulub~apN, Severity, or intenseness, of winter. (K.) A^atayotuhu fiY hlbpi Al$~itaA'i I came to him during the severe, or intense, cold of winter. (El-Umawee.)
hulub~apN * : see hulobapN.

haluwbN * A woman who draws near to her husband, or ingratiates herself with him; syn. mutaqar~ibapN mino zawojihaA; (K, TA;) and is loving, or affectionate, to him; and distant with respect to others. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, contr., A woman who is distant, or shy, with respect to her husband, or who alienates herself from him, or avoids or shuns him, (K,) and draws near to, or ingratiates herself with, her special friend. (TA.) ― -b3- From halabahu bilisaAnihi “ he carped at him severely with his tongue; ” because a wife carps either at her husband or at her friend: or, accord. to IAar, in the former sense, from ↓ yawomN hal~aAbN “ a day of gentle, constant, innocuous rain; ” and in the latter sense from the same phrase as signifying “ a day of rain attended by thunder and lightning and terrors, and destructive to dwellings. ” (TA.)
haliybN * and hulayobN: see hal~aAbN.

hulaAbapN * The filth that is washed away from the membrane which encloses the fœtus: (K:) i. q. HuwalaA'u: [a word which has two applications, which see:] also called hulaAbapu AlsqA': (TA:) [but AlsqA' is written by mistake for Als~iqoYi]. [See also hulaAtapN.]

hal~aAbN * (K) and hal~aAbapN (S, K) A cold wind, with rain. (S, ISd, K.) ― -b2- yawomN hal~aAbN A day in which is wind and rain: (S:) a day of rain attended by thunder and lightning and terrors, and destructive to dwellings. (IAar.) ― -b3- Also, A day of gentle, constant, innocuous rain. (IAar.) ― -b4- Also, A day of dry cold; or dry by reason of cold. (Az, in the T, art. Hlb.) ― -b5- EaAmN hal~aAbN, and ↓ A^aholabu, A year of much rain. (K.) ― -b6- ↓ EAm A^aholabu (tropical:) A plentiful, or fruitful, year; a year of abundant herbage, or vegetation: like A^azab~u. (S.) ― -b7- hal~aAbN and ↓ muhal~ibN and ↓ haliybN, (K,) or as in one copy of the K, that of Et-Tabláwee, the last is ↓ hulayobN, (TA,) and this is the more correct reading, (MF,) [Three] very cold days, in Kánoon el-'Owwal [or January O. S.]: or in the severe, or intense, cold of winter: (K:) or in the severe, or intense, cold of the month [above mentioned], in the latter part of it. (L.) -A2- hal~aAbN (tropical:) One who satirizes [and reviles] much: (ISh:) [who carps much and severely at others with his tongue: see 1].
haAlibu Al$~aEori * and mudaHoriju AlbaEori [Two] days of winter. (K.) ― -b2- See art. dHrj ― -b3- layolapN haAlibapN A rainy night. (K.)

A^aholabu *
Having much hair [of the kind called hulob]; very hairy: (K:) fem. halobaA'u. (CK.) A horse having much hair of the kind called hlb: (S:) a coarse-haired man: (TA:) a man having coarse hair upon the part where are the two veins called AlA^axodaEaAni, and upon his body: (TA:) having much hair upon the head and body. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aholabu A tail cut off. (K.) ― -b3- Also, [accord. to the CK, or,] Having no hair upon it: and, contr., Having much hair: (K:) [in each sense, as seems to be implied in the K, an epithet applied to a tail: but, app., accord. to the TA, applied to a horse]. ― -b4- halobaA'u, fem., A beast of carriage (TA) having much hair. (K, TA.) ― -b5- halobaA'u The podex; syn. A_isotN: (K:) used as a subst.; originally an epithet. (TA.) ― -b6- A_iy~aAka waA^aholaba AlEaDoraTi Beware of him who has a hairy podex. Originally said by a woman to her son, who was boasting that he found no one whom he did not overcome, and who was afterwards thrown down by a man answering to this description. A proverb used in cautioning the self-conceited. (Meyd, TA.) ― -b7- A^aroDN halobaA'u (tropical:) Land abounding with plants, or herbage. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, [contr.,] (tropical:) Land of which the herbage has been eaten. (TA.) ― -b9- hulobapN halobaA'u (in the CK, halobapN hulobaA'u) A severe calamity. (K.) ― -b10- See hal~aAbN.

lahu A^uholuwbN *
He [a horse] has ardour, or impetuosity, in his running &c.: formed by transposition from, or a dial. form of, A^ulohuwbN. (M.) Eadowuhu *uw A^ahaAliyba [His (a horse's) running is of ardent, or impetuous, modes, or manners]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aholuwbN A kind, or way [or speech]: syn. fan~N (K) and A^asoluwbN: (AO:) pl. A^ahaAliybu. (AO, K.) ― -b3- AhlwbN mn Alv~anaA'i A kind, or way, of praising, or eulogizing. (TA.)

maholuwbN * (S, A, L, Msb) and ↓ muhal~abN (TA) A horse having his tail shorn: (Msb:) having the hair of his tail utterly removed: (L:) having his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail &c.,] shorn: (A:) having his hlb plucked out. (S, TA.)
muhal~abN * : see maholuwbN.
muhal~ibN * : see hal~aAbN.

hilobaAvN *
A kind of dates. Said to be the only kind brought form El-Basrah to the Sultán. (AHn.)

hilobawovN *
Stupid; foolish; of little sense: or dull of speech and understanding; doltish; heavy; syn. fadomN. (S, and some copies of the K.)

hilobaAjapN *
Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (S:) or one unsurpassed in stupidity, foolishness, or paucity of sense: or heavy, dull, stupid, and of little use: (TA:) or a heavy, or dull, man: (T:) as also hilobaAjN: (L:) Khalaf El-Ahmar says, I asked an Arab of the desert respecting the meaning of hlbAjp, and he said, It means a stupid, or foolish, man, or one of little sense, bulky, or corpulent, impotent in speech or actions, and heavy, or dull, or doltish, a great eater, who who — who —, and he continued to add to his interpretation something each time; after which he said to me, desiring to depart, he is one who comprises every evil quality. (S, K. *)

1 halata * , [aor.
haluta , and
halita ?] inf. n. halotN, He peeled a thing; or deprived it of its outer covering, or crust; syn. qa$ara. (K.) ― -b2- halata Ald~ama, as also salata, He peeled off, or scraped off, (q$ara,) the [dried] blood with a knife. (Lh, L.) ― -b3- halta dama Albadanapi, [as also salata,] He scratched the skin of the bdnp [or beast brought to Mekkeh for sacrifice, or there sacrificed, or the right reading is Aln~adabapi, i. e. the sear. (see salata,)] with a knife, so that he made the blood to appear. (Lh, L, TA.)

7 Anhlt yaEoduw *
i. q. Anslt, (in the CK, Anhlt baEuda wAnslt,) He withdrew himself privately, or stole away, without being known to do so, running. (Ibn-El-Faraj, K.)

halotaY *
A certain plant; (S, K;) when it dries, it becomes red; and when it is eaten, and grows, it is called jamiymN: or, accord. to Az, a certain tree, growing like the Sil~iyaAn, except that its colour inclines to red: or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, as AHn says, a plant of the kind called Tariyfap, growing like the Sl~yAn and the naSiY~, red when fresh and moist, and more red when it has dried: it is watery; and the camels and sheep &c. scarcely ever eat it when they find any other herbage to serve them in its stead. (TA.)

hulaAtapN * The black filth that is washed away from the membrane which encloses a young lamb or kid in its mother's womb. (K, TA.) [For gusaAlapu Als~axolapi Als~awodaA'i, as in the copies of the K in my hands, I read AlswdA'u. ― -b2- See also hulaAbapN.]

halotaAtN * [accord. to the TA and a MS. copy of the K: in the CK hulotaAtN:] A company of people staying, or abiding, in a place; and of people journeying. (K.) So accord. to AZ; but accord. to ISk, with v. (L.)

halovaY *
An assembly, a company, or congregated body, of men. (IAar.) [Or perhaps it is halovFY.] ― -b2- Also, and ↓ halovaA='N [or perhaps halovaA='u] and ↓ hilovaA='N and ↓ halovaA='apN and ↓ hilovaA='apN and ↓ hulovapN An assembly, a company, or a congregated body, (composed of a great number of men, TA,) whose voices are raised high. (K.) [That hilovaA' is with tenween is expressly shown by Fr.: but whether halovaA' is so is doubtful.] ― -b3- Also ↓ hilovaA^apN, with the second syll. short, An assembly, or a company, more in number than what is called waDomap. (Th.) ― -b4- mino kul~i wajohK ↓ jaA'ato hilovaA^apN There came parties from every direction. (Th.)
hulovapN * : see halovaY.
hilovaA='N * : see halovaY.

hlvA'N * [app. halovaA'N], coll. gen. n., n. un. with p, A kind of palm-tree, slender below, and thick at the head; the unripe dates of which are of a reddening yellow, disagreeable in taste; and its fresh ripe dates of the best, or sweetest, kind. (Aboo-Hátim, in Msb.) ― -b2- See halovaY.
hailovaA='apN * : see halovaY and hulaAvN.
hulaAvN * and ↓ halovaA'apN and ↓ hilovaA'apN Flaccidness, or languor, (A_isotiraxoA',) that comes upon a man. (K.)

halaAy^ivu *
People of the lower, or lowest, class. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa mino halaAy^ivihimo, mentioned, but not explained, by IAar: thought by ISd to signify He is of the dregs of them: or, of their assembly, or company. (TA.)

A_iholiylajN * (IAar, S, K) and A_iholiylijN, (Fr, Sh, K,) but this is disapproved by IAar, who observes that there are no words in Arabic of the measure A_ifoEiylilN, but there are of the measure A_ifoEiylalN, as A_iholiylajN and A_iboriysamN and A_iToriyfalN, (S,) and haliylajN, (L,) but this is disallowed by ISk, (S,) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p, (K,) an arabicized word, (S,) from Ahlylh, (TA,) [or rather hliylaho, a Persian word,] A well-known fruit, [the fruit of the myrobalan, as well as the myrobalan-tree,] one kind of which is yellow, (K,) and another kind black, the latter being in the highest state of ripeness, and another kind called kaAbuliY~N: it is useful as a remedy for quinseys, and preserves the intel-lect, and removes the head-ache, (when used made into a conserve, TA,) and is, in the stomach, like an intelligent housewife, who is a good manager, in the house: (K, TA; but omitted in some copies of the K:) so is this medicine to the brain and stomach. (TA.) [See also biliylajN, in art. blj.]

hilojaAbN *
A large cooking-pot. (K.)

div2.head: hld &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

juwEN hil~aqobN *
Vehement hunger. (AA, T, L.) See also hil~aqotN.

juwEN hil~aqotN *
Vehement hunger. (K.) [See also hil~aqosN.]

1 hamaA^a * , aor.
hamaAa , (K,) inf. n. hamo'N; (TA;) and ↓ AhmA^; (K;) He rent, (K,) i. e., pulled so that it tore, (TA,) a garment: (K:) he wore out, or rendered threadbare, [and ragged]. (K.)
4 A^ahomaAa see 1.
5 taham~aAa see 7.
7 AnhmA^ * (K) and ↓ thm~A^ (S, K) It (a garment) became rent: (TA:) became worn-out, or threadbare, (S, K,) and ragged. (S.)

himo'N *
A worn-out, threadbare, or ragged, garment: pl. A^ahomaA'N. (K.)

1 hmata * , [aor.
hamuta ,] It (variyd) became hidden in the grease; (K;) became overspread by the grease. (TA.)
4 Ahmt AlkalaAma * , and AlD~aHika, He made speech, and laughter, low; he spoke, and laughed, low. (K.) It is said to be from Alhamosu; the s being changed into t. (MF.)

1 hmj * , [app. hamija, aor.
hamaja ,] inf. n. hamajN, He hungered; was hungry. (L.) ― -b2- hamajati AlA_ibilu mina AlmaA='i, (S, K,) aor.
hamuja , inf. n. hamojN, (S,) The camels drank of the water at one draught, (S, K,) until they satisfied their thirst. (S.)
4 Ahmj * , (inf. n. A_ihomaAjN, TA,) He (a horse, S, K, or other animal that runs, Lh,) strove or exerted himself, in his running, (S, K,) and then ran impetuously, so as to raise the dust. (TA.)

hamajN *
Hunger: or (in the K, and) bad management of the means of subsistence. (S, K.) ↓ hamajN haAmijN [Severe hunger: or very bad management of the means of subsistence:] (S, K:) the latter word is added to give intensiveness to the signification; (TA;) or to corroborate; (S, K;) as in the case of layolN laAy^ilN. (S.) ― -b2- hamajN Small flies, like gnats, that fall upon the faces of sheep or goats, and asses, (S, K,) and into their eyes: (S:) or gnats; so called from hamajN signifying “ hunger; ” because when they are hungry they live, but when they become satiated they die: or SigaAr Ald~awaAb~i: (L:) [but this is evidently a mistake for SigaAru Al*~ubaAbi the young ones, or little ones, of flies:]) or any grubs that burst forth from flies or from gnats: (Lth, A:) pl. of hamajapN, (S,) [or rather this is the n. un. of hamajN, which is a coll. gen. n.]. ― -b3- hamajN Lean sheep or goats: (K:) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p. (S, K.) ― -b4- hamajN (tropical:) Stupid, or foolish, men; or men of little sense: (K:) or stupid, or foolish, young men of the meaner sort: (S:) or simply young men of the meaner sort: or mixed and low set of men: or disorderly vagabonds: (TA:) you say also rajulN hamajN and hamajapN a stupid, or foolish, man; and rijaAlN hamajN, and A^ahomaAjN: (TA:) or hamajapN signifies a stupid, or foolish, man, who has not firm command of himself. (Aboo-Sa'eed.) ― -b5- hamajN Old and weak ewes: (K:) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p: which also signifies simply a ewe. (TA.) ― -b6- qawomN hamajN A people in whom is no good. (TA.) ― -b7- ↓ hamajN haAmijN Young men of the meaner sort; like hamajN alone: and a mixed set of men who have no intelligence nor manliness. (TA.)

hamiyjN * A doe-antelope scared, or frightened, by [the small flies called] hamajN: (S:) a young doe-antelope, (K,) of beautiful body: (L:) one lank in the belly: or one that has two streaks of a colour different from that of the rest of the body in [the two parts called] the Tur~ataAni: (K:) or one that has two such streaks on her back; which is only the case in such as are white; and also applied to the male: (TA:) or one that has been attacked by a pain in consequence of which her face has become flabby. (K.)
haAmijN * : see hamajN. ― -b2- (tropical:) [A people] left to mix tumultuously, one part with another. (K.) [The explanation seems to be borrowed from the Kur, xviii. 99.]

1 hamadati Aln~aAru * , aor.
hamuda , (S, A, L,) inf. n. humuwdN, (S, A, L, K,) The fire became extinguished (As, S, A, L, K) entirely; went out entirely, (As, S, A, L,) none of it remaining: (L:) or lost its heat: (L, K:) when [only] its flame has ceased, you say of it xamadat. (As, L.) ― -b2- hamada, (M, A, L,) aor.
hamuda , (M, L,) inf. n. humuwdN, (M, L, K,) (tropical:) He died;
[became extinct;] (M, A, L, K;) perished; (TA;) like as did Thamood; (Lth, A, L;) as also xamada. (A.) ― -b3- kaAd yahamodu mina AljuwEi (tropical:) He nearly perished of hunger. (L.) ― -b4- hamada, aor.
hamuda , (S, A, L,) inf. n. humuwdN (S, L, K) and hamodN, (L, K,) (tropical:) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became dissundered (L, K) and worn-out, (S, A, L, Msb,) by being long folded, (A, L, Msb, K,) so that a person looking at it would imagine it sound, but, when he touched it, would find it fall to pieces. (A, * L, Msb. *) ― -b5- hamadat Alr~iyHu (assumed tropical:) The wind became still. (Msb.) ― -b6- hamadati AlA^aroDu, inf. n. humuwdN, (tropical:) The land became lifeless, without herbage, without wood, and without rain. (L, K.) ― -b7- hamada $ajaru AlA^aroDi (tropical:) The trees of the land became worn-out, or wasted; and perished. (L.) ― -b8- hamadato A^aSowaAtuhumo (assumed tropical:) Their voices became silent. (L.)

4 Ahmd * , inf. n. A_ihamaAdN, (assumed tropical:) He stilled, or quieted. (K.) ― -b2- He (God, and a man,) killed, or destroyed, a man, or men. (A.) ― -b3- Ahmd AlA^amora (tropical:) He put an end to the affair. (A.) ― -b4- Ahmd AlqaHoTu AlA^aroDa (tropical:) Drought rendered the land sterile, so that it contained no herbage but such as was dried up and broken. (L.) ― -b5- Ahmd, (inf. n. A_ihomaAdN, K.) (assumed tropical:) He kept silence in an unpleasant case. (L, K.) ― -b6- Ahmd, (S, L,) inf. n. A_ihomaAdN, (L, K,) He remained, continued, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, L, K,) in a place: (S, L:) he was still; (K;) i. e., did not move. (TA.) -A2- Ahmd, (S, L) inf. n. A_ihomaAdN, (L, K,) He hastened, or was quick, (S, L, K,) in going along: (S, L:) thus it bears two contr. significations: (S, L, K:) he (a dog) ran; syn. A^aHoDara. (L.) -A3- AhmdwA fiY AlT~aEaAmi, (inf. n. A_ihomaAdN, K,) They fell to eating of the food. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, K. *)
hamidN * : see haAmidN.
hamodapN * (assumed tropical:) Apoplexy: caros: syn. sakotapN. (S, L.) ― -b2- [A trance. (See raqodapN.)]

hmiydN * (tropical:) Sheep or goats that have died: (L:) or the beasts or the like (mAl) that are registered in the government-accounts as due from a man. (ISh, L, K.) You say, A=xa*anaA mAlohamiydi He (the collector) exacted from us taking for the sheep or goats that had died: (L:) or, taking what was registered as due from us in the governmentaccounts. (ISh, L.) ― -b2- See haAmidN.

haAmidN * and ↓ hamidN and ↓ hamiydN (tropical:) In a state of death, or extinction]. (M, L.) ― -b2- haAmidN (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, [dissundered and] wornout by being long folded, so as, when touched, to fall to pieces: (A:) or anything old and wornout: (L, Msb:) pl. hum~adN. (A.) See 1. ― -b3- A^aroDN haAmidapN (tropical:) Land in which is no herbage: (S:) and in the same sense haAmidN is applied to a place: (K:) or sterile land, (A, L,) the herbage of which is dried up and broken, (A,) or containing no herbage except what is dried up and broken: (L:) dry and dusty: pl. hawaAmidu. (L.) ― -b4- haAmidN (tropical:) Old and worn-out or wasted, blackened, and changed, [for the worse]. (K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A tree black and wasted: (L:) or dried up; (A;) as also herbage. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Fruit black and stinking. (A, L.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A date just ripe, thickskinned and yellow. (TA.) ramaAdN haAmidN Ashes [in a state of extinction or] wasted, (L,) and compacted together, and changed in appearance. (A, L.)

hamaA*iY~N * , (S, L,) or humaA*iY~N, (L, in all its senses,) Quickness (L, K) in running: (L:) or exertion, or haste, in pace, or in going. (Sh, L.) ― -b2- Violence, of rain: (A 'Obeyd, S, L, K:) and [so in the L: in the TA, as some say,] violent occasions of rain, and of mutual reviling, and of running; which are sometimes violent, and at other times remit: (L:) and violence of heat; (IAar, L, K;) as also HumaA*iY~N. (IAar, L.) You say, yawomN *uwhumaA*iY~K, and HumaA*iY~K, A day of violent heat. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- Quick, or swift; (A 'Obeyd, S, L, K;) applied to a she-camel, (A 'Obeyd, S, L, K,) and to a he-camel, (A 'Obeyd, S, L.)

1 hamarahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
hamura (S, K) and
hamira , (K,) inf. n. hamorN, (S,) He, or it, poured it; out or forth; (S, A, K;) namely, water, (S, TA,) and tears, and rain, and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- hamara maA fiY AlD~aroEi He drew forth all the milk that was in the udder. (S, K.) ― -b3- hamara lahu mino maAlihi (assumed tropical:) He gave to him of his property. (S, K.) ― -b4- hamara AlkalaAma, (K,) or fY kalaAmihi, (A,) aor.
hamura , inf. n. hamorN: (TA;) and biAlkalaAmi ↓ A_inohamara; (S;) (tropical:) He talked much. (K.) -A2- hamara, intrans.: see 7. in two places.

7 Anhmr *
It poured; poured out or forth; (K;) said of rain, and of tears; (TA;) as also ↓ hamara, (K,) aor.
hamira , inf. n. humuwrN; (TA;) [and so, app., ↓ Ahtmr, q. v.:] it flowed; said of water, (S, K,) of rain, and of tears; like Anhml: (TA:) and in like manner, Eayonuhu biAld~amoEi ↓ hamarato His eye flowed with tears; as also hamalato. (A.) ― -b2- Anhmr bAlklAm: see 1.
8 Ahtmr * : see 7. ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a horse) ran (S, K, TA) like a torrent. (TA.)

hamirN *
Much sand; as also ↓ yahomuwrN. (K.)

hamorapN *
A fall of rain. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Angry speech. (Sgh, L, K.)
hamaraY * : see ham~aArN.

ham~aArN * A cloud pouring forth much rain; as also ↓ haAmirN. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (S,) (tropical:) Loquacious, garrulous; babbling; a great talker; a babbler; or nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk; as also ↓ mihomarN and ↓ mihomaArN (S, K) and ↓ yahomuwrN. (Sgh, K.) And mihomarN ↓ xaTiybN (tropical:) An orator copious in speech. (A, TA) And ↓ hamaraY, applied to a woman, (tropical:) Clamorous; (K, TA:) abounding in talk or speech, like a pouring torrent. (TA.)

haAmirN *
Pouring rain, and tears; as also ↓ munohamirN. (TA.) See also ham~aArN.
mihomarN * : see ham~aArN; the former, in two places.
mihomaArN * : see ham~aArN; the former, in two places.
munohamirN * : see haAmirN.
yahomuwrN * : see hamirN: -A2- and see also ham~aArN.
Q. 1 hamoraja Ealayohi Alxabara * , (inf. n. hamorajapN, L, K,) He rendered the news, tidings, or information, confused to him. (S, L, K. *)

hamorajapN *
Confusion; (K, L;) as also hamorajN, and ↓ hamar~ajN, and hamar~ajapN: ex. of the last waqaEa Alqawomu fiY hamar~ajapK The people fell into a state of confusion: (L:) and the third (L) and fourth (TA) signify also civil war, or conflict and faction, or discord, or dissension; syn. fitonapN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- A confused manner, or state, in walking. (S.) ― -b3- A confused noise, or mixture of voices, or unintelligible sounds, of men; as also ↓ humorujaAnN. (K.) ― -b4- Lightness, or agility, and quickness. (K.) ― -b5- What is rain, or false; syn. baATilN. (K.) ― -b6- Alguwlu hamorajapN mina Aljin~i The Ghool are a mixture of the Jinn. (L.)
hamar~ajN * : see hamorajapN. ― -b2- Penetrating (maADK) in affairs. (K.)
humorujaAnN * : see hamorajapN.

1 hamazahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
hamiza (S, Msb, K) and
hamuza , (K,) inf. n. hamozN, (S, Msb, K,) He pressed it; squeezed it; pinched it; (S, A, Msb, K,) as, for instance, a walnut, (A, TA,) or other thing, (S, TA,) in the hand; (S, A, TA,) and a man's head; (S, A, TA;) and a spearshaft, with the mahaAmiz, to straighten it. (TA.) ― -b2- He pushed, impelled, or repelled, him or it, (S, K, TA,) meaning anything; as also lamazahu &c.
(TA.) You say, hamazatohu A_ilayohi AlHaAjapu Want impelled, or drove, him to him or it. (TA.) ― -b3- He struck, or beat, him; (S, K, TA;) as also lamazahu &c. (TA.) ― -b4- He goaded, or spurred, him; (K, TA;) he urged him on (namely a horse) with the mihomaAz, to make him run. (Msb.) ― -b5- He bit him. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- He broke it. (K.) -A2- (tropical:) He (the devil) suggested evil to his mind. (JK, A, TA.) You say, A^aEuw*u biA@ll~`hi mino hamozihi; and mino hamazaAti Al$~ayaATiyni; (tropical:) I seek refuge in God from his [the devil's] evil suggestion; and from the evil suggestions of the devils. (A.) -A3- (tropical:) He blamed, upbraided, or reproached, him; he found fault with him; syn. of the inf. n. EayobN, (Fr, in TA, art. lmz; and IAar, in TA, in the present art.) as also lamozN: (Fr, in TA, art. lmz; and S,) or he spoke evil of him, or spoke of him in a manner that he disliked, mentioning vices or faults as chargeable to him, behind his back, though it might be with truth; syn. A_igotaAbahu fiY gayobatihi: (Msb:) and [so] hamazahu fiY qafaAhu he backbit him. (JK, A.) -A4- hamaza AlHarofa, (S, O,) or Alkalimapa, aor.
hamiza , inf. n. hamozN, (Msb,) [He pronounced the word with the sound termed hamoz, or hamozap, of which the sign is ',] is from hamazahu in the first of the senses explained above; (S, Msb,) because what is termed hamoz in speech, (S,) or hamozap, (Kh, TA,) [i. e. the sound so called,] is [as it were] pressed, or squeezed, (Kh, S, TA,) from its place of utterance [by a sudden emission of the voice forced out after a compression of the passage whereby it has been stopped]. (Kh, TA.) It was said to an Arab of the desert, A^atahomizu AlfaA^orapa, [meaning Dost thou pronounce AlfaA^orap with hemz, or hemzeh?] and he said, [understanding the words to mean dost thou squeeze the rat, or mouse?] Als~in~aworu yahomizuhaA [The cat squeezes it]. (S.) See hamozN, below. [And see also nabara.]

7 Anhmz * [quasi-pass. of hamazahu; It was pressed, squeezed, or pinched: he was pushed, &c. The first of these significations is indicated, or implied, in the JK and the TA.] ― -b2- Anhmz AlHarofu [The word was pronounced with the sound termed hamoz, or hamozap]. (S.)

hamozu Al$~ayoTaAni * was explained by Mohammad as meaning (tropical:) Madness, or insanity; syn. muwtapN, i. e. junuwnN; because it arises from the goading and pressing or pinching of the devil. (A 'Obeyd, K.) See 1; and see also hamazaAt, voce hamozapN. -A2- hamozN, (S,) and hamozapN, (Kh, TA,) [the former a gen. n., and the latter the n. un.,] The sister of alif; one of the letters of the alphabet; [written thus;] a genuine word, old, heard [from the Arabs of classical times], and well known; so called for a reason mentioned above: see 1, last signification: so says Kh; therefore no regard is due to what is said in certain of the expositions of the Keshsháf, that the term hmzp thus used has not been heard [from any of the Arabs of classical times], and that its name is A^alofN: (TA:) several persons say, that the term hmzp is mostly applied to the movent [alif], and Alf to the quiscent letter. (MF, TA.) See the letter A.
hamozapN * n. un. of hamozN, q. v. ― -b2- hamazaAtu Al$~ayaATiyni (tropical:) The vain suggestions of the devils, which they inspire into the mind of a man. (S, TA.) See also 1; and see hamozN.

humazapN *
i. q. gam~aAzN; (K;) i. e., (TA,) One who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually; (S, TA;) as also ↓ ham~aAzN (S, TA) and ↓ haAmizN; (S, K;) and so lumazapN: (S, K, art. lmz:) [or rather] the first and second are intensive epithets (TA) [but the third is not intensive]: or one who backbites his brother; as also ↓ ham~aAzN: (Lth, A, TA:) or one who defames men (yaxolufuhumo mino waraAy^ihimo wabaA^okulu luHuwmahumo); and the action thus signified is like giybapN, and may be [by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head; as also ↓ ham~aAzN: (TA:) or, conjointly with lumazapN, one who speaks evil of men, or backbites them, and defames them: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA:) or both together, one who goes about much, or habitually, with calumny, or slander, separating companions and exciting enmity between friends: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) humazapN is applied to a man and to a woman; (S, TA;) [like lamuzapN;] for its p is to denote intensiveness, and not the fem. gender: (TA:) ↓ hum~aAzN [which is the pl. of haAmizN] signifies persons who blame, upbraid, reproach, or find fault with, others behind their backs, much, or habitually: (IAar, TA:) [or, more correctly, it has not an intensive signification.] See also lumazapN.
ham~aAzN * : see humazapN, throughout.
haAmizN * : see humazapN, throughout.
mihomazN * : see mihomaAzN.

mihomazapN *
An instrument for beating, (maqoraEapN, AHeyth, K, TA,) of copper or brass, [app. meaning a kind of spur, or a goad,] with which beasts of carriage are urged on: pl. mahaAmizu: (AHeyth, TA:) or a staff or stick: (K:) or a staff, or stick, with an iron in its head, with which the ass is goaded, or urged on. (Sh, K.) See also mihomaAzN. ― -b2- [The pl., mahaAmizu, of this word or of mihomazN, is also applied to An instrument, or instruments, with which spear-shafts are pinched and straightened: see 1, first signification.]

miohamAzN * and ↓ mihomazN (S, Msb, K) A well-known thing; (Msb;) [namely, a spur;] an iron which is [attached or fixed] in the kinder part of the boot of him who breaks, or trains, beasts of carriage: (S, K:) pl. [of the former] mahaAmiyzu (K) and [of the latter] mahaAmizu. (S, K.) See also mihomazap.

1 hamas * , aor.
hamisa , (A, TA,) inf. n. hamos (AHeyth, L, TA) and hamiysN and humuwsN, (L, TA,) He spoke inaudibly: (AHeyth, TA:) or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, (AHeyth, TA,) so as to be hardly intelligible. (TA.) It is said in a trad. fajaEala baEoDunaA yahomisu A_ilaY baEoDK And some of us began to speak to others in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, so as to be hardly intelligible. (TA.) And in another trad., kaAna *aA A_iSal~aY AlEaSora hamasa bi$aYo'K laA nafohamuhu He used, when he performed the afternoon-prayer, to utter something in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, we not understanding it. (TA.) You say also, hamasa A_ilaY~a biHadiyvihi [He uttered his discourse to me inaudibly: or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner.] (A.) And Al$~ayoTaAnu yahomisu biwasowasatihi Sadora AlA_inosaAni [The devil speaks inaudibly in his suggesting vain or unprofitable things into the bosom of man]. (A.) And hamasa Al$~ayoTaAnu fiY AlS~adori The devil suggested vain, or unprofitable things in the bosom; syn. wasowasa. (TA.) See also hamosN below. ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He made the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading. So in the saying, A_ihomiso waSaho and hamosFA waSaho Make thou the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading, and be thou silent: addressed by a thief to his companion. (TA.) And hence the saying of the Rájiz,
fahun~a yamo$iyna bihi hamiysaA
And they walk with him making the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading. (S.) hamiysN also signifies The walking softly; with a soft-sounding tread: (TA:) [and so hamosN; as in the saying,] samiEotu hamosa AlA^axofaAfi waAlA^aqodaAmi [I heard the soft-sounding treading of the feet of camels and of the feet of men]. (A.) See also hamosN below. -A2- hamasa AlS~awota, aor.
hamisa , inf. n. hamosN, He made the sound, or voice to be low, faint, gentle, or soft. (Msb.) And hamasa AlkalaAma, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, [He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner; like hamasa alone; lit.,] he made speech, or the speech to be low, faint, gentle, or soft. (A, TA.) -A3- hamasa AlT~aEaAma, (TK), [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (AZ, K,) He chewed the food with the mouth closed: (AZ, K, TA:) or without opening the mouth. (TA.) You say, huwa yaokulu hamosFA He eats without opening his mouth. (A.) Hence, a toothless old woman's eating is termed hamosN. (AHeyth.) hamasahu also signifies [simply] He chewed it. (TA.)

3 hAmshu * , inf. n. muhaAmasapN, He spoke, or discoursed secretly to him, or with him. (A.) You say also, haAmasuwA, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) They spoke, or discoursed, secretly together; as also ↓ thAmswA. (K, * TK.)
6 tahaAomasa see 3.

hamosN *
A low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound. (S, A, Msb, K.) So it has been explained as occurring in the words of the Kur, [xx. 107,] falaA tasomaEu A_il~aA hamosFA [So that thou shalt not hear aught save] a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound, arising from the shifting of the feet from place to place towards the scene of congregation [for the general judgment]: or, as Az thinks, the meaning here is, the sound of the patting, or pattering, of the feet (xafoqa AlA^aqodaAmi) upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b2- The faint, or gentle, sound of the voice in the mouth, of such kind as has no mixture of the voice of the chest, nor loudness of utterance. (Lth, K.) See also mahomuwsN. ― -b3- And Anything low, faint, gentle, or soft, (kul~u xafiY~K, K, TA,) of speech and the like: (TA:) [see again, mahomuwsN:] or the faintest, or slightest, sound of the feet; (S, K;) i. e., of their tread upon the ground: (TA:) so [accord. to J] in the instance in the Kur, [xx. 107,] mentioned above: (S:) and [in like manner] ↓ hamiysN signifies the sound of the shifting from place to place of the feet of camels. (K.) See also 1.
hamiysN * : see 1: and see hamosN.

kalaAmN mahomuwsN * [Speech spoken inaudibly: or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, so as to be hardly intelligible: see 1: or] speech not spoken out or openly. (A, * Msb.) ― -b2- HarofN mahomuwsN, (Msb,) or Harofu Alhamosi, (IJ,) [A letter which is pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; a non-vocal letter; a sound with which the breath passes forth, not from the voice of the chest, but passing forth gently; (IJ;) contr. of majohuwrN: (Msb:) AlHuruwfu Almahomuwsapu are the letters (ten in number, S,) which are comprised in the saying Hav~ahu $axoSN fasakato: (S, K: *) so called [accord. to some] because the stress is made weak in the place where any one of them occurs until the breath has passed forth with it. (Sb, S.)

div2.head: hm$ &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

Q. 1 hamolaja * , (L, Msb,) inf. n. hamolajapN, (S, L, K, &c.,) He (a hackney, or pacing horse, biro*awon, S, L, &c., i. e. a rahawaAn, TA,) went an easy and quick pace; (Msb;) he (a hackney, or pacing horse, or a beast,) went a good and quick pace; he went at a good and quick and graceful pace; (L;) he (a beast of carriage) went a good pace. (Abridgment of the 'Eyn.) See naSaba Als~ayora.
hamolajapN * , as a simple subst., (An easy and quick, or good and quick, or good and quick and graceful, or good, pace of a hackney, or pacing horse, or beast of carriage:] pl. hamaAliju. (L.)

himolaAjN * , (S, K, &c.,) used as the act. part. n. of hamolaja, (Abridgment of the 'Eyn,) whence it would seem that the regular form of the act. part. n., muhamolijN, has not been used, (Msb,) an epithet applied to a hackney, or pacing horse, biro*awon, (S, K, &c,) or a beast of carriage, (L,) both to the male and female, (L, Msb,) Going, or that goes, an easy and quick pace; (Msb;) a good and quick pace; a good and quick and graceful pace; (L;) a good pace: (Abridgment of the 'Eyn:) syn. muhamolijN: (K: in the CK muhamolajN:) a man's beast for riding: (L:) pl. hamaAliyju: (S:) a Persian word, arabicized: (S, L, K:) [but I have not found its original in a Persian lexicon]. ― -b2- $aApN himolaAjN A sheep in which is no marrow, by reason of its leanness. (K.)

A^amorN muhamolajN *
An affair rendered manageable, or easy. (L, K.) ― -b2- An affair proved by experience. (L.)

div2.head: hmY &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 hanuw^a * , aor.
hanuAa , inf. n. hanaA='apN; and haniy^a, aor.
hanaAa ; It came, or happened, without inconvenience, or trouble: (K:) [it was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment: see what immediately follows]. ― -b2- hanuw^a AlT~aEaAmu (S, K *) aor.
hanuAa , inf. n. hanaA='apN (S, K) and hanaA^apN and hano'N, (K,) or hino'N (as in some copies of the K, and in the L); epithet haniYo'N; (S;) and haniy^a, (Akh, S, K,) aor.
hanaAa , inf. n. hano'N; (TA;) and hanaA^a, aor.
haniAa , (Lth,) The food was, or became, pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater: or easy to swallow; not attended by trouble: [agreeable:] or not succeeded by harm, even after digestion. (Z, cited voce maruw^a.) ― -b3- hanaA^aniY AlT~aEaAmu, (Akh, S, K), and hanaA^a liYa, aor.
haniAa and
hanaAa (S, K) and
hanuAa , (K,) unexampled, says Akh, in the class termed mahmooz, (S,) [though baraA^a and qaraA^a are similar with respect to their having damm to the aor.,] inf. n. hano'N and hino'N, (S, K,) [The food was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to me: or easy to swallow; &c.: see hanuw^a]. ― -b4- hanaA^aniY AlT~EAmu wamarA^aniY: see art. mrA^. ― -b5- hanaA^ahu *`lika, and hnA^ lahu *lk That (thing) was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to him; &c. (TA.) [See hanuw^a.] ― -b6- hanaA^aniY xabaru fulaAnK The news of such a one was pleasant to me to hear. (TA.) ― -b7- haniy^a AlT~EaAma, aor.
hanaAa ; and baAlT~EAmi ↓ thn~A^, (S, K,) and thn~A^ AlT~EAm, and AsthnA^hu, (TA,) [He enjoyed the food; found it pleasant, or productive of enjoyment; &c.: see hanuw^a:] he found the food to be productive of no evil result, and not attended by inconvenience. (TA.) ― -b8- haniy^a, (AZ, S, K,) aor.
hanaAa , inf. n. hanaA^N and hano'N, (K,) He (a beast) lighted upon a good piece of herbage, but did not satiate himself therewith. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b9- A^akalonaA h`*aA AlT~aEaAma Hat~aY haniy^onaA minohu We ate this food until we were satiated with it. (TA.) ― -b10- haniy^ati AlA_ibilu The camels were satiated with herbage. (TA.) ― -b11- haniy^a bihi He rejoiced in him, or it. (K.) ― -b12- hanaA^anaA All~`hu AlT~aEaAma [God made the food pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to us: &c.: made us to enjoy it: see hanuw^a]. (TA.) ― -b13- hanaA^atoniyhi AlEaAfiyapu [Health made it pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to me: &c.]. (K.) ― -b14- liyahoniy^oka AlfaArisu [May the horseman give thee joy: a form of congratulation on the exploits of a horseman; i. e., I congratulate thee on the exploits of the horseman]: also written and pronounced liyahoniyka: lyhnk, though it occurs in a trad., pronounced liyahonika or liyahonaka, (but which pronunciation is to be preferred is disputed,) is said to be a vulgarism, and not allowable. (TA.) ― -b15- hanaA^ahu, aor.
hanaAa (K) [and app.,
haniAa (see haAniy^N)], inf. n. hano'N, (TA,) He fed him; or gave him to eat. (K.) ― -b16- hanaA^ahu, aor.
hanaAa and
haniAa , (S, K,) inf. n. hano'N; (S;) and ↓ AhnA^hu; (IAar, K;) He gave him, or bestowed upon him: (S, K:) gave him plentifully. (TA.) ― -b17- hanaA^a AlT~aEaAma, inf. n. hano'N and hino'N (K) and hanaA='apN (as in some copies of the K) or hanaA^apN (as in others) or hinaA^apN (as in others) or hanoA^apN (as in the CK), He made the food good; qualified it properly; seasoned it: syn. A^aSolaHahu. (K.) ― -b18- hanaA^a maAlahu, (TA,) and mAlh ↓ AhtnA^, (K,) He put his property in a right, or good, state. (K.) ― -b19- hanaA^a Alqawoma, aor.
hanaAa , He nourished, or maintained, the people; (S;) satisfied their wants; bestowed upon them. (TA.) Ex. hanaA^ahumo $ahorayoni [He maintained them two months]. Hence the proverb quoted in illustration of the word haAniy^N, accord. to the second reading. (TA) ― -b20- hanaA^ahu He aided, succoured, or defended, him. (K.) -A2- hanaA^a AlA_ibila, aor.
hanaAa (S, K,) and
haniAa and
hanuAa (K: dev. from constant rule as shown above: TA), inf. n. hanaA^N and hano'N, (TA,) He smeared the camels with hinaA=', which is tar, or liquid pitch, syn. qaTiraAn, (AZ, S, K,) or a kind thereof, (TA,) [as a
remedy for, or preservative against, the mange, or scab]. ― -b2- layosa Alhano'u biAld~as~i The smearing of a camel [all over] with hinaA=' is not [merely] smearing the cavities under the shoulders, and the like, which the mange, or scab, more quickly attacks. A proverb, applied to him who does not a thing thoroughly. (TA.) ― -b3- See 2.

2 han~aAhu waman~aAhu * (in a trad. respecting the prostration for inattention) He (the devil) made him to think of pleasant things, or things productive of enjoyment, and of things wished for, or objects of desire, in his prayer. The former verb is pronounced thus to assimilate it to the latter. (TA.) ― -b2- hn~A^hu biAlA^amori, inf. n. tahoniy^apN and tahoniYo'N; (S, K;) and ↓ hanaA^ahu, (K,) inf. n. hano'N; (TA;) He congratulated him on the thing, (S, K,) such as the possession of a government, &c.: (S:) he said to him liyahoniy^oka [May it give thee joy]. (K.) ― -b3- [When the agent of the verb is God, the meaning necessarily is, He granted him enjoyment in the thing; made him to have enjoyment in it.] ― -b4- hun~iy^ota walaA tunokaho: see art. nkA^.
4 A^ahonaAa see 1.

5 thn~A^ *
He gave many gifts. (IAar.) ― -b2- thn~A^ bika*aA [unless it be a mistake for thy~A^, as IbrD suggests, which I think not improbable, though mentioned in this art. in the TA] He prided himself in such a thing: syn. tmr~A^ and tgy~Z and tsm~n and txy~l and tzy~n. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1.
8 A_ihotanaAa see 1.

10 AsthnA^hu *
He asked him for aid, succour, or defence. (K.) ― -b2- He asked him for a gift. (K, TA.) ― -b3- He conceded to him, or gave him, a part of his dues, or rights. (TA.) ― -b4- See 1.

hino'N *
A gift. (S, K.) -A2- A part of the night. (K.) -A3- hino'N subst. from hanaA^a AlA_ibila; (K;) i. e., The smearing with hinaA='. (MF.)

A_ibilN hanoA^aY *
Camels which have lighted upon a good piece of herbage, but are not satiated therewith. (K.)

hinaA='N *
Tar, or liquid pitch; syn. qaTiraAnN: (S, K:) or a kind thereof. (TA.) See also nuwrapN; and qAlibN. -A2- hinaA='N dial. var. of A_ihaAnN, (K,) or formed from the latter by transposition, (TA,) A raceme of a palm-tree. (AHn, K.) [See A_ihaAnN.]

haniYo'N *
What comes or happens to one without inconvenience, or trouble: (S, K:) [what is pleasant, or productive of enjoyment; an unalloyed gratification, i. e., a thing that gives unalloyed enjoyment; see what follows:] as also ↓ mahonaA^N, (K,) a subst., sometimes written and pronounced mahonaA; pl. mahaAniy^u, sometimes written and pronounced mahaAnK. (TA.) [See mhnA^ also below.] ― -b2- Pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater: or easy to swallow; not attended by trouble: or not succeeded by harm, even after its digestion. (Z, cited voce maruw^a.) ― -b3- haniyoy^FA mariyoy^FA [May it be, or Eat it, or Drink it, with enjoyment, and with wholesome result: or with ease in the swallowing, and with quickness in digesting: &c.: see maruw^a]. (S.) ― -b4- haniyoy^FA lahu *`lika [May that be productive of enjoyment to him!]. (TA.) ― -b5- haniyoy^FA and mariyoy^FA are of the number of epithets which are employed after the manner of inf. ns. significant of a prayer or good wish, governed in the acc. case by a verb understood. (Sb.)

hunayoy^apN * (K) and hunay~apN and hunayohapN (the second is the most usual; and the third is said to be formed by substituting h for '; but accord. to some, the word is incorrectly written with ', [so says F,] and is a dim. formed from hanowapN, which becomes first hunayowapN, and then hunay~apN: see art. hnw:) (TA:) A little; a little while. (K.)

haAniy^N *
A servant. (K.) ― -b2- haAniy^FA occurs in this sense in a trad.; but the reading commonly known is maAhinFA. If right, it is an act. part. n. from hnA^ “ he gave. ” (TA.) ― -b3- A_in~amaA sum~iyta haAniy^FA litahoniy^a, or litahonaA^a; the former is the reading of El-Umawee; the latter, of Ks; Thou art only named Háni (Giver, or Nourisher,) that thou mayest give, accord. to both readings; or that thou mayest nourish, or maintain, and supply people's wants; ltEwl wtkfY: (TA:) [such is said to be the meaning of lthnA^ here:] and accord. to El-Umawee, lthny^ signifies litumoriy^a, (S,) [which is app. the same as ltEwl]. A proverb: said to him who is known for his beneficence, in order that he may continue to do as he has been wont. (TA.)

mahonaA^N * : see haniY'N. ― -b2- laka AlmahonaA^u, (S,) and AlmahonaA, (TA,) [Unalloyed gratification to thee!] ― -b3- laka AlmahonaA^u waEalayohi Alwizoru [To thee be unalloyed gratification, and on him be the burden, or sin]: said, accord. to a trad., to one who asked whether he should accept an invitation to eat the food of one who received unlawful interest or profit; and also said with respect to eating the food of a tyrannical intendant. (TA.)
mahonuwo'N * A camel smeared with hinaA'. (S.)

hanabN * [probably an inf. n., of which the verb is haniba, aor.
hanaba ,] Weakness of understanding; want of discrimination; stupidity; foolishness; littleness of sense. (S.)
hanabaY * &c.: see hun~abaA'u.

hun~abaA'u * (incorrectly written by J, in a verse which he quotes, hanobaA'u, K, TA; but in an old and excellent copy of the S, I find the word written hanabA'u;]) and hun~abaY (K) and hanabaA'u and ↓ hanabaY (IDrd, K) A woman of weak understanding; without discrimination; stupid; foolish; of little sense: (S, K:) accord. to some, as mentioned in a note by Aboo-Zekereeya, in the S, in this art., hunabaY signifies an insane woman; or one possessed by a jinnee. (TA.) hun~abaA'u is the only word of the measure fuE~alaA'u known to Az. (TA.) Accord. to the K, IDrd writes A_imoraA^apN hanabaA'u and hanabaY: but this is [thought to be] a mistake: he gives the two forms hun~abaA'u and hun~abaY, as stated by IM and others; and, app., hanabaY. (TA.) ― -b2- The first and second of these three words also signify A man who is stupid, foolish, or of little sense. (K.)

mihonabN *
Exceedingly stupid, or foolish. (IAar, Az, K.)
Q. 1 hanobata * , inf. n. hanobatapN, He was languid and sluggish. (IKtt, K.) It may be said that the n is augmentative, and that the word is derived from habotapN, signifying “ weakness. ” (TA.)

Q. 1 hanotaba fiY A^amorihi *
He was remiss in his affair. (K.) See also hanobata.

2 han~adatohu * , inf. n. tahoniydN, She (a woman) behaved towards him in a blandishing manner: (IDrd, L:) she enamoured him by blandishment, (L, K,) and by amatory conversation or conduct: (L:) she enslaved him by amatory conversation, or conduct. (S, L.) [Thought by Golius to be derived from hinod, a proper name of a woman.] ― -b2- hn~dt biqalobihi She deprived him of his heart. (Ibn-El-Mustaneer, L.) -A2- hn~d, inf. n. tahoniydN, He made a sword of Indian iron. This is the original signification. (T, L.) ― -b2- He sharpened a sword. (L, K.)

hinod * a name for A hundred camels; (M, L, K;) as also ↓ hunayodapu; (T, S, M, A, L, K;) which latter is a determinate noun, imperfectly decl., not admitting the art. Al, [though it is written with it in the S, and in a verse cited in the S and L,] nor having a pl., nor a proper sing.: (T, L:) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce sarifa:] or the former is a name for more than a hundred camels and less: (K:) or a little more and a little less: (M, L:) or two hundred camels: (M,
A, L, K:) so accord. to Ez-Ziyádee, as mentioned by ISd, who adds that he had not heard it from any other than IJ: (L:) and the latter, a hundred of other things: (S, L:) or any hundred: (AO, S, L:) also the former, two hundred years: and the latter, [written with the art. Al,] a hundred years. (Th, ISd, L.) -A2- Alhinodu The name of a well-known nation; (M, L, K;) or of a country: (S, L:) [the Indians: and India:] rel. n. ↓ hinodiY~N: pl. hunuwdN: (S, L, K:) and AlA^ahaAnidu signifies the men of Alhinod [or India]; as also AlhanaAdiku, (L, K,) pl. of hinodikiY~N [q. v. in art. hndk]. (L.) ― -b2- See also A^aHomasu.

hinodiY~N * : see hinodN. ― -b2- Also, Indian aloes-wood. (L.) ― -b3- sayofN hinodiY~N, (L,) and ↓ hinoduwaAniY~N, [in the CK hinodawaAniY~N,] and hunoduwaAniY~N, (S, A, L, K,) A sword made in the country of Alhinod, [or India,] and well fabricated: (L:) or, made of the iron of that country: (A:) as also ↓ muhan~adN, in the latter sense, (S, A, L,) and in the former: (L:) so termed in relation to the people called Alhinod: (K:) and ↓ sayofN muhan~adN a sharpened, or sharp, sword. (L.)
huinoduwaAniY~N * : see hinodiY~N.
hunayodapu * : see hinodN.
muhan~adN * : see hinodiY~N.
hinodabN * and hinodabaA'N &c.: see art. hdb.

hinodaAzN * , (S, K,) with kesr, (K,) found in the work of Az, in several places, written with fet-h, [hanodaAzN,] (TA,) A limit; syn. Had~N: (K:) [or rather a measure:] an arabicized word, from A^anodaAzah, (S, K,) with fet-h, (K,) which is Persian: (S:) the arabicized word is with kesr to the first letter because of the rareness of the measure faEolaAlN in the cases of words not reduplicative. (K.) You say, A^aEaT`Ahu bilaA HisaAbi walaA hinodaAzK [He gave to him without calculation and without measure]. (S.)
hinodaAzapN * The cubit with which [certain] cloths and the like are measured; [about twenty-five inches in length:] also a Persian word arabicized. (TA.)

muhanodzN *
One who determines the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water, and of buildings: [an architect: and also a geometrician:] from hinodaAzN: but they change the z into s, (S, K,) and say muhanodisN, (S,) because there is not in the [genuine] language of the Arabs a z with a d before it. (S, K.)

hanodasapN * [The art of determining the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water: and hence, the art of architecture: and the practice, and science, of geometry:] a subst. from muhanodisN, q. v. (S, K.)

muhanodisN *
One who determines the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water: [and hence, an architect: and a geometrician: derived from hinodaAzN, (S, K,) which is Persian [in origin], (S,) arabicized from A=bo A^anodaAzo; (K;) AndAz signifying “ the act of measuring, ” and A=b signifying “ water; ” (TA;) the z being changed into s because there is not in the [genuine] language of the Arabs a z after d. (S, K.)
4 hanaAra Alv~awoba * , aor. yuhaniyruhu, inf. n. AhonaArapN, or hinaArapN; for A^anaArahu: see art. nyr.

div2.head: hnE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
hanoqabN * , (K) by some written hinoqab~N, (TA,) Short: (K:) but it is not a word of established authority. (IDrd.)

div2.head: hnm &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haA='a binafosihi A_ilY AlmaEaAliY * , (S, K,) aor. yahuwo'u, (S,) inf. n. hawo'N, (TA,) He raised his mind to high things, or objects; purposed, or aspired to, high things. (S, K, TA.) The vulgar say, yahowiY binafosihi. (S.) ― -b2- maA huw^otu hawo'ahu I did not know it, nor desire, or mean, [to do it; i. e., I did it not knowingly, nor intentionally]. (TA.) ― -b3- huw^otu bihi xayorFA, (Az, S, K) and $ar~FA, (K,) and Huw^otuhu bixayorK, and bi$ar~K, (Lh,) inf. n. hawo'N, (TA,) I thought him to be possessed of good, (Az, S, K,) and, of evil. (K, TA.) ― -b4- huw^otuhu bimaAlK kaviyzK I thought him to be possessed of much wealth. (TA.) ― -b5- A_in~iY laA^ahuw^o'u bika Eano h`*aA AlA^amori Verily I exalt thee above this thing; I hold thee above it]. (Lh.) ― -b6- huw^otu bihi I rejoiced in him, or it. (AA, K.) ― -b7- hawiy^a A_ilayohi, aor. yahowaA^u, He purposed, or intended, it. (K.) -A2- haA='i and haA='a and haA^o, in imperative senses, and the forms into which they are inflected, see below.

3 hAwA^hu *
He contended with him for superior glory: like haAwaAhu. (IAar.) [See also art. hwY.]

haA='i * , haA='a, haA^o, &c. ― -b2- haA'i, with kesr, is syn. with haAti, Give; [or changed from this verb;] and is thus inflected: sing. masc. haA='i, fem. hAy^iY; dual. masc. and fem. haAy^iyaA; pl. masc. haAw^uwA, fem. haAy^iyna: (S, K: like haAtuwA; haAtiyaA; haAtiY, haAti, haAtiyna: ' holding the place of t: S.) ― -b3- But haA='a, with fet-h, is syn. with haAka, Take; [or changed from this word;] and is thus inflected: sing. masc. haA='a, fem. haA='i, without Y; dual masc. and fem. haAw^umaA; pl. masc. haAw^umu, [so in the K, and so I find it in one copy of the S: in another copy of the latter, haAw^umu, as it is pronounced before a conjunctive A; for instance, in the Kur, lxix, 19:] fem. haAw^un~a, (S, K:) or haAw^umona: (L:) [which last does not exactly correspond with the model haAkun~a: but I think it most probable that haAkun~a is changed by idghám from haAkumona; and in like manner, that haAw^un~a is changed from haAw^umona:] (like haAka, haAki; haAkumaA; haAkumo, haAkun~a:
hawuAa holding the place of k: S:) also, sing. masc. haA^o (originally haA='u, S), fem. haAy^iY; dual masc. (S) and fem. (S, K) haAA=; (S, K;) pl. masc. haAw^uwA, (S,) fem. haA^ona: (S, K:) also, sing. masc. and fem. haA^o; dual. masc. haAA=, fem. haAy^iyaA; pl. masc. haAw^uwA, fem. haAw^un~a. (TA.) ― -b4- [See a saying of 'Omar cited voce ramaA='N, in art. rmY.] ― -b5- When it is said to thee haA='a Take, thou sayest maA A^ahaA='u What shall I take? syn. maA A=xu*u; and maA A^uhaA='u, in the pass. form, What shall I receive, or be given? syn. maA A^uEoTaY. (S.) [Also, in the TA, it seems to be said that A^ahaA='a signifies A^aEoTaY He gave, or made to take: but this is uncertain; as the former verb is there written AhA'a, and the latter is without the syll. points]. ― -b6- haA='a is also syn. with lb~ayoka At thy service! &c.. (K, TA.) -A2- laA haA='a A@ll~`hi *aA, or, more chastely, laA haA A@ll~`hi *aA, or the former is a barbarism; originally laA waA@ll~`hi h`*aA: hA and *A are separated, and the name of God is introduced between them; (K;) and the meaning is No, by God, (I did not) this! (S, art. hA, q. v.) or No, by God, this (is what I swear by)! (K.)

hawo'N *
Mind; purpose; aspiration; desire; ambition. (S, K, TA.) Ex. baEiy*u Alhawo'i A person of far-reaching aspiration, or ambition. (S, TA.) ― -b2- hawo'N Penetrating judgment. (K.) ― -b3- waqaEa fY hawoy^iY, and ↓ huwy^iY, It occurred to my mind, or imagination. (K.)
huwo'N * : See preceding sentence.

muhowaA^an~N * (S, K) and ↓ mahoway^in~N (K) A wide desert, or wide tract of the kind called SaHoraA='. (S. K.) ― -b2- Custom: syn. EaAdapN. (K.) ― -b3- A part of the night. (K.) ― -b4- The mention of mhwA^n~ in this art., by J, says IB, and F after him, is wrong; for its measure is mfwE~l; the w being an augmentative letter. [But if so, F has himself done wrong, in mentioning it, not only here, but also in art. hwn, (where, if the w be augmentative, it is equally inappropriate,) as though it were a quasi-quadriliteral-radical word, of the measure mfEAul~.] ISd gives it as formed by transposition from the root hnA^, and explains it as signifying a wide place. (TA.)
muhoway^in~N * : see muhowaA^an~N.
1 huwba * : see art. hyb.

hawobN *
Distance; remoteness. (S, K.) ― -b2- tarakotuhu fiY hawobK daAbrK, and daAbirK ↓ huwbK, (S, K,) or, accord. to some, as stated in a marginal note in a copy of the S, in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeya, fY hwbi dAbrK, with hwb as a prefixed n., (TA,) I left him in such a place that it was not known where he was: (S, K:) hwb dAyr being the name of a land over which the Jinn, or genii, have obtained ascendancy: (TA:) or the correct reading is [hwt] with t. (K.) -A2- hawobN A stupid, or foolish, and loquacious, man: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) pl. A^ahowaAbN. (TA.) -A3- hawobN The heat, or burning, of fire; (S, K;) and its flaming, or blazing; of the dial. of El-Yemen: also, the heat, or burning of the sun: also of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
huwbN * : see hawobN.
mahuwbN * : see art. hyb.
2 hw~t bihi * , inf. n. tahowiytN, He called out to him; (K;) saying Hawota Hawota: (TA, art. Hyt:) he cried out to him, and called him. (S.) A dial. form of hy~t. (TA.) [See hay~ata.]
hawotapN * : see what follows.

huwtapN * (K) and ↓ hawotapN (S, K) A low, or depressed, tract, or piece, of land: (S, K:) or a deep place: (IAth:) or the space between two mountains: (IAar:) pl. huwatN (as in the CK) or huwt (as in the TA.) It may be said that huwtN and huwatN are coll. gen. ns. [of each of which the n. un. is with p]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also huwtapN A road, or way, descending to water. (IAar.) ― -b3- Sab~a All~`hu Ealayohi wamowatapF ↓ hawotapa an imprecation, respecting which ISd says, I know not what is hwtp here. [It probably signifies A cry, such as destroyed the tribe of Thamood: see haw~ata.] (TA.)

maDaY hiytaA'N mina All~ayoli *
A certain time, or portion, of the night passed. Accord. to Aboo- 'Alee, hytA' is of the measure fiEolaA'N, and quasicoordinate to sirodaAHN, and belonging to this art. (TA.)

hiytaAh hiytaAh *
A cry by which the Arabs urge on a dog against the game which they are pursuing. (TA.) [In the L written hayotaA', and mentioned in art. hyt.]

tarakahumo hawovFA bawovFA *
He made a great slaughter among them. (TA.) [See art. bwv.]

hawovapN *
A thirst. (K.)

1 hawija * , aor.
hawaja , inf. n. hawajN; (L;) and ↓ thw~j; (A, TA;) He (a man) was characterized by what is termed hawajN, (L, A,) which is similar to hawakN; (L;) i. e., stupidity, foolishness, or paucity of sense: (JK, L:) tallness, combined with hastiness, and stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense: (S:) or tallness, with stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense and levity or fickleness or unsteadiness, and hastiness: (K:) or tallness, with levity or fickleness or unsteadiness, and hastiness: (TA:) or tallness, (A,) or excessive tallness, (L,) with stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense. (L.)

4 Ahwjhu *
He found him to be such a man as is termed A^ahowaju. (L.)
5 tahaw~aja see 1.
hawajN * : see 1. ― -b2- fY fulaAnK EawajN, and hawajN, are syn., [meaning In such a one is a deviation from rectitude]. (AA, L.)
haAjapN * a dial. form of HaAjapN; but of weak authority. (L, from a trad.)

A^ahowaju * A man characterized by what is termed hawajN; (S, L, &c.;) stupid, foolish, or having little sense: (JK, L:) or tall, with hastiness, and stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense, &c.: (S, &c.:) fem. hawojaA='u: (A:) [pl. huwjN.] ― -b2- A^ahowaju AlT~uwli (tropical:) A man exceedingly, or excessively, tall. (A.) ― -b3- Also A^ahowaju (tropical:) A courageous man, who throws himself into a scene of war. (A.) ― -b4- A^ahowaju (tropical:) A he-camel that goes quickly, as though characterized by what is termed hawajN: fem. hawojaA='u: [pl. huwjN:] or the fem. epithet only is used, applied to a camel; and you say naAqapN hawojaA='u; (TA;) i. e., a she-camel that goes quickly, &c., as explained above; (S, K;) and that does not always care where she puts her feet on the ground. (A.) ― -b5- riyHN hawojaA='u (tropical:) Any wind that blows violently: (IAar:) or a wind of which the blasts are closely consecutive, as though characterized by what is termed hawajN: or a wind that carries away the dust, and makes a trace upon the ground like that made by dragging the skirt: (TA:) or a wind that tears up the tents: (S, K:) pl. huwjN. (S.)

1 haAda * , aor. yahuwdu, (S, L, &c.,) inf. n. hawodN, (S, L, K, &c.,) He returned (IAar, A, L, Msb) from evil to good or from good to evil: (IAar, L:) he repented, (S, A, L, K;) and returned to the truth; (S, L, K;) as also ↓ thw~d: (L:) and the latter, he repented and did righteously. (AO, S, A, L.) ― -b2- hudonaA A_ilayoka We have turned unto Thee with repentance. (Kur, vii, 155.] So accord. to Mujáhid and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr and Ibráheem. (L.) It is made trans. by means of AlY because implying the meaning of rajaEonaA. (ISd, L.) ― -b3- haAda, (S, A, L,) aor. yahuwdu, inf. n. hawodN; (L;) and ↓ tahw~d; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) He became a Jew; (S, A, L, K;) he became of the Jewish religion. (L, Msb.)

2 hw~duh * , (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (S,) He made him (his son [for instance] Msb) a Jew; (S, L, Msb;) he turned him to the religion of the Jews; (L, K;) taught him that religion, and initiated him in it. (L.) -A2- tahowiydN The talking together of jinn, or genii: (L, K:) so termed because of the gentleness and weakness of their voices. (L.) ― -b2- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He reiterated his voice, or quavered, or trilled, gently. (Ibn-Jebeleh, L, K.) ― -b3- hw~d, (L,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (K,) He sang; syn. gan~aY: (Aboo-Málik, L:) he sang, or gladdened, and diverted; syn. Tar~aba waA^alohaY. (K.) See also muhaw~idN. -A3- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He went, or proceeded, gently, or in a leisurely manner, (S, L, K,) like the manner termed dabiybN: from AlhawaAdapu. (S, L, K.) It is said in a trad., A^asoriEuwA Alma$oYa fiY AljanaAzapi walaA tuhaw~iduwA kamaA tuhaw~idu Alyahuwdu wAln~aSaAraY [Make ye your pace to be quick at a funeral, and go ye not in a gentle or leisurely manner like as go the Jews and the Christians]. (S.) See also 5. ― -b2- hw~d, (L,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (S, L, K,) It beverage, or wine,) intoxicated (S, L, K) a person: and rendered him languid, and caused him to sleep. (L.) ― -b3- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN and tahowaAdN; (L, K;) and ↓ thw~d; (TA;) He uttered a weak, gentle, (L, K,) and languid, (L,) voice. (L, K.) ― -b4- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN (S, L, K) and tahowaAdN; and ↓ thw~d; (K;) He was low, not loud, in speech, or utterance. (S, L, K) ― -b5- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN (L, K) and tahowaAdN; and
↓ thw~d; (L;) He was slow, or tardy, in his pace, (L, K,) and gentle. (L.) ― -b6- hw~d He (a man) rested; or was still, quiet, or at rest. (Aboo-Málik, L.) ― -b7- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He slept. (S, L.) ― -b8- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN and tahowaAdN; and ↓ thw~d; He was gentle; he acted, or behaved, in a gentle manner. (L.) ― -b9- Also, The murmuring and gentle sounding of the wind over sand. (L.) -A4- hw~d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He ate of a camel's hump; (K;) or what is termed hawadap. (TA.)

3 hAwdhu * , (A,) inf. n. muhaAwadapN. (S, A, L, K,) He made peace with him; reconciled himself with him; (A;) syn. of the inf. n. muwaAdaEapN; (A, L;) in the K, muwaAEadapN, which is a mistake; (TA;) and muSaAlaHapN, (S, L,) and muhaAdanapN: (TA:) and also muraAjaEapN [app. signifying the restoring a person, or taking him back, into one's favour]. (TA.) ― -b2- He inclined towards him reciprocally; syn. maAyalahu: and haAwadaA They two inclined each towards the other; syn. maAyalaA: (TK:) syn. of the inf. n. mumaAyalapN. (S, L.) ― -b3- He returned to him, or it, time after time; syn. EaAwadahu: (TK:) syn. of the inf. n. muEaAwadapN. (K.)

5 tahaw~ada see 1 and 2. ― -b2- thw~d fiY ma$oyihi He walked gently, imitating the motions of the Jews in their reciting or reading. (El-Basáïr.) See also 2. ― -b3- thw~d He became allied, or allied himself, or sought to ally himself, (tawaS~ala, K, and taqar~aba, ElBasáïr,) by a bond of relationship; or by some other sacred or inviolable bond or tie, or a quality &c. to be regarded as sacred or inviolable or rendering him entitled to respect or reverence. (K, El-Basáïr.) See also mutahaw~idN.
Alhuwdu * : see yahuwdu.
hawodapN * : see hawadapN.

hawadapN *
A camel's hump: (S, K:) or the base of the hump: (Sh, L:) as also ↓ hawodapN: (L:) pl. hawadN: (S, L, K:) [or rather, this is a coll. gen. n., and hawadapN is the n. un.].

hawaAdapN *
Gentleness; lenity; (A, L, K;) and that kind of conduct whereby one hopes to effect the adjustment of an affair between a people: (L, K:) quietness: (L:) peace, or reconciliation: inclination, or affection: (S, L:) favour, or partiality: (L:) facilitation, whereby a person is indulged in an affair. (L, K.) Ex. laA taA^oxu*uhu fiY A@ll~`hi hawaAdapN Quietness with respect to a restrictive ordinance of God, with favour or partiality towards any one, will not affect him, or influence him. And laA taA^oxu*uhu fiyka hawaAdapN Favour or partiality with respect to thee will not affect him, or influence him. (L, each from a trad.) ― -b2- hawaAdapN also signifies A sacred or inviolable bond or tie; or a quality &c. to be regarded as sacred or inviolable, or rendering one entitled to respect or reverence: and a bond of relationship. (L.)

haAy^idN *
Returning (Msb) [from evil to good or from good to evil: see 1:] repenting and returning to the truth: (S, L:) pl. huwdN, (S, A, L, Msb,) like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN. (S, L, Msb.)

yahuwdu * and Alyahuwdu and ↓ Alhuwdu [the second of which is the most common,] signify the same, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) A certain tribe; [namely, the Jews:] (L:) yahuwdu is said by some to be originally yahuw*u, and arabicized by the change of * into d; but ISd disapproves of this assertion: others say, that it is from haAda “ he repented: ” (L:) it is imperfectly decl., because it is a proper name and of the measure of a verb; and [of the fem. gen., as it is said to be in the S and L,] because it means a qabiylap: but it is allowable to prefix to it the art. Al, and to say Alyahuwdu: (Msb:) this, however, is allowable only on the ground of its being, with the art. prefixed, for Alyahuwdiy~uwna; for it is of itself determinate: (S, L:) [thus] yahuwdu is [as it were] pl. of ↓ yahuwdiY~N; (L;) which is the rel. n. of yhwd, or, accord. to Sgh, of yahuwdaA [or Judah], thus written by him with the unpointed d in this instance, the son of yaEoquwb [or Jacob]: (Msb:) yahuwdu (sometimes, TA) has yahodaAnN as a pl.: (K:) this pl. occurs in a poem of Hassán: (TA:) Fr, says, of huwdFA, in the Kur, ii, 105, that it is for yahuwdFA [app. a mistake for yahuwda]; or that it may be pl. of haAy^idN. (L.)
yahuwdiY~N * : see yahuwdu.

Alyahuwdiy~apu *
The Jewish religion. (L.)
ginaA='N muhaw~idN * [in some copies of the S, muhaw~adN,] A low, not loud, singing. (S, L.) ― -b2- muhaw~idN also signifies Gladdening, and diverting; syn. muToribN and mulohK. (IAar, L.)

mutahaw~idN *
Allied, or allying himself, or seeking to ally himself, (mutawaS~ilN, IAar, Sh,) by what is termed hawaAdapN. (IAar, Sh, L.) See 5.

Alhawo*apu * , (L, K,) or hawo*apu, [without the art. Al, as a proper name,] (S, L,) written by Ed-Demeeree with damm, but fault has been found with him for this, (MF,) [The bird called] the qaTaAp: (S, L, K:) or, as some say, the female qTAp: (L:) or hawo*apu, (as a determinate noun) is the name of a certain bird, (L, K,) different from the above: (L:) pl. huwa*N, (as in the CK and a MS copy of the K) or hawo*N, formed by eliding the augmentative letter: (TA:) [and this seems to be the correct reading; for it occurs in a verse, cited in the TA, in which the measure required it to be of one syllable: it therefore appears that hawo*N is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p.]

1 haArah * , (K,) [aor. yahuwruhu,] inf. n. haworN, (TA,) He threw it down; pulled it down; pulled it to pieces; or demolished it; namely, a building; (K;) and in like manner, a jurof [i. e. an abrupt, water-worn, bank, rising by the bed of a torrent or stream]; (TA [in which huw^uwrN is given as an inf. n. of this verb; but it is more probably an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only, agreeably with analogy;]) as also ↓ hw~rhu, (S, A,) the pronoun relating to a building, (A,) and to a jurof; (S;) and hy~rhu [in illustration of which see what is said of thy~r, below]; (S, art. hyr;) and ↓ thw~rhu, in which the pronoun relates to the upper part of a jurof, or to the brink of a well. (TA.) ― -b2- haAra Alqawoma, (K,) aor. yahuwruhumo, inf. n. haworN, (TA,) (tropical:) He slew the people, and threw them down prostrate, one upon another, (K,) like as when a jurof falls down. (TA.) And [in like manner you say,] Daraba fulaAnFA fahaArahu (assumed tropical:) He smote such a one and prostrated him; as also ↓ hw~rhu. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- haAra, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yahuwru, inf. n. haworN (S, Msb) and huw^uwrN, (S,) It became thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, or demolished; or it fell in ruins, or to pieces; (S, A, K;) said of a building, (K,) and of a jurof [explained above]; (S, A;) as also ↓ AnhAr and ↓ thw~r (S, A, K) and thy~r, (K,) which last has Y as being interchangeable with w, or it may be of the measure tafayoEala [originally tahayowara]: (TA:) or it fell; it fell, or tumbled, down; it collapsed; broke down; said of a building; (TA;) as also ↓ AnhAr and ↓ thw~r; (Msb, TA;) said of a building, (TA,) and of a jurof, (Msb,) or of the upper part of the latter, and of the brink of a well; (TA;) [and ↓ Aihotawara, q. v., probably signifies the same:] or it cracked, without falling; said of a jurof: (Msb:) or it cracked in its hinder part, remaining yet in its place; said of a building. (TA.)
2 hw~rhu * : see haArahu, in two places.

5 thw~r * : see haAra, in two places; in the former of which, thy~r is also mentioned as syn. with tahw~r. ― -b2- (tropical:) He plunged, or fell, into an affair with little care [for the consequence thereof]: (S, K:) or thw~r fiY AlA^umuwri he plunged, or fell, into affairs without thought, or reflection, or consideration: (A:) or tahaw~urN is a state, or condition, adventitious to the irascible faculty, by reason of which one ventures upon affairs not fit, or meet, to be ventured upon; as the fighting with unbelievers
when they are more than double the number of the Muslims. (KT.) -A2- thw~rhu: see haArahu.
7 A_inohawara see haAra, in two places.
8 Aihotawara * : see haAra, last signification. ― -b2- It (a thing, S) perished. (S, K.)

haAy^irN * and haArK, (S, A, Msb, K,) the latter formed by transposition from the former, [first into haAriYN, and then into haArK,] (S, TA,) like as $aAy^iku Als~ilAHi is changed into $aAkiY Als~ilAHi, (S,) applied to a building, (K,) and to a jurof, [explained above, (see haArahu,)] (S, A, Msb,) Becoming thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, or demolished: (S, A, K:) or falling; falling, or tumbling, down: (IAar:) or cracking, without falling: (Msb:) or cracking in its hinder part, remaining yet in its place. (TA.) See an ex. of the latter voce jaforN: and another in the Kur, ix. 110.]
mutahaw~irN * A man plunging, or falling, or who plunges, or falls, into an affair with little care [for the consequences thereof]. (S.) See 5.

hawasN *
Somewhat of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession, (S, A, K,) in the head: (A:) or a vertigo, or giddiness, and confused noise, in the head. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Hence used by the vulgar to signify Hope. (TA.)

mahaw~asN *
Affected with somewhat of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- A man who talks to himself. (A.) ― -b3- Sometimes, One who is affected with melancholy, and with vain, or unprofitable, suggestions. (TA.) ― -b4- And One who occupies himself with the science of alchemy. (TA.)

1 haA$a * , aor. yahuw$u, inf. n. hawo$N, (S, A, Msb,) It (a company of men) was, or became, in a state of conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension: (Msb:) he, or it, (a number of people,) fell into a bad state, or state of disorder or disturbance; as also hawi$a, like samiEa; [indicating that its aor. is
hawa$a , and its inf. n. as above;] and ↓ thw~$: (TA:) it (a company of men, S, A) was, or became, roused, or excited; (A, TA;) in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance; (S, A, TA;) and in like manner, ↓ haw~a$a, said of the belly, it was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation, &c., by reason of leanness: (S:) or hawi$a, like samiEa, [see above,] (K,) aor.
hawa$a , inf. n. hawo$N, (TK,) he (a man, TK) was, or became in a state of commotion, agitation, &c.; or his belly became small, syn. Sagura, (K, TA, [or empty, (Sagura being perhaps a mistranscription for Safira, for it is said in another part of this art. in the TA that Alhawo$u signifies “ the belly's being empty, ”)] by reason of leanness; from IF: (TA:) or it (the belly) became so. (IF, TA.) ― -b2- haA$ati AlA_ibilu, (JK, TA,) or Alxayolu, (A,) fY AlgaArapi, (JK, A,) aor. tahuw$u, (JK,) inf. n. hawo$N, (JK, TA,) The camels, (JK, TA,) or the horses, (A,) took fright, and ran away at random, (JK, A, TA,) and became dispersed, (TA,) or separated themselves, (JK,) and went to and fro, (JK, A,) in the hostile sudden attack made by a party of armed horsemen. (JK, A, TA.) ― -b3- ha$otu A_ilaY fulaAnK I became agile or brisk, and advanced towards such a one. (TA.) And haA$a A^aholu AlHarobi baEoDuhumo libaEoDK The warriors became agile or brisk, and hastened, one to another; [in like manner] ↓ thAw$wA. (A.) -A2- Also, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He collected: and mixed, or confused, or confounded. (TA.) You say, hu$otu maAlFA HaraAmFA I collected unlawful wealth. (Sgh, TA.) And haA$ahumo and ↓ haw~a$ahumo He mixed, or confused, or confounded, them; and collected them hence and thence. (A.) See also 2.

2 hw~$ * : see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see 5. -A2- Also, haw~a$otuhumo I occasioned variance between them, or among them. (Msb.) And hw~$ bayonahumo He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension, between them, or among them. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb,) hw~$, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tahowiy$N, (K,) He mixed, confused, or confounded, (S, Msb, K, TA,) a company of men, (S, TA,) one with another; (TA;) and general rules; (Msb;) and anything. (S.) See also 1, last sentence: and see $aw~a$a. [Hence also,] hw~$t Alr~iyHu biAlt~uraAbi The wind brought the dust of various sorts [mixed together]. (S, * IF, K.)

3 haAwa$ahumo *
He mixed, mingled, or consorted, with them: (K:) or did so to create, or excite, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension; or to make mischief: (TA:) and muhaAwa$apN signifies conflicting; like munaAwa$apN. (TA, art. nw$.)

5 thw~$ * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also thw~$wA They mixed, or mingled, together; or became mixed, confused, or confounded, together; as also ↓ thAw$wA; (K;) and ↓ haw~a$uwA. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- And thw~$wA Ealayohi They collected themselves together against him. (IF, Msb, K.)
6 thAw$wA * : see 1, near the end: ― -b2- and see 5.

hawo$N *
A large number: (S, K:) or, as the women of Temeem say, a multitude of men; and of beasts of carriage; as also bawo$N: (Aboo- 'Admán:) and men collected together in war. (TA.) You say, ↓ jaA='a biAlhawo$i AlhaAy^i$i He came with multitude, or the multitude; (K;) like as you say, jaA='a biAlbawo$i AlbaAy^i$i. (TA.)

hawo$apN *
Conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension: (A 'Obeyd, S, A, Msb, K:) excitement: commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance: (S, A, K:) and confusion: (A, Msb, K:) and ↓ huwaA$apN is like hawo$apN; (TA;) or signifies war. (JK.) You say, waqaEato hawo$apN fiY Als~uwqi [Conflict and faction, &c., happened in the market]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., A_iy~aAkumo wahawo$aAti All~ayoli wahawo$aAti AlA^asowaAqi (S, TA) Beware ye of the misfortunes, calamities, or evil accidents, of night; and of the wrong courses, and trickery and robbery, of the markets. (TA.) hawa$aAtu Als~uwqi, thus related by Th, but not explained by him, is thought by ISd to mean The confusion of the market, and the defrauding there practised in buying and selling. (TA.) See also hayo$apN in two places.

huwaA$apN *
A mixed, or confused, assembly, company, or assemblage, of men; ('Arrám;) as also ↓ hawiy$apN: (K, * TA:) and huwaA$aAtN, [the pl. of the former,] collections of men, and of camels, (S, K,) mixed, or confounded, together: (S:) and what is collected of unlawful wealth or property; (K, * TA;) and of lawful. (TA.) See also mahaAwi$u. -A2- See also hawo$apN.
hawiy$apN * : see hawaA$apN.
