haw~aA$N * and haw~aA$apN Camels unlawfully collected: (JK:) or the latter, camels taken from this and that place: (TA:) and the latter also, camels taking fright and running away at random. (JK.) See also haAy^i$N.

haAy^i$N * : see hawo$N. -A2- A_ibilN hawaAy^i$u, [pl. of haAy^i$apN,] Camels taking fright and running away at random, in a state of confusion, attacked by a party of armed horsemen: (Lth:) or taking fright and running away at random, (JK, A,) separating themselves, (JK,) and going to and fro. (JK, A.) See also haw~aA$N. -A3- haAy^i$apN A great viper. (TA.)
tahowaA$N * : see mahaAwi$u.
tahowiy$N * : see mahaAwi$u.
tahaAwu$N * and tahaAwi$N: see mahaAwi$u.
mahuw$N * : see mahaAwi$u.

mahaAwi$u *
What is gotten by force or theft: (K:) or any wealth, or property, (S,) that is gotten by unlawful means, (JK, S,) such as force and theft and the like: (S:) pl. of ↓ mahuw$N: (A:) or as though pl. of this latter word, as signifying collected; and mixed, confused, or confounded. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano A^aSaAba maAlFA mino
mahaAwi$a A^a*ohabahu A@ll~`hu fiY nahaAbira [Whoso getteth wealth, or property, of such as is unlawfully acquired, God will make it to pass away in places of destruction]: (S:) but this is variously related; some saying ↓ tahaAwi$a; and some, tahaAwu$K; and some, nahaAwi$a, with n, which is explained in the K as signifying maZaAlim: the relation given in the S is that which is commonly known by the lexicologists; but all are correct, excepting that tahaAwi$, with t, and with a kesreh to the w, is disapproved by some of the lexicologists: (TA:) this last word is a contraction of tahaAwiy$u, pl. of ↓ tahowaiA$N, of the measure tafoEaAlN from Alhawo$u, (K, TA,) meaning “ the collecting ”; and “ mixing, ” “ confusing, ” or “ confounding ”: (TA:) or from hu$otu maAlFA HaraAmFA. (Sgh, TA.) A poet says,
taA^okulu maAjamaEota mino tahowaA$i
[Thou eatest what thou hast collected of things unlawfully acquired]. (Sgh, TA.)

div2.head: hwE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 haA='a * , aor. yahaA='u and yahiyo'u, (K; the latter not of respectable authority, Lh;) inf. n. hayoy^apN, He was, or became, of good, or goodly, form or appearance, or other properties denoted by the term hayoy^ap, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- [hayuw^a, accord. to the K, signifies the same: but see below.] ― -b3- hayuw^a, accord. to IHsh and others, the only verb of this form whose medial radical letter is Y: (MF:) accord. to the K, syn. with haA='a, in a sense indicated above: but IJ states that it has a superlative sense; that it is to be classed with qaDuwa “ excellent [or how excellent (see baTuw^a voce buTaA=na)] is he in his judging! ” and ramuwa “ excellent [or how excellent] is he in his throwing, or shooting! ” [wherefore it signifies Excellent, or how excellent, is he in his form or appearance! &c.;] and that it is, like qaDuwa [and ramuwa], invariable [as to person, tense, and mood]. He observes that, as a verb of the measure faEula is formed from one whose final radical letter is Y, [as qaDuwa and ramuwa from qaDaY and ramaY,] so is this formed on the same measure from a verb whose medial radical letter is Y: and that it is invariable [as to person, tense, and mood,] because of its resemblance, in its superlative sense, to the class of verbs of wonder, and to niEoma and biy^osa. He further remarks, that they [the Arabs] have abstained from forming a verb on the measure faEula [variable as to person, tense, and mood,] from one whose medial radical letter is Y, fearing to make what is difficult to pronounce still more so; for in that case they would be obliged to say A^abuwEu buEotu, and buwEaA; and, as would also happen if a variable verb of the same measure were formed from one whose final radical letter is Y, the change of Y into w, which is more difficult to pronounce, would thus become frequent. (TA.) ― -b4- haA='a A_ilayohi, aor. yahaA='u, inf. n. hiyoy^apN, He desired, longed for, longed to see, him or it. (K.)

2 hy~A^ * , inf. n. tahoyiy^apN and tahoyiYo'N, [primarily signifies He invested him with, or made him to have, hayo'ap, as meaning garb, guise, &c. See Bd xviii. 9. ― -b2- And hence,] He prepared, provided, disposed, arranged, or put into a right, or good state, &c. (S, K.) [And hence, He rendered an affair feasible, or practicable; he facilitated it.]

5 thy~A^ * [He, or it, was, or became, prepared, provided, disposed, arranged, or put into a right or good state, &c. And hence, It (an affair) was, or became, feasible, or practicable: and it (a thing) was, or became, attainable, or within power or reach.] ― -b2- thy~A^ liloA^amori; and haA=' lahu, (S, K,) aor. yahaA='u (K) and yahiYo'u, (S, K,) inf. n. hayoy^apN; (S;) He prepared himself for the thing. (K.) Ex. waqaAlato hiy^otu laka And she said, I have prepared myself for thee: accord. to one reading [for hayota, in the Kur, xii. 23]. (Akh, S.) ― -b3- [See also thn~A^.] ― -b4- thy~A^ lahu AlA^amoru, (Msb, K, art. AtY, &c.,) or Al$~aYo'N, (S, art. AtY, &c.,) The thing, or affair, was, or became, feasible, or practicable, to him; and the thing was attainable.] ― -b5- thy~A^ lilobukaA='i [He was ready, or about, to weep: a phrase of frequent occurrence; like A^araAda AlbukaA='a, and ham~a biAlobukaA'i.] (S, art. jh$, &c.)

6 tahaAyaw^uwA EalaY *`lika *
They agreed together upon that, or to do that. (K, * TA.)

haYo'N * and hiYo'N The calling, or a call, to food and beverage. (K.) ― -b2- The calling, or a call, to camels to drink: (K:) or, [rather,] a call to camels to food, or provender. (TA.) ― -b3- [See arts. jyA^ and hA^.]

yaA haYo'a maA liY * [but see $Y'N] [Oh! what has happened to me?] an expression of regret; haYo'N being a word signifying regret for a thing that passes away from one, or escapes him: (S, TA:) or, (as some say, TA,) an expression of wonder: (K:) see also yaA$aYo'i and yaAfaYo'a, which are syn. with yaAhaYo'a: (TA:) or haYo'a, (accord. to certain of the lexicologists, as related by IB, TA,) is an imperative verbal noun, signifying Attend! (tanab~aho); like Saho, which signifies “ Be silent! ” (K;) the interjection yA being put before it in like manner as it is in the saying of Esh-Shemmakh,
A^alaA yaA A@soqiyaAniY qabola gaArapi sanojaAli
[Come now! O, give me to drink, before the expedition of Sinjáb!]; (TA;) and hY' being indeclinable, with a vowel for its termination to obviate the occurrence of two quiescent letters, and with fet-hah as the final vowel because it is more easy of pronunciation than the others in this case. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [See also art. $yA^.]

hayoy^apN * and ↓ hiyoy^apN Form, fashion, shape, aspect, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineaments; (S, TA;) guise; or external state or condition; (Msb;) state with regard to apparel and the like; or garb; (Lth;) state, condition, or case; quality, mode or manner of being: (K:) pl. hayoA=tN and hiyoA=tN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hasanu Alhayoy^api [of goodly form, aspect, or appearance, guise, state of apparel, garb, &c.]. (S.) ― -b3- [Also, goodliness of form &c.: see 1. See also samotN, for an addition.] ― -b4- [hayoy^apN EaAriDapN, in Logic, An accidental mode.] ― -b5- A^aqiyluwA *awiY AlhayoA=ti EavaraAtihimo, in a trad., signifies, Forgive ye the people of good qualities &c., who keep to one state and way, their slips. It alludes to those who make a slip unwittingly. (TA.)
hiyoy^apN * : see hayoy^apN.
hayiYo'N * : see what next follows.
hay~iy^N * and ↓ hay~iYo'N A person of good, or goodly, form or appearance, or other properties denoted by the term hayoy^ap. (K.)
muhay~aA^N * [Prepared, &c.] ― -b2- Also i. q. zumaA warodN, q. v. (MF, art. wrd.)

mahaAyaA^apN *
A thing respecting which persons have agreed together. (K, TA.)
matahay~iy^apN * A camel that seldom fails of becoming pregnant when she has been covered. (K.)

1 haAbahu * , (S, K, &c.,) first pers. hibotu, originally habiyotu, (S,) aor. yahaAbu, (S, K,) [originally yahoyabu,] and yahiybu, (IKtt, cited by MF,) imp. habo, originally haAbo, (S,) inf. n. hayobapN (S, K, Msb) and mahaAbapN (S, K) and hayobN; (K;) and ↓ AhtAbh and ↓ thy~bh; (K;) [He revered, venerated, respected, honoured, dreaded, or feared, him or it;] he regarded him or it, i. e., anything, TA,) with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; (S, K, * Msb, TA;) and fear; (S, K;) cautious fear, or caution. (K, Msb.) ― -b2- habi Aln~aAsa yahaAbuwka Reverence men, [and] they will reverence thee. (TA.) ― -b3- huwba, in which the original Y is changed into w, [He (a man) was regarded with reverence, veneration, or awe; with fear; or with cautious fear, or caution]. (S, K.)

2 hay~abotuhu A_ilayohi *
I made it to be regarded by him with reverence, veneration, or awe; with fear; or with cautious fear, or caution. (S, K.)

4 AhAb biSaAHibihi * (tropical:) He called his companion. And in like manner, A^ahabotu bihi A_ilaY Alxayori (tropical:) I called him, or invited him, to what was good. (MF.) ― -b2- AhAb biAlA_ibili He called to the camels, in driving them or urging them, by the cry haAbo haAbo. (K.) ― -b3- AhAb biganamihi He (a pastor) cried out to his sheep, or goats, in order that they might stop, or return: and AhAb biAlbaEiyri [He cried out to the camel, for the same purpose]. (S.) AlA_ihaAbapu is The crying out to camels, and calling them. (As and others.) ― -b4- AhAb baAlxayoli He called the horses, or called out to them by the cry haAbi, (so in the S and in a MS. copy of the K: in the CK, haAbo,) or by the cry of habo and habiY, meaning Come! Approach! or Advance boldly! (K.) Az remarks his having heard hAb used [as a cry] only to horses; not to camels. (TA.) See habohaba, in art. hb.

5 tahay~aba see 1. ― -b2- tahay~abaniY It filled me with awe, or fear: (El Jarmee:) it made me to fear: (S, ISd, Msb:) I regarded it with awe, or fear; i. q. tahay~abotuhu: (Th:) I feared it; i. q. xifotuhu. (S, ISd, K.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
wamaAtahay~abuniY AlmawomaApu A^arokabuhaA
A_i*aA tajaAwabati AlA^aSodaA'u biAls~aHari
[And the waterless desert fills me not with awe, or fear; (or makes me not to fear, &c.;) I ride over it when the male owls (?) answer one another at early dawn: thy~bnY being for tatahay~abuniY]. (S, &c.)
8 A_ihotayaba see 1.
habo * (K) and ↓ haAbi and ↓ habiY, (S, K,) [but respecting the second of these words see 4,] Cries to horses, meaning, Come! Approach! (S, K,) or Advance boldly! (K.)
haAbi * and habiY: see habo.
haAbN * (assumed tropical:) A serpent. (K.) ― -b2- haAbN A calling to camels, in driving, or urging, them, by the cry haAbo haAbo. (K.) ― -b3- See 4.
hayobaAnN * : see haAy^ibN, and mahiybN.
hayuwbN * : see haAy^ibN, and mahiybN.

hayobapN * and ↓ mahaAbapN: see 1. ― -b2- [As substs., Reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; fear; cautious fear, or caution.] ― -b3- Also, great, reverend, or venerable, dignity; a quality inspiring reverence or veneration or respect or honour; venerableness; awfulness; a quality inspiring dread or awe. (MF.)
hay~abN * : see haAy^ibN.

hay~iabaAnN * : see haAy^ibN. ― -b2- hay~abaAnN (K) or [rather] ↓ hay~ibaAnN, (TA, [see haAy^ibN]) A he-goat: (K:) explained by the word tayosN; but this is a signification not found [by SM] elsewhere, and appears to be a mistake for manotafi$N; for in the L and other lexicons we find the word explained by munotafi$N xafiyfN, Scattered, and light; with a citation of the following verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh:
tamuj~u All~ugaAma Alhay~aibaAna kaA^an~ahu
janaY Eu$arK tanofiyhi A^a$odaAquhaA Alhudolu
[She ejects from her mouth the scattered and light froth, as though it were plucked fruit of the 'oshar which the flabby sides of her mouth cast forth:] and we also find, in the R, quTonN hy~bAnN explained as signifying cotton that is plucked, or teased with the fingers, so as to become scattered; syn. mntf$: or hy~bAn signifies, in the abovecited verse, accord. to some, Light, [which signification is also given in the K, but in the CK displaced; following, instead of preceding, the word Alr~aAEiY, and without w before it;] and separated into small particles: (TA:) [or] the froth of the mouth of camels; (Az, K;) i. q. lugaAmN: (Mj, Sifr es-Sa'ádeh:) Az cites the above verse; and says, that the fruit of the Eu$ar [or asclepias gigantea] comes forth like a small pomegranate, and, when burst open, discloses what resembles [white] raw silk; to which the poet likens the froth of the camel's mouth. (TA.) ― -b3- hay~abaAnN (or hay~ibaAnN, TA,) A pastor. (K, from Es-Seeráfee.) [Accord. to the CK, a light, or an active pastor: but see above.] ― -b4- hay~abaAnN (or ↓ hay~ibaAnN, TA,) Dust, or earth: syn. turaAbN. (K.) ― -b5- See haAy^bN.
hay~ibaAnN * : see hay~abaAnN.
hay~aAbN * : see haAy^ibN.
hay~aAbapN * : see haAy^ibN.

haAy^ibN * [act. part. n. of haAba, Regarding with reverence, veneration, dread, or awe; with fear; with cautious fear, or caution;] fearing men. (K.) This is the original [simple] epithet. (TA.) ― -b2- The following, which are explained in the K in the same manner as the above, are intensive epithets: (TA:) namely ↓ hayuwbN (S, K) and hayuwbapN, (S, L,) [in which the p is added to strengthen the intensiveness,] and ↓ hay~aAbN and hay~aAbapN, (S, K,) in which p is added for the purpose above mentioned, (TA,) and ↓ hay~ibN, (K,) which may be contracted into hayotN, (TA,) and ↓ hayobaAnN (K) and ↓ hay~ibaAnN (S, K) and ↓ hay~abaAnN; (K;) of which last two forms, the latter only is admitted by some of the learned; but MF admits only the former of them; asserting fayoEalaAnN to be unknown as the measure of an unsound word, like as fyaEilaAn is unknown as that of a sound word except in extr. instances; (TA;) [Having much reverence, veneration, dread, or awe; much fear; much cautious fear, or caution:] fearing men [much]: (K:) a coward, who regards men with awe, or fear, &c.: (S:) [The last of these epithets is also explained in the CK as signifying having much fear, or very fearful; (kaviyru Alxawofi;) and a coward: but in the TA and in a MS copy of the K, Alxwf is omitted; and in the TA is added by the author, after kvyr, the words mn kl~ $Yu; as though the meaning of the word were “ much, or many, of any things: ” the correct reading seems to be the former, and the meaning intended by SM, having much fear, or very fearful, of everything: in like manner] ↓ hayuwbN signifies a man who fears everything. (TA.) ― -b3- ↓ AlA_iymaAnu hayuwbN [Faith is fearful, or very fearful; i. e.,] he who possesses faith fears acts of disobedience: occurring in a trad.: (S:) in this case, hywb is used in the sense of an act. part. n.: or it signifies [faith is feared; or regarded with reverence, &c.; i. e.,] he who possesses faith is feared, or regarded with reverence, &c.: in which case hywb is used in the sense of a pass. part. n. (TA.)
h`*aA Al$~aYo'u mahoyabapN laka * [This thing is a cause of awe, or fear, to thee]. (S.)
mahaAbN * : see mahiybN.
mahaAbapN * : see hayobapN.
mahuwbN * : see mahiybN.

mahiybN * and ↓ mahuwbN, (S, K,) the former agreeable with rule, (TA,) and ↓ hayuwbN, (K) [respecting which see also haAy^ibN,] and ↓ hayobaAnN, (Th, IM, K,) [Regarded with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; with fear; with cautious fear, or caution;] a man whom others regard with reverence, &c.; (S;) a man whom others fear. (K.) ― -b2- makaAnN mahuwbN, formed from the verb huwba, the original Y being changed into w (S, K,) A place regarded with awe, or fear; (S;) a place in which one is impressed with awe, or fear: as also ↓ makaAnN mahaAbN: (S, K:) mahaAbN signifies a place of awe, or fear. (IB.) ― -b3- Almahiybu and Almahuwbu and ↓ Almutahay~abu (assumed tropical:) The lion: (K:) because regarded with awe, or fear, by men. (TA.)
Almutahay~abu * : see Almahiybu.

2 hy~t bihi * , (S, K,) inf. n. tahoyiytN, (TA,) as also hw~t, (S,) He cried out to him, and called
him, (S, K,) saying, hayota hayota; or saying yaAho yaAho, which is a cry by which a pastor calls his companion from afar; or, accord. to AZ, saying yaA hayaA [or rather yaAhayaAho: see art. yh]. (TA.)

3 haAt *
Give me: (K:) haAti yaA rajulu Give me, O man: (T, S, M:) i. q. A^aEoTiniY: (T, S, M, K:) to two men, haAtiyaA: to a plurality of men, haAtuwA: to a woman, haAtiY: to two women, haAtiyaA: to a plurality of women, haAtiyna: you say haAti lA haAtayota [Give me: mayest thou not give (hereafter)! an imprecation, of the like of which there are many examples]; and haAti A_ino kaAnato bika muhaAtaApN [Give me, if there be in thee (a disposition for) giving]; and maA A^uhAtiyka [I do not give thee], like as you say, maA A^uEaATiyka; but you do not say haAtayotu; nor do you use this verb in a prohibitive manner: [it is used neither affirmatively nor prohibitively:] accord. to Kh, haAti is from A@taY, aor. yuwtiY; the A being changed into h. (S.) [But A@taY is of the measure A^afoEala; and haAti is the imp. from the measure faAEala. See also art. htY, where it is mentioned again in the S and K.]

hayota * an exclamation denoting wonder: the Arabs say, hayota liloHilomi [What forbearing mildness, or clemency!] (L.) ― -b2- hayota laka, (Akh, S, K, &c.,) and hayoti lk, (Akh, K,) and hayota lk, (Akh, IB, K,) and the first letter is sometimes with kesreh; (K;) as is related on the authority of 'Alee, (TA,) [so that you say hiyta and hiyti and hiytu, the first of which three forms is mentioned by Fr, Akh, IB, and the third by Fr, IB; but for the second I find no other authority than that implied above;] of all which, the most common is hayota lk, with fet-hah to the h and t: (Zj:) hayota is of the dial. of Howrán, whence it became introduced into Mekkeh; and hiyta, of the dial. of El-Medeeneh: (Fr:) [imper. verbal ns.] i. q. halum~a, Come! (Akh, S, L, K,) or taEaAla the same, (Fr, Ks,) or A^aqobilo, the same, or Come forward! (L.) It occurs in the Kur, xii. 23; where it is commonly read hayota laka; (Zj;) but 'Alee and Ibn-'Abbás are said to have read hiy^otu laka, with hemzeh. [See art. hyA^.] (TA.) hayota is itself invariable whether used to denote the sing. or pl. or fem. or masc.; but the difference of number is observed in what follows it; for you say hayota lakumaA [Come ye two!] and hayota lakun~a [Come ye women! &c.]: (S:) you also say simply hayota [Come!] and this is also said to signify Hasten! and Set forth journeying through the land, or earth. (TA.) Authorities differ respecting this word; whether it be Arabic or arabicized; and whether it be a noun or a verb; &c. Accord. to AZ, as related by Az, hyt lk is arabicized in the Kur, from the Hebrew hytA kx [app. a mistake for hytA kx, which I suppose to be meant for עַהׇּה לְבׇה “ Now, come! ” occurring in Gen. xxxi. 44]. (TA.)
hayota hayota * : see 2.

hiytN *
A low, or depressed, piece of ground: (K:) a piece of ground having a low, or depressed, bottom: (TA:) i. q. huw~apN and huwtapu. (IAar.)
hiytaA'N * , and hiytaAh: see art. hwt.
hay~aAtN * [Clamorous; calling out often, or much]. (S.)

1 haAva lahu * , aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN and hayavaAnN, He gave him a little, or something little in quantity. (AZ, S, K.) [See also HavaA, in art. Hvw.] ― -b2- haAva fiY kayolihi, inf. n. hiyovN, He gave little in his measure, or in his measuring; i. q. HavaA, inf. n. HavowN: it is like what is termed jizaAfN. (TA.) -A2- haAva, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, It was in a state of motion, or commotion; (S, K;) like haA$a, inf. n. hayo$N. (S.) ― -b2- haAva Alqawomu, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN; and ↓ tahaAyava; The party became intermixed in altercation. (TA.) ― -b3- haAva birijolihi Alt~uraAba, aor. yahiyvu, He dug up the dust, or earth, with his foot. (TA.) ― -b4- haAva, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN: (TA;) and ↓ AsthAv; (K;) He corrupted, or marred; acted corruptly; did mischief; syn. A^afosada. (K, TA.) ― -b5- haAva fY maAlihi, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, He acted corruptly (A^afosada) with his property; (K;) as also EaAva; (TA;) [he scattered and marred his property; squandered it; expended it quickly: see art. Eyv]. ― -b6- Also, [contr.,] He acted rightly with his property. (TA.) ― -b7- haAva fiY $aYo'K He acted corruptly with a thing; and took it without gentleness; (TA;) [as also EaAva]. ― -b8- haAva Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami The wolf did mischief among [or worried] the sheep, or goats; (TA;) [as also EaAva]. -A3- haAva mina AlmaAli, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, He obtained what he wanted of the property. (K.)

3 haAyavahu * , inf. n. muhaAyavahu, He contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in abundance, or multitude; as, for instance, of wealth, or of dependants or followers. (TK.) muhaAyavapN is syn. with mukaAvarahN. (K.) ― -b2- See 10.

5 thy~v *
He gave. (K.) thy~v lahu $ayoy^FA He gave him a thing. (TK.)
6 tahaAoyava see 1.
10 AsthAv * (and ↓ hAyv, TA,) He deemed [a thing] much; syn. A_isotakovara. (K.) AsthAv maA A^aEoTaAhu [He deemed what he gave him much]. (TK.) ― -b2- See 1.

hayovapN *
An assembly, a company, a congregated body, (As, S, K,) of men, or people; like hayo$apN. (As, S.)
haAy^ivapN * The clamour, or confused noise, (jalabap,) of a people. (L.)

muhaAyivN *
Taking much; one who takes much. (K.)

1 haAja * , aor. yahiyju, inf. n. hayojN and hayajaAnN [the most common form]; and hiyaAjN; and ↓ AhtAj, and ↓ thy~j; It (a thing, S) became raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked; syn. vaAra: (S, L, K:) it became so by reason of distress, or difficulty; or of harm, or injury: you say haAja bihi Ald~amu, inf. n. hayojN and hayajaAnN, The blood became roused, or stirred up, in him: (A, L:) and in like manner, Almir~apu the gall, or bile: and AlgubaAru the dust. (A.) See also haAy^ijN. ― -b2- haAja, inf. n. hiyaAjN and huyuwjN and hayajaAnN; and ↓ AhtAj; (tropical:) He (a stallion-camel) became excited by lust; initum appetivit; brayed, and became excited by lust. When this is the case, he becomes lean, and his price is lessened. (L.) ― -b3- haAjato Eayonuhu, (S, art. mrH; and L, art. rmd; &c.) inf. n. hayajaAnN, (K, art. rmd; &c.) His eye became inflamed; painful and swollen; affected with ophthalmia; (L, art. rmd;) i. q. ramida. (S, art. rmd; and L, K, * in the same art.) ― -b4- haAjN bh fahajaAhu (tropical:) [He became excited against him, or attacked him, and satirized him]. (A.) ― -b5- haAja AlhijaA='u bayonahumaA (tropical:) [Satire was excited between them two. (A.) ― -b6- haAjati AlHarobu (inf. n. hayojN, Msb) (tropical:) War became excited, or raised. (A, Msb.) ― -b7- haAja Al$~ar~u bayonahumo (tropical:) Evil become excited among them. (A.) ― -b8- haAja, inf. n. hayojN, He, or it, was in a state of commotion. (L.) ― -b9- haAjati Als~amaA='u famuTironaA The sky became cloudy and windy, and we were rained upon. (TA.) ― -b10- haAja; (S, K;) [followed by an accus., and also by b;] and ↓ hy~j, inf. n. tahoyiyjN, the most common form;] and ↓ haAyaja; (S;) He, or it, raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked, (S, K,) a thing; (S;) syn. A^avaAra. (K.) Thus the first of these verbs is trans. as well as intrans. (S.) All have the same meaning: (S:) or the second has an intensive signification. (Msb.) ― -b11- haAja AlgubaAra, and ↓ hy~jhu, [which is more common,] He raised the dust. (TA.) ― -b12- Al$~ar~a ↓ hy~j (tropical:) He excited evil
among a people. (A) ― -b13- Aln~aAqapa faA@nobaEavato ↓ hay~ajotu I roused the she-camel, and she became roused. (A.) ― -b14- hijotuhu fahaAja I roused him, and he became roused. (TA.) ― -b15- haAjato lahu Ald~aAru Al$~awoqa The dwelling excited his longing desire. (A.) ― -b16- haAja He, or it, disquieted, and scared, a person. (L.) ― -b17- haAj AlA_ibala, inf. n. hayojN, He put the camels in motion, by night, towards the watering-place and pasture. (L.) ― -b18- haAjati AlA_ibilu The camels thirsted. (K.) ― -b19- haAja, (inf. n. hiyaAjN, S, and hayojN, TA,) (tropical:) It (a plant, or herbage,) dried up: (S, K:) [it withered:] it (a leguminous plant) became yellow: (Msb:) or dried up and became yellow: and became tall. (L.) ― -b20- haAjati AlA^aroDu, inf. n. hiyaAjN and hayojN and hayajaAnN, (tropical:) The plants, or herbage, or leguminous plants, of the land dried up. (L.)
2 hay~aja see 1 and 4.
3 hAyjhu * , (TK,) inf. n. hiyaAjN, (S, K,) He fought with him; engaged in a conflict, or combat, with him. (TK.) ― -b2- yawomu AlhiyaAji The day of fight, conflict or combat. (S, K. *) ― -b3- See 1.

4 A^ahaAjati Alr~iyHu Aln~abova * (tropical:) The wind dried up, or caused to dry up, the plants, or herbage: (S, K *:) and [so] ↓ hay~ajatohu. (O, K in art. SwE.) ― -b2- A^ahoyajonaA AlA^aroDa (tropical:) We found the land to have its plants or herbage, dried up. (S, K.)
5 tahay~aja see 1.
6 tahaAyajuwA * (assumed tropical:) They leaped, or sprung up, together, to fight, one against another. (S, K.)
8 A_ihotayaja see 1.
hijo * : see hiyj.

hayojN *
Civil war; or conflict and faction; or discord, or dissension; syn. fitonapN. (L.) See hayojaA='u. ― -b2- Excitement of the blood: or, of coitus: or, of longing desire. (L.) ― -b3- yawomu hayojK A day of wind: or, of clouds, or mist, and rain. (K, TA: [but accord. to some copies of the K, instead of “ and rain, ” “ or, of rain. ”]) ― -b4- haAja lahu hayojN HasanN, said with respect to a cloud, or body of clouds, when first rising; (As;) [meaning, It hath had a good rising, or hath risen well, so as to present, at its first rising, a good, or promising, appearance: an expression like lahu na$o'N HasanN, q. v., art. n$A^]. ― -b5- hayojN, (assumed tropical:) Yellowness: [app. in a plant]: (L:) or a state of drying up. (IAar, L.) See haAy^ijN.
hiyji * , indecl., with kesreh for its termination, and ↓ hijo, Cries by which a she-camel is chidden. (K.) [See also hajohaja, in art. hj.]

haAjapN * A ewe that does not desire the ram: as though deprived of excitement. (M.) ― -b2- haAjapN A female frog. (L, K.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce SubaArapN. ― -b3- An ostrich. (L.) Pl. of both, haAjaAtN. (L. K.) Dim. huwayojapN and huyayojapN. (L.)
hayojaY * : see hayojaA='u.
hayojaA='u * and ↓ hayojaY (S, L, K) and ↓ hayojN and ↓ hiyaAjN (L) the third [as also the fourth] originally an inf. n., (Msb,) War. (S, L, K.)
hay~ijN * : see haAy^ijN.
hiyaAjN * : see 1 and 3; and hayojaA='u.

$ayo'N hayuwjN * , and ↓ mihoyaAjN, A thing, or person, that raises, rouses, excites, stirs up, or provokes, much: each of these epithets having a trans. signification. The former is also used as a fem. epithet. (L.)

haAy^ijN * (tropical:) Anger; an ebullition of anger, rage, or passion; syn. faworapN. (S, K.) Ex. haAja haAy^ijuhu (tropical:) His anger became roused, or excited; (S;) became violent; (TA;) he became inflamed with anger. (A.) And hadaA^ haAy^ijuhu (tropical:) The ebullition of his anger, rage, or passion, became appeased. (S.) ― -b2- haAy^ijN (S, K) and ↓ hay~ijN (TA) (tropical:) A stallion excited by lust; initum appetens. (S, K.) ― -b3- A^aroDN haAy^ijapN (tropical:) Land of which the leguminous plants have dried up, or become yellow: (S, K:) or, as in some lexicons, [and as in one copy of the S in my hands,] and become yellow: (TA:) or, of which the leguminous plants have dried up. (TA.) baqolN haAy^ijN, and ↓ hiyojN, (tropical:) Leguminous plants dried up, or drying up, [and yellow]. (L.)
mihoyaAjN * A she-camel that is excited by desire for its accustomed place, and hastens thither. (S, K.) ― -b2- See habuwjN. ― -b3- mihoyaAjN A camel that thirsts before [other] camels. (K.)

1 haAda * , aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN; (S, L, K;) and ↓ hy~d, (L, K,) inf. n. tahoyiydN; (TA;) He moved, or put in motion, (S, L, K,) a thing, (S,) or anything: this is the original signification. (L.) ― -b2- haAdN, aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN and haAdN; (L, K;) and ↓ hy~d; (K;) It frightened, or terrified, and afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, a person. (L, K.) ― -b3- haAda, aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN; (L, K;) and ↓ hy~d; (K;) He repaired; put into a right or proper state. (L, K.) It is said in a trad., with reference to the Mosque (of Mohammad, L), hidohu, (S, L,) meaning Repair it: (L:) or pull it down, and then repair it: (S, L:) or pull it down, and recommence the building of it, and repair it, and put it into a right or proper state. (L.) ― -b4- haAda, (Yaakoob, S, L, K,) aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN, and haAdN; (L;) and ↓ hy~d; (Yaakoob, S, L:) He chid a man; and turned him away, or back, from a thing: (S, * L, K:) or yahiydu is only used with a negative in this sense. (Yaakoob, K.) ― -b5- haAda He removed a person or thing from his or its place. (L, K. *) ― -b6- haAda He or it disquieted, disturbed, or unsettled, a person. (K.) ― -b7- maA yahiyduniY ka*aA Such a thing does not move me; (L;) it does not disquiet, disturb, or unsettle, me; I am not moved by it; do not care for it, or regard it. (S, L.) Accord. to Yaakoob, yhyd is only thus used with a negative. (S, L.) One says, laAa yhiydan~aka h`*aA Eano raA^oyika Let not this move thee at all from thine opinion. (TA.)
2 hay~ada see 1.
haAdN * : see hayodN.

hayodN * and ↓ hiydN and haAdN (S, L, K) and hayodK and hiydi and haAdi (IB, L) and hiydo (L) Cries by which camels are chidden (S, L, K) and urged. (L.) ― -b2- Also hayodN A mode of singing to camels, to urge or excite them: (L:) or the commencement of such singing: (TA:) when a man is about to sing to camels for this purpose, he says hydo hydo, and then sings, or prolongs and modulates his voice. (L, TA.) ― -b3- hayoda maA laka, (T, L, K,) and hiyda mAlk, (Sh, L,) and hiydo mAlk, (L,) [What is thy state, or condition, or thy affair, or business?] forms of speech used in inquiring of a man respecting his state, or condition, or his affair, or business; (T, L, K;) like as you say yaA h`*aA maA laka. (T, L.) One says, laqiyahu faqaAla lahu hayoda maA laka [He met him, and said to him, What is thy state, &c.?] and laqiytuhu famaA qaAla liY hayoda maA laka [I met him, and he said not to me, What is thy state, &c.?] (Lh, L,) and yaA hayoda maA liA^SoHaAbiki, and yaA hayoda maA A^aSoHaAbuka, [What is the state, &c., of thy companions?] (Ks, L,) and one says, lawo $atamotaniY maA qulotu hayoda, maAlaka, meaning, [Hadst thou reviled me, or shouldst thou revile me, I had not said, or would not say,] What is thine affair? (As, on the authority of 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar.) When a straycamel passes by a man, and he does not turn him aside, nor does he regard it, you say, mar~a baEiyrN famaA qaAla lahu hayoda maA laka, and, as related by an Arab of the desert, hayodi mA lk, with kesr to the d, [A camel passed by, and he said not to him, What is thy state, &c.?] (AZ, L.) ― -b4- ↓ maA lahu hayodN walaA haAdN He has no motion: (L, K:) or neither hyd nor hAd is to be said to him; meaning, he is not to be moved, nor withheld
from a thing, nor chidden away from it. (S, L.) -A2- hayodN i. q. hayodabN A flabby pubes. (Fr, in TA, voce kaEotabN.)
hiyod * : see hayodN.
hayodaAn * [whether with or without tenween is not shown] Cowardly; or a coward: (S, L;) a heavy, cowardly man; like hidaAnN. (L.)
2 hy~rhu * : see hw~rhu.
5 thy~r * : see thw~r.

1 haA$a Alqawomu * , aor. yahiy$u, (S,) inf. n. hayo$N, (S, K,) The people, or company of men, were, or became, in a state of commotion and excitement, (S, K, *) EalayonaA against us. (S.) ― -b2- haA$a Alqawomu baEoDuahumo A_ilaY baEoDK The people, or company of men, leaped, or sprang, one, or one portion. towards another, for fight, or conflict: (TA:) and Aln~aAsu baEoDuhumo A_ilaY baEoDK ↓ thy~$ The men, or people, leaped, or sprang, one, or one portion, towards another, (JK,) in the slightest kind of conflict. (TA.) ― -b3- haA$a fiY Aln~aAsi, (JK, TA,) inf. n. hayo$N, (JK, K,) He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension, between, or among, the people; made mischief among them. (JK, K, * TA.) ― -b4- haA$a Alr~julu, (JK,) inf. n. hayo$N, (JK, K,) The man used, or uttered much foul speech or language. (JK. Sgh, K. *) -A2- haA$a, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Fr, K,) He collected. (Fr, K, TA.) [In this sense, as well as the first, it is like hA$ having hawo$N for its inf. n.]
5 tahay~a$a see 1.

hayo$apN *
i. q. hawo$apN; (S, K;) Conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension. (JK, K.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) layosa fiY Alhayo$aAti qawadN, (K, TA,) or, accord. to one relation, fY Alhawo$aAti, (TA,) There is no retaliation for one slain in cases of conflict and faction, &c., when the slayer is unknown. (K, TA.) And hayo$aAt in the phrases hayo$aAtu All~ayoli and hayo$aAtu AlaA^asowaAqi is like hawo$aAt. (TA.) -A2- A company of men: (JK, S:) or a mixed, or confused, company. (K.)

1 haADahu * , aor. yahiyDu, (S, K,) inf. n. hayoDN, (S,) He broke it, namely, a bone, after it had become set; as also ↓ AhtADhu: (S, K:) and in like manner, a wing. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a thing) made him to fall back into his disease; (S, A, TA;) and so haADahu A_ilaY maA bihi. (TA.) You say also, hAD AlHuzonu Alqaloba (assumed tropical:) Grief affected the heart time after time. (TA.) And AlgazaAmu ↓ thy~Dhu [Vehemence of desire] returned to him a second time. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It softened him, or it. (TA.) And so IAar explains the verb as occurring in the saying of 'Áïsheh, lawonazala biAljibaAli Alr~aAsiyaAti maAnazala biA^abiY lahaADahaA (assumed tropical:) [Had that befallen the firm mountains which befell my father,] it had softened them. (TA.) [See also an ex. of a similar meaning voce ZlE.] ― -b4- (tropical:) It (drowsiness) made him languid. (A, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He broke him, or defeated him: as in the imprecation uttered by 'Omar the son of 'Abd-el-'Azeez against Yezeed the son of El-Mohelleb, when he broke his prison, and escaped, Aall~`hum~a A_in~ahu qado haADaniY fahiDohu (tropical:) O God, verily he hath broken me, or defeated me, and encroached on me (Aid~axala EalaY~a), then do Thou break him, or defeat him, and requite him for that which he hath done. (TA.)
2 hy~Dhu * (assumed tropical:) He roused, excited, or provoked, him; and it, namely the heart. (IB.)
5 tahay~aDa see 7: -A2- and see also 1.

7 AnhAD *
It [a bone] broke, or became broken, (JK, K,) after having been set; (JK;) and ↓ thy~D signifies the same. (K.)
8 A_ihotayaDa see 1.
hayoDN * (assumed tropical:) Any pain following upon pain. (S, TA.) See also hayoDapN. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Softness. (TA.)

hayoDapN * , (Lth, K,) or ↓ hayoDN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) A disease after a disease: a return of anxiety, or disquietude of mind; and of grief. (Lth, JK, K.) ― -b2- bihi hayoDapN (assumed tropical:) He has a purging and vomiting together; [i. e. the cholera: used in this sense in the present day:] (S, K:) or a discharge of the belly alone. (TA.) You say also, A^aSaAbato fulaAnFA hayoDapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) A change of his temperament, such as often occasions laxness of the bowels, causing a frequent going to and from the privy, affected such a one, from the disagreement with him of something which he had eaten. (TA.) ― -b3- bihi hayoDapu AlkaraY (tropical:) In him is the languor produced by drowsiness. (A, TA.)
mahiyDN * A bone broken after having become set; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ muhotaADN (S) and ↓ munohaADN. (S, A.)
muhotaADN * : see mahiyDN.
munohaADN * : see mahiyDN.

musotahaADN * [A beast] that has had a leg broken, and has recovered, and has been hastily laden and driven, and whose bone has consequently broken a second time, after it had become set and nearly well: or, accord. to ISh, one that has been diseased, and recovers, and is hastily put to work, so that he is distressed thereby; or that eats food, or drinks beverage, and in consequence relapses into disease. (TA.)

1 maA zaAla yahiyTu * , inf. n. hayoTN; and maA zaAla fiY hayoTK wamayoTK; He ceased not to be engaged in crying out, or vociferating, or calling for aid or succour; and in evil, or mischief; and raising a clamour, or confused noise. (K.) IKtt says, that yhyT has no pret. (TA.) [See also 3.]

3 hiyaATN * [in the senses assigned to it in what here follows] is an inf. n. of which the verb [haAyaTa] is obsolete. (L.) You say, maA zaAla fiY hiyaATK wamiyaATK He ceased not to be in a state of approaching, or drawing near, and retiring to a distance: (K:) or hiyaATN signifies the act of advancing: (Lh:) or hiyaATN and miyaATN respectively signify the most vehement driving in coming to water, and the most vehement driving in returning from water; and the meaning is, going and coming: (Aboo-Tálib:) or both signify the being in a state of commotion, tumult, or disturbance; as some say, arising from their saying “ No, by God, ” and “ Yes, by God: ” (TA:) [it is also said that] muhaAyaTapN [which is likewise an inf. n. of maAyaTa] signifies the act of crying out, or vociferating; and raising a clamour, or confused noise; [(see also 1;) and so, app., hiyaATN; for it is immediately added,] one says, waqaEa Alqawomu fiY hiyaATK wamiyaATK [as though meaning the people, or company of men, fell into vociferating, &c.]. (S.) bayonahumaA muhaAyaTapN is also said to signify Between them two is low, faint, or gentle, speaking. (TA.) [See miyaATN.] ― -b2- Accord. to IAar, hAyThu signifies He esteemed him weak. (TA.)

6 thAyTwA *
They came together, or coalesced, and arranged, or adjusted, their affairs; (Fr., S, K;) contr. of tmAyTwA. (Fr, S.)
haAy^iT * and maAy^iTN are explained by IAar as signifying Going and coming. (TA.)
